title: Diabetes
body:
Diabetes is a chronic metabolic condition marked by elevated blood glucose that damages the heart, blood vessels, eyes, kidneys and nerves over time. Type 2 diabetes, the most common form, occurs when the body becomes resistant to insulin or produces too little of it, and its prevalence has risen worldwide over the past three decades. Type 1 diabetes results from minimal or no insulin production, and across all types, lack of affordable insulin and diagnostics leaves over half of the 830 million affected people without treatment.

- **Symptoms:**
Type 1 diabetes often presents suddenly with frequent urination, thirst, constant hunger, weight loss, vision changes and fatigue. Type 2 diabetes usually shares these symptoms but they tend to be less marked, so the disease may remain undiagnosed for years, increasing the chances of complications.

- **Treatment:**
Living well with diabetes starts with early diagnosis and access to basic diagnostics such as blood glucose testing, followed by periodic specialist assessments for complications. Blood glucose should be controlled through diet, physical activity and medication when needed, while blood pressure and lipid management lower cardiovascular risks. Regular screening for eye, kidney and foot damage and timely treatment of complications further improve outcomes.

- **Prevention:**
Although type 1 diabetes cannot currently be prevented, effective strategies exist to prevent type 2 diabetes and related complications. Population-wide policies and setting-specific practices that promote regular exercise, healthy eating, smoke-free lifestyles and control of blood pressure and lipids support better health regardless of diabetes status.

title: Hypertension
body:
**About the condition:**
- Hypertension (high blood pressure) occurs when blood flowing through vessels exerts persistently elevated force, making the heart work harder.
- It is a serious, often silent condition that raises the risk of heart, brain, kidney, and other diseases, contributing to premature deaths worldwide and disproportionately affecting low- and middle-income countries.

**Symptoms:**
- Many people are asymptomatic, but signs can include early morning headaches, nosebleeds, irregular heart rhythms, vision changes, and buzzing in the ears.
- Severe stages may lead to fatigue, nausea, vomiting, confusion, anxiety, chest pain, and muscle tremors; untreated hypertension can trigger angina, heart attacks, heart failure, arrhythmias, or sudden death.

**Causes/Risk factors:**
- Modifiable factors: high salt intake, diets rich in saturated and trans fats, low fruit and vegetable consumption, physical inactivity, tobacco use, harmful alcohol consumption, being overweight or obese, and prolonged exposure to air pollution.
- Non-modifiable factors: family history of hypertension, age over 65, and co-existing diseases such as diabetes or kidney disease.

**Prevention/Management:**
- Reduce modifiable risks through healthier diets, increased physical activity, weight management, quitting tobacco, limiting alcohol, and minimizing air-pollution exposure when possible.
- Manage mental stress, monitor blood pressure regularly (at home or with a health professional), and treat high blood pressure alongside any other medical conditions.

title: Cardiovascular Diseases
body:
**About the condition:**
- Cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) are disorders of the heart and blood vessels—including coronary heart disease, cerebrovascular disease, and rheumatic heart disease—and are the leading global cause of death (≈17.9 million annually), with many deaths occurring prematurely (<70 years).
- Heart attacks and strokes account for most CVD deaths; detecting high-risk individuals and ensuring access to essential medicines and health technologies in primary care can avert premature mortality.

**Symptoms:**
- Heart attack: pain or discomfort in the chest, arms, left shoulder, elbows, jaw, or back; difficulty breathing; nausea or vomiting; light-headedness or faintness; cold sweat; pallor. Women more often present with shortness of breath, nausea, vomiting, and back or jaw pain.
- Stroke: sudden weakness or numbness of face/arm/leg (especially one side), confusion, difficulty speaking or understanding, vision problems, difficulty walking/dizziness/loss of balance, severe headache without known cause, fainting or unconsciousness.
- Rheumatic heart disease: shortness of breath, fatigue, irregular heartbeats, chest pain, fainting; rheumatic fever symptoms include fever, joint pain and swelling, nausea, stomach cramps, vomiting.

**Causes/Risk factors:**
- Behavioural: unhealthy diet (high salt, low fruit/vegetables), physical inactivity, tobacco use, harmful alcohol consumption.
- Environmental: air pollution contributing to heart disease and stroke risk.
- Physiological/intermediate: raised blood pressure, blood glucose, blood lipids, overweight/obesity; linked social drivers include ageing, income, and urbanization.

**Prevention/Management:**
- Stop tobacco use, limit dietary salt, eat more fruit and vegetables, engage in regular physical activity, and avoid harmful alcohol use.
- Improve air quality, reduce pollution, and implement health policies that make healthy choices affordable and accessible, fostering sustained behaviour change.
- Identify high-risk individuals early and provide appropriate treatment, counselling, and access to noncommunicable disease medicines and basic health technologies.

**When to see a doctor:**
- Seek immediate medical care for any signs of heart attack or stroke, or if experiencing the listed rheumatic heart disease or rheumatic fever symptoms.

title: Cancer
body:
Cancer is a group of diseases caused by uncontrolled growth of abnormal cells that can invade nearby tissues or spread (metastasize) to distant organs, making it one of the leading global causes of death and a major burden on individuals and health systems.

**Causes**
- Tobacco use, including smokeless forms
- Unhealthy weight, poor diets low in fruits and vegetables, and physical inactivity
- Excess alcohol use and unsafe sex
- Chronic infections such as hepatitis B or HPV, especially in low- and middle-income countries
- Ultraviolet and unnecessary ionizing radiation exposure (including unsafe occupational or medical exposures)
- Household smoke from solid fuels and urban air pollution

**Prevention**
- Modify or avoid the above risk factors wherever possible
- Maintain a healthy diet and regular physical activity
- Limit alcohol, practice safe sex, and stay up to date on hepatitis B and HPV vaccinations
- Reduce UV exposure and ensure radiation is used safely in workplaces and medical settings
- Seek regular medical care to enable early detection and timely management

**When to See a Doctor**
- If you notice persistent or unusual symptoms that could indicate cancer, seek evaluation promptly for early diagnosis
- Participate in recommended screening programs to detect abnormalities before symptoms appear and obtain timely referral for diagnosis and treatment
- Consult healthcare teams to discuss treatment options (surgery, medicines, radiotherapy) and supportive services such as palliative or survivorship care

title: Mental Health
body:
Mental health is a state of well-being that lets people cope with life’s stresses, realize their abilities, learn and work effectively, and contribute to their communities, making it intrinsic to overall health.

**Causes**
- Combined individual, family, community and structural pressures can undermine mental health
- Adverse circumstances such as poverty, violence, disability and inequality increase the risk of developing a mental health condition
- Under-resourced health systems, poor-quality care, stigma, discrimination and human rights violations further worsen mental health outcomes

**Prevention**
- Countries are pursuing the WHO Comprehensive Mental Health Action Plan (2013–2030), which emphasizes governance, community-based care, and coordinated promotion and prevention strategies
- WHO initiatives like the World Mental Health Report, the Special Initiative for Mental Health and mhGAP support nations in scaling up affordable services and community networks focused on prevention and early support

title: Depression
body:
Depressive disorder is a common mental health condition marked by a persistent low mood or loss of interest in activities, lasting most of the day nearly every day for at least two weeks and affecting daily functioning worldwide.

**Symptoms**
- Disturbed sleep patterns and appetite changes
- Feelings of low self-worth, hopelessness about the future, or thoughts about dying
- Tiredness, poor concentration, and loss of pleasure or interest in usual activities

**Causes**
- Complex interactions among social, psychological and biological factors
- History of abuse, severe losses or other adverse events
- Ongoing problems at school or work that contribute to stress and distress

**Prevention**
- Structured prevention programmes that reduce depression risk
- Accessible psychological treatments and medications (though often limited in low- and middle-income countries)
- WHO-supported initiatives such as mhGAP, Problem Management Plus, Group IPT, Thinking Healthy, Step-by-Step, and self-help resources like Doing What Matters in Times of Stress to expand early care and self-management

title: Nutrition
body:
Nutrition underpins health and development by supporting infant, child and maternal outcomes, strengthening immunity, enabling safer pregnancy and childbirth, lowering noncommunicable disease risk, and fostering productivity, economic growth and longevity.

**Causes**
- Malnutrition takes multiple forms: undernutrition (wasting, stunting), micronutrient deficiencies, overweight, obesity and diet-related NCDs
- Low- and middle-income countries face a dual burden of undernutrition and obesity, with undernutrition linked to about 45% of deaths among children under 5
- Limited exclusive breastfeeding (only 44% of infants under 6 months) and high sodium intake beyond the 5 g/day recommendation contribute to poor nutritional outcomes

**Prevention**
- WHO's 2016–2025 nutrition strategy and related frameworks (maternal, infant and young child nutrition plan; NCD global action plan; women’s, children’s and adolescents’ health strategy) guide evidence-based policies and interventions
- Global priorities include reducing salt intake and eliminating industrially produced trans fats from the food supply to curb diet-related diseases
- Breastfeeding promotion and comprehensive nutrition programmes aim to break the cycle of malnutrition across populations

title: Malaria
body:
Malaria is a serious yet preventable and curable disease caused by parasites transmitted through bites of infected female *Anopheles* mosquitoes, with *Plasmodium falciparum* and *Plasmodium vivax* posing the greatest risks and placing nearly half of the global population at risk, especially in sub-Saharan Africa.

**Symptoms**
- Acute febrile illness starting 10–15 days after an infective mosquito bite, with fever, chills and headaches that resemble other illnesses
- Progression to severe disease and potential fatality within 24 hours if *P. falciparum* malaria is left untreated
- Severe anaemia, respiratory distress linked to metabolic acidosis, or cerebral malaria in children; multi-organ failure in adults; asymptomatic infections may occur in partially immune individuals

**Causes**
- Infection by malaria parasites transmitted via female *Anopheles* mosquito bites
- High burden regions include sub-Saharan Africa, South-East Asia, Eastern Mediterranean, Western Pacific and the Americas, with children under five, pregnant women, people with HIV/AIDS, non-immune migrants, travellers and mobile populations at heightened risk

**Prevention**
- Early diagnosis and timely treatment to reduce severity, prevent deaths and limit transmission
- Artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT) as the recommended first-line treatment for *P. falciparum*
- Preventive antimalarial medicines and chemoprophylaxis for travellers to malaria-endemic regions, coupled with professional medical or public health advice
- WHO-endorsed vector control strategies to protect populations at risk

title: Breast Cancer
body:
Breast cancer occurs worldwide, causing about 2.3 million cases and 670 000 deaths in 2022; it affects women in almost every country (with 0.5–1% of cases in men) and demands early diagnosis paired with comprehensive treatment, rehabilitation and palliative care to reduce its burden.

**Symptoms**
- Lumps or thickening in the breast
- Changes in breast size or shape
- Skin dimpling, redness or other visible skin changes
- Nipple changes or discharge
- Swollen lymph nodes

**Causes**
- Female sex and increasing age (roughly 99% of cases occur in women)
- Obesity, harmful alcohol use, tobacco use and certain reproductive histories
- Family history, radiation exposure, hormone therapy and genetic mutations (BRCA1, BRCA2, PALB2)
- Many cases still arise without identifiable risk factors

**Prevention**
- Early diagnosis through awareness of symptoms, prompt medical evaluation and mammography screening for women aged 50–69
- Integrating timely diagnosis with comprehensive treatment, rehabilitation and palliative care to maintain optimal functioning and improve outcomes
- Applying WHO's Global Breast Cancer Initiative focus on health promotion, timely diagnosis and complete treatment plans to drive mortality reductions

**When to See a Doctor**
- Seek prompt medical evaluation if any of the listed breast changes or symptoms appear
- Follow recommended screening schedules (such as mammography for women aged 50–69) to detect early-stage disease

title: Asthma
body:
Asthma is a major noncommunicable disease affecting children and adults worldwide, caused by airway inflammation and narrowing that trigger cough, wheeze and shortness of breath; in 2019 it affected about 262 million people and led to 455 000 deaths, with most fatalities occurring in low-income settings where underdiagnosis and undertreatment persist.

**Symptoms**
- Persistent cough, often worse at night
- Wheezing sounds when breathing
- Shortness of breath or difficulty breathing, especially during exercise or at night
- Chest tightness
- Episodes triggered by cold, weather changes, allergens, smoke, fumes, dust, perfumes or infections

**Causes**
- Family history of asthma or allergies (eczema, rhinitis)
- Urban lifestyles, environmental smoke and pollution exposure
- Early childhood events affecting lung development (low birth weight, prematurity)
- Exposure to allergens such as dust mites, moulds and chemicals
- Obesity

**Prevention**
- Avoid or reduce exposure to known triggers (allergens, smoke, pollutants, fumes)
- Follow individualized action plans and education programmes that teach treatment use, trigger avoidance and response steps for worsening symptoms
- Utilize inhaled medications (bronchodilators and steroids) with spacers when needed to keep airway inflammation controlled and limit severe attacks

**When to See a Doctor**
- Seek medical evaluation to confirm asthma if symptoms such as persistent cough, wheezing, shortness of breath or chest tightness occur
- Consult healthcare professionals promptly when symptoms worsen, interfere with sleep, work or school, or require frequent reliever medication

title: Anaemia
body:
Anaemia is a major public health concern, mainly affecting young children, pregnant and postpartum women, and menstruating adolescent girls and women. Low- and lower-middle income countries bear the greatest burden of anaemia, particularly affecting populations living in rural settings, in poorer households and who have received no formal education. Globally, it is estimated that 40% of all children aged 6–59 months, 37% of pregnant women and 30% of women 15–49 years of age are affected by anaemia. Anaemia caused 50 million years of healthy life lost due to disability in 2019. The largest causes were dietary iron deficiency, thalassaemia and sickle cell trait, and malaria.

**Overview:**
Anaemia is a condition in which the number of red blood cells or the haemoglobin concentration within them is lower than normal. It mainly affects women and children. Anaemia occurs when there isn't enough haemoglobin in the body to carry oxygen to the organs and tissues. In severe cases, anaemia can cause poor cognitive and motor development in children. It can also cause problems for pregnant women and their babies. Anaemia can be caused by poor nutrition, infections, chronic diseases, heavy menstruation, pregnancy issues and family history. It is often caused by a lack of iron in the blood. Anaemia is preventable and treatable. In many low- and lower-middle income settings, the most commonly-recognized causes of anaemia are iron deficiency and malaria.

**Scope of the problem:**
The population groups most vulnerable to anaemia include children under 5 years of age, particularly infants and children under 2 years of age, menstruating adolescent girls and women, and pregnant and postpartum women. Anaemia is estimated to affect half a billion women 15–49 years of age and 269 million children 6–59 months of age worldwide. In 2019, 30% (539 million) of non-pregnant women and 37% (32 million) of pregnant women aged 15–49 years were affected by anaemia. The WHO Regions of Africa and South-East Asia are most affected with an estimated 106 million women and 103 million children affected by anaemia in Africa and 244 million women and 83 million children affected in South-East Asia.

**Signs and symptoms:**
Anaemia causes symptoms such as fatigue, reduced physical work capacity, and shortness of breath. Anaemia is an indicator of poor nutrition and other health problems. Common and non-specific symptoms of anaemia include: tiredness, dizziness or feeling light-headed, cold hands and feet, headache, and shortness of breath, especially upon exertion. Severe anaemia can cause more serious symptoms including: pale mucous membranes (in the mouth, nose etc.), pale skin and under the fingernails, rapid breathing and heart rate, dizziness when standing up, and bruising more easily.

**Causes:**
Anaemia is diagnosed based on blood haemoglobin concentrations falling below specified thresholds established based on age, sex, and physiological status. It is considered a symptom of an underlying condition(s). Anaemia may be caused by several factors: nutrient deficiencies, inadequate diet (or the inadequate absorption of nutrients), infections, inflammation, chronic diseases, gynaecological and obstetric conditions, and inherited red blood cell disorders. Iron deficiency, primarily due to inadequate dietary iron intake, is considered the most common nutritional deficiency leading to anaemia. Deficiencies in vitamin A, folate, vitamin B12 and riboflavin can also result in anaemia due to their specific roles in the synthesis of haemoglobin and/or erythrocyte production. Additional mechanisms include nutrient losses (e.g. blood loss from parasitic infections, haemorrhage associated with childbirth, or menstrual loss), impaired absorption, low iron stores at birth, and nutrient interactions affecting iron bioavailability. Infections can be another important cause of anaemia, depending on the local burden of infectious diseases, such as malaria, tuberculosis, HIV and parasitic infections. Infections can impair nutrient absorption and metabolism (e.g. malaria, ascariasis) or can cause nutrient loss (e.g. schistosomiasis, hookworm infection). Many different chronic conditions can cause inflammation and lead to anaemia of inflammation or anaemia of chronic disease. HIV infection causes anaemia through a wide range of mechanisms including ineffective production or excessive destruction of red blood cells, blood loss, and side effects of the drug treatment. Consistent heavy menstrual losses, maternal blood volume expansion during pregnancy, and blood loss during and after childbirth, particularly in cases of postpartum haemorrhage, commonly lead to anaemia. Additionally, in some regions, inherited red blood cell disorders are a common cause of anaemia. These include conditions such as α- and β-thalassemia due to abnormalities of haemoglobin synthesis, sickle cell disorders due to changes in the haemoglobin structure, other haemoglobinopathies due to haemoglobin gene variants, abnormalities of red cell enzymes, or abnormalities of the red blood cell membrane.

**Treatment and prevention:**
The treatment and prevention of anaemia depend on the underlying cause of the condition. There are many effective ways to treat and prevent anaemia. Changes in diet can help reduce anaemia in some cases, including: eating foods that are rich in iron, folate, vitamin B12, vitamin A, and other nutrients; eating a healthy diet with a variety of foods; and taking supplements if a qualified health-care provider recommends them. Other health conditions can cause anaemia. Actions include: prevent and treat malaria; prevent and treat schistosomiasis and other infections caused by soil-transmitted helminths (parasitic worms); get vaccinated and practice good hygiene to prevent infections; manage chronic diseases like obesity and digestive problems; wait at least 24 months between pregnancies and use birth control to prevent unintended pregnancies; prevent and treat heavy menstrual bleeding and haemorrhage before or after birth; delay umbilical cord clamping after childbirth (not earlier than 1 minute); and treat inherited red blood cell disorders like sickle-cell disease and thalassemia.

**Self-care:**
There are several ways to help prevent and manage anaemia in daily life, including eating a healthy and diverse diet and speaking to a health-care provider early if you have symptoms of anaemia. To keep a healthy and diverse diet: eat iron-rich foods, including lean red meats, fish and poultry, legumes (e.g. lentils and beans), fortified cereals and dark green leafy vegetables; eat foods rich in vitamin C (such as fruits and vegetables) which help the body absorb iron; and avoid foods that slow down iron absorption when consuming iron-rich foods, such as bran in cereals (wholewheat flour, oats), tea, coffee, cocoa and calcium. If you take calcium and iron supplements, take them at different times during the day. People with heavy menstrual bleeding should see their doctor for treatment. Doctors may recommend iron supplements or hormonal contraceptives. Some infections can cause anaemia. Wash your hands with soap and water and use clean toilets to reduce the risk of infection. Malaria can also cause anaemia. People living in places where malaria is common should follow prevention advice from local health authorities. Seek prompt treatment if you suspect you have malaria.

**Global impact:**
The consequences of anaemia can vary. It can affect school performance (through developmental delays and behavioural disturbances such as decreased motor activity, social interaction and attention to tasks), productivity in adult life and overall quality of life in general. During pregnancy, anaemia has been associated with poor maternal and birth outcomes, including premature birth, low birth weight and maternal mortality. In addition to the health consequences, anaemia can have important financial impacts for individuals, families, communities and countries. It is estimated that for every US$ 1 invested in reducing anaemia in women, US$ 12 in economic returns could potentially be produced.

**WHO Response:**
Anaemia reduction is included as one of six World Health Assembly Global Nutrition Targets within the Comprehensive implementation plan on maternal, infant and young child nutrition. Additionally, anaemia in women 15–49 years of age is one of the targets for the United Nations 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. WHO has committed to supporting countries to reduce anaemia. At the Nutrition for Growth Summit in 2021, WHO committed to develop a comprehensive framework for action to prevent, diagnose and manage anaemia through a multisectoral approach. WHO, together with UNICEF, is also establishing an Anaemia Action Alliance, bringing partners across sectors together to support implementation of the framework at the country level.

title: Arthritis
body:
**Key Facts:**
• Arthritis affects about 1 in 5 U.S. adults
• Affects the joints, tissues around the joint, and other connective tissues
• Leading cause of work disability among adults
• People with other chronic conditions (obesity, diabetes, heart disease) often have arthritis

**Overview:**
• Arthritis is a general term for conditions that affect the joints, tissues around joints, and other connective tissues
• There are more than 100 types of arthritis
• The causes of some forms of arthritis are unknown
• About 54 million U.S. adults have arthritis
• The number of people with arthritis is expected to increase as the population grows and ages

**Risk Factors:**
• Smoking
• Having overweight or obesity
• Joint injuries (from sports, falls, and accidents)
• Work-related activities that lead to joint injury (bending, squatting, and other repetitive motions)

**Symptoms and Diagnosis:**
• Symptoms vary by arthritis type but usually include:
  - Joint pain
  - Stiffness
• Health care providers can diagnose arthritis by:
  - Reviewing your health and family history
  - Doing a physical exam
  - Taking X-rays
  - Doing lab tests (as needed)
• Once diagnosed, you can work with your provider to decide on the best ways to manage and treat it

**Managing Your Arthritis:**
• Importance of managing symptoms:
  - Prevents or delays it from getting worse or causing disability
  - Reduces pain
  - Improves overall health and well-being
• Five ways to manage arthritis and its symptoms:
  1. Learn self-management skills
  2. Be physically active
  3. Manage your weight
  4. Protect your joints
  5. Talk to your health care provider if you have symptoms
• Early diagnosis allows for sooner treatment to lessen effects and prevent or delay progression
• Joint-friendly physical activity (like walking) can help arthritis pain

**Treatment:**
• There is no cure for arthritis, but it can be treated and managed
• Treatments vary depending on arthritis type and may include:
  - Over-the-counter medicines
  - Physical therapy
  - Prescription medicines
  - Surgery (if needed)
• Your provider will discuss treatment options that are right for your arthritis type and personal needs
• Rheumatologists are doctors trained as experts in diagnosing, treating, and caring for people with arthritis

title: Liver Cancer
body:
Liver cancer can begin in the liver or spread there from elsewhere, and its seriousness depends on tumour size, location, spread, whether it is primary or secondary, and your overall health.

**Symptoms**
- Yellowing of the eyes or skin (jaundice), sometimes with itchy skin, dark urine or pale stools
- Loss of appetite, unintentional weight loss, tiredness, flu-like malaise or a lump on the right side of the tummy
- Digestive changes such as nausea or vomiting, pain in the upper right abdomen or right shoulder, feeling full quickly, or abdominal swelling unrelated to meals

**Causes**
- Age over 60 (most common over 85) and male sex
- Medical conditions including hepatitis, liver cirrhosis, gallstones, diabetes, liver flukes or HIV
- Family history (parent or sibling with primary liver cancer)
- Secondary liver cancer arising when cancers elsewhere spread to the liver; many cases relate to lifestyle factors

**Prevention**
- Maintain a healthy weight
- Use protective clothing and masks when working around harmful chemicals
- Limit alcohol intake to no more than 14 units per week
- Quit smoking

title: Chronic Kidney Disease
body:
Chronic kidney disease (CKD) affects more than 1 in 7 American adults, often without obvious signs, and requires blood and urine tests for detection so treatment can begin early to protect kidney function and overall health.

**Causes**
- Kidney damage that lowers filtering ability, allowing waste and fluid to build up and contribute to complications such as heart disease, anemia, mineral imbalances and depression
- Diabetes and high blood pressure are the leading causes of kidney failure in the United States, accounting for two-thirds of new cases

**Prevention**
- Keep blood pressure below 140/90 mm Hg (or your personalised target)
- Stay within target blood sugar ranges if you have diabetes
- Be physically active, lose weight if needed and quit smoking to protect kidney health
- Get tested regularly if you're at risk and include a nephrologist on your care team when needed
- Follow prescribed medicines, including ACE inhibitors or ARBs when recommended, and work with a dietician on a kidney-friendly eating plan that adapts as your health changes

title: Heart Attack
body:
A heart attack (myocardial infarction) happens when blood flow to the heart muscle is suddenly blocked, usually by a clot, and it is a life-threatening emergency that requires rapid treatment to limit damage.

**Symptoms**
- Chest pain or pressure, heaviness, tightness or squeezing across the chest
- Pain spreading to the arms (often the left but possibly both), jaw, neck, back or tummy
- Lightheadedness, dizziness, sweating or shortness of breath
- Nausea, vomiting, coughing, wheezing or overwhelming anxiety similar to a panic attack
- Some people experience only milder discomfort resembling indigestion, or symptoms such as breathlessness, sickness or back/jaw pain without chest pain

**Causes**
- Coronary heart disease, where fatty plaques clog the coronary arteries
- Plaque rupture triggers a blood clot that blocks blood flow to the heart muscle, causing the heart attack

**Prevention**
- Quit smoking and limit alcohol intake
- Maintain a healthy weight, eat a low-fat, high-fibre diet with wholegrains plus at least five portions of fruit and vegetables daily
- Do at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic exercise each week (unless your doctor advises otherwise)

**When to See a Doctor**
- Call emergency services (999) and request an ambulance immediately if a heart attack is suspected—the faster the response, the better the outcome
- While waiting for help, chewing and swallowing a 300 mg aspirin tablet (if not allergic) can help thin the blood

title: Underactive Thyroid (Hypothyroidism)
body:
An underactive thyroid (hypothyroidism) happens when the thyroid gland does not produce enough hormone, leading to issues such as tiredness and weight gain that can usually be managed with lifelong treatment.

**Symptoms**
- Extreme tiredness, feeling cold more than usual or weight gain
- Constipation, difficulty concentrating, low mood or depression
- Dry skin, dry hair or hair loss, a hoarse voice, irregular or heavy periods
- Symptoms often develop slowly, may be mild at first and can resemble other conditions

**Causes**
- Hashimoto's disease, where the immune system attacks the thyroid (most common in women aged 30–50)
- Other thyroid problems such as thyroiditis, previous thyroid surgery or radiotherapy, or treatment for an overactive thyroid
- Low iodine intake (rare in the UK), certain medicines and family history of thyroid disease

**When to See a Doctor**
- See a GP if you experience possible hypothyroidism symptoms so they can examine you and order blood tests (TSH and T4)
- Inform your GP if you are pregnant or planning pregnancy, because levothyroxine doses and monitoring usually need adjustment to reduce risks such as pre-eclampsia, birth defects, premature birth or miscarriage

title: Ageing and Health
body:
People worldwide are living longer. Today most people can expect to live into their sixties and beyond. Every country in the world is experiencing growth in both the size and the proportion of older persons in the population. By 2030, 1 in 6 people in the world will be aged 60 years or over. At this time the share of the population aged 60 years and over will increase from 1 billion in 2020 to 1.4 billion. By 2050, the world's population of people aged 60 years and older will double (2.1 billion). The number of persons aged 80 years or older is expected to triple between 2020 and 2050 to reach 426 million. All countries face major challenges to ensure that their health and social systems are ready to make the most of this demographic shift. In 2050, 80% of older people will be living in low- and middle-income countries. The pace of population ageing is much faster than in the past. While this shift in distribution of a country's population towards older ages—known as population ageing—started in high-income countries, it is now low- and middle-income countries that are experiencing the greatest change. By 2050, two-thirds of the world's population over 60 years will live in low- and middle-income countries.

**Causes**
- Accumulation of a wide variety of molecular and cellular damage over time
- Gradual decrease in physical and mental capacity
- Growing risk of disease
- Some variations in older people's health are genetic
- Most variations are due to people's physical and social environments, including their homes, neighbourhoods, and communities
- Personal characteristics such as sex, ethnicity, or socioeconomic status
- The environments that people live in as children, or even as developing fetuses, combined with their personal characteristics, have long-term effects on how they age
- Beyond biological changes, ageing is often associated with other life transitions such as retirement, relocation to more appropriate housing and the death of friends and partners

**Prevention**
- Maintain healthy behaviours throughout life, particularly eating a balanced diet
- Engage in regular physical activity
- Refrain from tobacco use
- These behaviours contribute to reducing the risk of non-communicable diseases, improving physical and mental capacity and delaying care dependency
- Supportive physical and social environments enable people to do what is important to them, despite losses in capacity
- The availability of safe and accessible public buildings and transport, and places that are easy to walk around, are examples of supportive environments
- Physical and social environments can affect health directly or through barriers or incentives that affect opportunities, decisions and health behaviour

title: Obesity and Overweight
body:
Overweight is a condition of excessive fat deposits. Obesity is a chronic complex disease defined by excessive fat deposits that can impair health. The diagnosis of overweight and obesity is made by measuring people's weight and height and by calculating the body mass index (BMI): weight (kg)/height² (m²). The body mass index is a surrogate marker of fatness and additional measurements, such as the waist circumference, can help the diagnosis of obesity. For adults, WHO defines overweight and obesity as follows: overweight is a BMI greater than or equal to 25; and obesity is a BMI greater than or equal to 30. For children under 5 years of age: overweight is weight-for-height greater than 2 standard deviations above WHO Child Growth Standards median; and obesity is weight-for-height greater than 3 standard deviations above the WHO Child Growth Standards median. For children aged between 5–19 years: overweight is BMI-for-age greater than 1 standard deviation above the WHO Growth Reference median; and obesity is greater than 2 standard deviations above the WHO Growth Reference median. Obesity can lead to increased risk of type 2 diabetes and heart disease, it can affect bone health and reproduction, it increases the risk of certain cancers. Obesity influences the quality of living, such as sleeping or moving.

**Causes**
- Imbalance of energy intake (diet) and energy expenditure (physical activity)
- Multifactorial disease due to obesogenic environments
- Psycho-social factors
- Genetic variants
- In a subgroup of patients, single major etiological factors can be identified (medications, diseases, immobilization, iatrogenic procedures, monogenic disease/genetic syndrome)
- Structural factors limiting the availability of healthy sustainable food at locally affordable prices
- Lack of safe and easy physical mobility into the daily life of all people
- Absence of adequate legal and regulatory environment
- Lack of an effective health system response to identify excess weight gain and fat deposition in their early stages

**Prevention**
- Ensure appropriate weight gain during pregnancy
- Practice exclusive breastfeeding in the first 6 months after birth and continued breastfeeding until 24 months or beyond
- Support behaviours of children around healthy eating, physical activity, sedentary behaviours and sleep, regardless of current weight status
- Limit screen time
- Limit consumption of sugar sweetened beverages and energy-dense foods and promote other healthy eating behaviours
- Enjoy a healthy life (healthy diet, physical activity, sleep duration and quality, avoid tobacco and alcohol, emotional self-regulation)
- Limit energy intake from total fats and sugars and increase consumption of fruit and vegetables, as well as legumes, whole grains and nuts
- Engage in regular physical activity
- Create supportive environments and communities that embed healthy diets and regular physical activity as the most accessible, available and affordable behaviours of daily life
- Structural, fiscal and regulatory actions aimed at creating healthy food environments that make healthier food options available, accessible and desirable
- Health sector responses designed and equipped to identify risk, prevent, treat and manage the disease
- Reduce the fat, sugar and salt content of processed foods
- Restrict marketing of foods high in sugars, salt and fats, especially those foods aimed at children and teenagers

title: Malnutrition
body:
Malnutrition covers deficiencies, excesses or imbalances of energy and nutrients, ranging from undernutrition and micronutrient problems to overweight, obesity and diet-related noncommunicable diseases that impact people worldwide, particularly children under five and populations in low- and middle-income countries.

**Causes**
- Undernutrition: wasting (acute weight loss), stunting (chronic low height-for-age) and underweight, often driven by inadequate food intake, infections and poor caregiving environments
- Micronutrient-related malnutrition: deficiencies or excesses of vitamins and minerals such as iodine, vitamin A and iron that impair growth and development
- Overweight and obesity: energy-dense diets high in sugars and fats combined with reduced physical activity leading to excessive fat accumulation, increased BMI and diet-related NCDs like cardiovascular disease, certain cancers and diabetes
- Poverty and inequity that limit access to nutritious foods, healthcare and supportive environments, making women, infants, children and adolescents especially vulnerable
tags: UN Decade of Action on Nutrition

title: Iron Deficiency Anaemia
body:
Iron deficiency anaemia develops when the body lacks iron, commonly due to blood loss or pregnancy, and is managed with iron tablets plus iron-rich foods.

**Symptoms**
- Tiredness, low energy, shortness of breath, heart palpitations, pale skin or headaches
- Less common issues such as tinnitus, altered taste, itching, sore tongue, hair loss, craving non-food items (pica), difficulty swallowing, mouth ulcers, spoon-shaped nails and restless legs syndrome

**Causes**
- Heavy periods or pregnancy, especially when dietary iron intake is low
- Blood loss from the stomach or intestines because of NSAID use, stomach ulcers, inflamed bowel or oesophagus, piles, or (less commonly) bowel or stomach cancers
- Any other condition or action that leads to blood loss

**Prevention**
- Increase intake of iron-rich foods (dark green leafy vegetables, fortified cereals and bread, meat, dried fruits, pulses)
- Reduce items that inhibit iron absorption when eaten in large amounts (tea, coffee, milk, dairy, high-phytic-acid wholegrain cereals)
- Follow GP advice on iron tablets, take them for the recommended duration, and use vitamin C sources like orange juice to aid absorption while managing side effects as directed

title: Acne
body:
Acne is a common skin condition that causes spots, oily skin and sometimes painful areas, typically affecting the face, back and chest at some point in most people's lives.

**Symptoms**
- Spots forming on the face (almost everyone with acne), back (over half) and chest (about 15%)
- Six spot types: blackheads, whiteheads, papules, pustules, nodules and cysts, which can become tender, painful or lead to permanent scarring

**Causes**
- Hormonal changes (especially during puberty, menstrual cycles or pregnancy) that increase abnormal sebum production and thicken hair follicle linings, blocking pores
- P. acnes bacteria becoming more aggressive when sebum changes, triggering inflammation and pus formation
- Family history increasing likelihood; poor hygiene or sexual activity are not causes

**Prevention**
- Wash affected skin no more than twice daily with mild soap/cleanser and lukewarm water; avoid very hot or cold water
- Do not squeeze spots or try to clean out blackheads; remove make-up before bed and choose water-based non-comedogenic products
- Use fragrance-free water-based emollients if skin is dry, shower soon after exercise to limit sweat irritation, and keep hair clean and off the face
- Seek pharmacist advice for mild acne treatments such as low-strength benzoyl peroxide; prescription medicines or antibiotics may be needed for chest/back or severe cases

**When to See a Doctor**
- Talk to a pharmacist for mild acne; if over-the-counter options fail or acne causes distress, see a GP
- Consult a GP for moderate or severe acne, or if nodules or cysts develop, to prevent scarring and access appropriate prescription treatments (which may take several months to work)

title: Chickenpox
body:
Chickenpox is a highly contagious infection that mostly affects children, causes an itchy rash with feverish symptoms, usually settles within 1 to 2 weeks, but can become serious for pregnant people, newborns and anyone with a weakened immune system.

**Symptoms**
- Itchy, spotty rash that can appear anywhere on the body; fever, aches, pains and loss of appetite may occur before or after the rash
- Stage 1 (spots): lesions may appear inside the mouth or around the genitals, spread or stay localized, and look red, pink, darker or similar to surrounding skin (harder to see on brown or black skin)
- Stage 2 (blisters): fluid-filled blisters become very itchy and may burst
- Stage 3 (scabs): spots form flaky or leaking scabs while new spots can still appear

**Causes**
- Infection with the varicella-zoster virus spreads from 2 days before spots appear until all have scabbed (about 5 days after they first show)
- Transmission occurs through being in the same room as an infected person, touching contaminated objects, or contact with someone who has shingles if you've never had chickenpox (shingles itself is not caught from chickenpox)

**Prevention**
- Stay away from school, nursery or work until all spots have scabbed (usually 5 days) to avoid spreading the virus, especially to newborns, pregnant people or immunocompromised individuals
- Home care to ease symptoms and limit complications: drink plenty of fluids (ice lollies for reluctant children), take paracetamol for pain, trim nails and cover hands with socks at night to prevent scratching, use pharmacy cooling creams/gels or antihistamines for itching, bathe in cool water and pat dry, wear loose clothing, and avoid scratching to reduce scarring
- Avoid ibuprofen unless a doctor advises it, never give aspirin to under-16s, and steer clear of vulnerable groups while contagious
- NHS chickenpox vaccination is available when there is a risk of passing the virus to someone with weakened immunity (e.g., a parent on chemotherapy); private clinics also offer the vaccine for £120–£200

**When to See a Doctor**
- Contact a GP if unsure about the diagnosis or concerned about your/your child's symptoms, and inform the surgery beforehand if you suspect chickenpox
- Call NHS 111 urgently if symptoms suddenly worsen, dehydration signs appear (such as fewer wet nappies), the skin around blisters becomes hot, painful or red (redness may be harder to see on brown or black skin), or if you are breastfeeding, pregnant without prior chickenpox, immunocompromised, have a newborn affected/exposed, or were near someone with chickenpox/shingles
- Some high-risk people may need antiviral medicine within 24 hours of spots appearing to prevent complications

title: Hair Loss
body:
Hair loss is common and often harmless, though losing hair can feel upsetting; some types are permanent, others are temporary, and targeted treatment may help depending on the cause.

**Symptoms**
- Normal shedding is 50–100 hairs a day and may go unnoticed, but noticeable thinning or bald patches can affect wellbeing and confidence
- Male and female pattern baldness typically runs in families and can progress over time; other patterns may follow illness, stress, cancer treatment, significant weight loss or iron deficiency

**Causes**
- Permanent causes include hereditary male or female pattern baldness
- Temporary hair loss can result from illness, stress, cancer treatment, weight loss, iron deficiency or other medical conditions

**Prevention**
- Many cases do not need treatment and either resolve as you recover or represent normal ageing, but options exist when hair loss is distressing
- Medicines: finasteride (men only) and minoxidil (men and women) can slow pattern baldness but work only while used, are not 100% effective and may not be available on the NHS
- Covering options: synthetic wigs (last 6–9 months, cheaper, easier care but can be hot/itchy) or real-hair wigs (last 3–4 years, more natural but costlier and harder to maintain); some NHS funding is available depending on eligibility
- Specialist procedures available in certain clinics include steroid injections or creams for bald patches, topical or tablet immunotherapy, ultraviolet light treatment, permanent make-up (micropigmentation), hair transplants, scalp reduction surgery, and artificial hair implants; availability on the NHS varies
- Emotional support such as counselling, support groups or online forums can help people cope with the impact of hair loss

**When to See a Doctor**
- Visit a GP if worried about hair loss, to identify the cause, discuss wellbeing impacts and review treatment options before considering commercial hair clinics
- Hair loss linked to medical conditions often stops or reverses after treatment, so professional assessment is useful before pursuing private treatments

title: Back Pain
body:
Back pain—especially in the lower back—is very common, usually improves over a few weeks, but can return or signal more serious problems in rarer cases; self-care plus medical support can help ease symptoms.

**Symptoms**
- Pain intensity ranges from mild (comes and goes but allows daily activities) to moderate (constant, affects sleep and concentration) and severe (constant, overwhelming, limits movement, self-care and sleep)
- Pain may worsen with sneezing, coughing or bowel movements, or be located anywhere from the lower back to between the shoulders

**Causes**
- Often unclear but may stem from injuries such as pulled muscles or strains
- Conditions including slipped discs, sciatica (trapped nerve) or ankylosing spondylitis can trigger back pain
- Rarely, serious issues like broken bones, cancer or infection are responsible

**Prevention**
- Stay active and keep up daily activities; avoid prolonged bed rest
- Use ibuprofen or other anti-inflammatory medicine (paracetamol alone is not recommended but can be combined with another painkiller if advised)
- Apply ice packs (wrapped) to reduce pain/swelling and heat packs to relieve stiffness or muscle spasm
- Practise back-specific exercises and stretches, stopping if pain worsens, and consider activities such as walking, swimming, yoga or pilates

**When to See a Doctor**
- See a GP if home measures fail after a few weeks, pain limits daily tasks, grows more severe, or causes worry and coping difficulties; they may prescribe painkillers, muscle relaxants or refer for physiotherapy, manual therapy, CBT, nerve procedures or surgery when indicated
- Seek urgent GP/111 advice for back pain with high temperature, unexplained weight loss, lumps or shape changes, pain worse at night or after rest, pain triggered by sneezing/coughing/pooing, or pain higher up the back
- Call 999 or go to A&E (do not drive yourself) for back pain with pain/tingling/weakness/numbness in both legs, numbness around genitals or buttocks, difficulty peeing, loss of bladder/bowel control, chest pain, or pain after a serious accident; bring current medicines with you

title: Hearing Loss
body:
Hearing loss becomes more common with age but can affect anyone; many causes are treatable, so see a GP if you notice changes or others mention difficulties.

**Symptoms**
- Difficulty hearing people clearly, misunderstanding speech (especially in noisy settings) or needing higher TV/music volume
- Trouble following phone calls or conversations, frequently asking others to repeat themselves, or feeling tired/stressed from concentrating on listening
- Others may notice the problem first; in children it can affect speech and school progress, and spotting signs in babies may require using the GOV.UK sound-response checklist

**Causes**
- Gradual loss in both ears often stems from ageing or long-term loud-noise exposure
- Ear infections with earache, fever, itching, pressure or discharge; earwax build-up causing blocked sensation and itchiness (usually one ear)
- Perforated eardrum after infections, loud sounds or sudden pressure changes; labyrinthitis or Ménière's disease causing sudden hearing loss with dizziness, vertigo or tinnitus

**Prevention**
- Address reversible causes: GPs can treat infections (antibiotics) or remove earwax with drops or extraction; specialists may recommend hearing aids or implants when loss is permanent, improving loudness and clarity
- Manage daily life: reduce background noise during conversations, face the person speaking, ask for repetition or written notes, and explore assistive tools (phone/TV amplifiers, flashing or vibrating alarms, smartphone/tablet apps)
- Protect remaining hearing by wearing ear protection around loud noises, keeping music volumes comfortable, and avoiding putting fingers or objects like cotton buds into ears

**When to See a Doctor**
- Book a GP appointment if hearing seems to be getting gradually worse or if hearing has not returned after treating ear infections or earwax build-up; some pharmacies and opticians offer free hearing tests too
- Seek urgent GP/111 help for sudden hearing loss in one or both ears, hearing that worsens over days or weeks, or hearing loss accompanied by other symptoms such as earache or discharge—early treatment may be critical

title: Constipation
body:
Constipation means pooing less often than usual, passing hard or lumpy poo, or struggling to empty the bowels; it is common at all ages and usually improves with straightforward diet and lifestyle changes (this guidance is for adults).

**Symptoms**
- Fewer than 3 poos in a week or pooing less often than normal
- Stool that is unusually large or small, dry, hard or lumpy, causing straining or pain and a feeling that the bowels have not fully emptied
- Possible stomach ache, bloating or feeling sick; behaviour changes such as confusion may hint at constipation in older adults or people with dementia or learning disability

**Causes**
- Too little dietary fibre (fruit, vegetables, cereals) or insufficient fluids
- Low physical activity, long periods sitting or lying down, or ignoring the urge to poo
- Changes in diet or routine; side effects of medicines (including opioid painkillers); stress, anxiety or depression
- Pregnancy, the postnatal period, older age (over 65) and rare medical conditions such as diverticular disease or bowel cancer

**Prevention**
- Diet: eat a healthy balanced diet, gradually increase fibre, and choose sorbitol-containing fruits (apples, apricots, grapes/raisins, raspberries, strawberries); add wheat bran, oats or linseed; stay well hydrated and avoid alcohol
- Toilet habits: keep a regular time and give yourself enough privacy; respond promptly to the urge to poo; use a low stool to raise knees above hips when on the toilet
- Activity: incorporate daily walks or runs and stay generally active
- Pharmacy support: if lifestyle steps are not enough, ask a pharmacist to recommend a short-course laxative (most work within 3 days)

**When to See a Doctor**
- Consult a GP if constipation persists despite self-care, recurs frequently, or is accompanied by bloating, tiredness, tummy pain, blood in poo, unexplained weight loss, sudden changes in bowel habits, or constipation linked to prescribed medicines (speak to the GP before stopping any medicine)
- Seek medical help for signs of faecal impaction (diarrhoea leaking around a blockage), as treatment may include stronger laxatives, suppositories, mini enemas or manual removal by a healthcare professional

title: Cough
body:
Most coughs clear on their own within 3 to 4 weeks, and self-care usually manages the symptoms.

**Symptoms**
- Persistent coughing that may include hacking fits, difficulty stopping, chest discomfort, swollen neck glands, breathlessness, or coughing up mucus/blood (these features can signal more serious illness)
- Systemic effects such as fever, feeling very unwell, or unexplained weight loss may accompany a cough

**Causes**
- Commonly triggered by colds or flu
- Other causes include smoking, heartburn (acid reflux), allergies such as hay fever, infections like bronchitis or COVID-19, and post-nasal drip; rarely, a cough indicates something serious such as lung cancer

**Prevention**
- Rest, stay hydrated, and remain at home if feverish or too unwell for normal activities
- Manage discomfort with paracetamol or ibuprofen; try hot lemon and honey (not for babies under 1) or pelargonium for those aged 12+, understanding the evidence is limited and checking suitability (especially if pregnant)
- Pharmacy options such as cough syrups, medicines (avoid codeine-based products in children under 12) and cough sweets may reduce coughing frequency; decongestants and codeine mixtures do not stop coughs
- Prepare hot lemon and honey by mixing half a lemon and 1–2 teaspoons of honey in boiled water and drinking warm (avoid hot drinks for small children)

**When to See a Doctor**
- See a GP if a cough lasts longer than 3 weeks, you lose weight without explanation, or you have a weakened immune system (e.g., due to chemotherapy or diabetes)
- Seek urgent GP/111 help if the cough is severe or rapidly worsening, you feel very unwell, have chest pain, painful swollen neck glands, breathing difficulties, or cough up blood
- During appointments, GPs may listen to the chest, examine mucus samples, order X-rays, allergy or lung function tests, or rarely refer to a specialist; antibiotics are only given when clearly needed (such as confirmed bacterial infection or high complication risk)

title: High Temperature (Fever) in Children
body:
A high temperature (fever) is very common in babies and young children and usually returns to normal within 1 to 4 days.

**Symptoms**
- Temperature of 38°C or more (check with a digital thermometer placed in the armpit; wait a few minutes after a bath or if wrapped in blankets)
- Feeling hotter on the back or chest, sweating, looking or feeling unwell, or experiencing a febrile seizure (fit)

**Causes**
- The body's natural response to fighting infections such as coughs, colds, chickenpox or tonsillitis, and a common reaction after vaccinations

**Prevention**
- Home care: give plenty of fluids (continue breastfeeding), offer food if wanted, watch for dehydration, keep the child at home and check on them regularly, including overnight
- Medicines: give paracetamol or ibuprofen only if the child is distressed or uncomfortable, following the leaflet advice; never alternate the two unless instructed by a health professional; avoid aspirin in under-16s, paracetamol in babies under 2 months, and ibuprofen in babies under 3 months, under 5 kg, with chickenpox, dehydration or asthma (unless a doctor recommends it)
- Comfort: do not undress or sponge down the child, and do not overdress them in layers

**When to See a Doctor**
- Contact 111 or your GP urgently if a baby under 3 months has a temperature of 38°C or more, a child aged 3–6 months has 39°C or more, the fever lasts 5 days or longer, there are other illness signs (such as rash), appetite drops, behaviour changes worry you, or there are signs of dehydration (dry nappies, sunken eyes, lack of tears)
- Call 999 immediately if the child has a stiff neck, a rash that does not fade with a glass test, light sensitivity, their first fit, unusually cold hands and feet, skin/lips/tongue turning blue, grey, paler or blotchy (may be harder to see on brown or black skin), is drowsy or hard to wake, extremely agitated or confused, has difficulty breathing (grunting, stomach pulling under ribs, very fast breathing), or is not responding normally or interested in feeding/activities

title: What to do if Someone has a Seizure (Fit)
body:
Seeing someone have a seizure (fit) can be alarming, but calm, simple actions help keep them safe until it stops.

**Symptoms**
- Warning signs you might observe: unusual sensations (smell or taste), mood changes, sudden noises (falling) or movements (eyes rolling, head turning) before convulsions begin
- During a seizure, the person may stiffen, jerk or twitch in specific body areas, change colour (paler, flushed, blue or grey; on brown or black skin check palms, soles, lips, gums, inside eyelids), lose consciousness or awareness, have altered breathing, mumble, wander or fumble, bite their tongue, lose bladder or bowel control, or experience a febrile-type fit
- Afterward they may be drowsy, need to sleep, or feel confused; note how long recovery takes

**Prevention**
- During the seizure: move the person only if in danger (busy road, hot cooker), cushion their head, loosen tight neck clothing, and after convulsions stop turn them onto their side; if seated in a wheelchair, apply brakes, keep seatbelts/harnesses fastened, support and cushion the head without moving them
- Stay with them, speak calmly, time the seizure from start to finish, and keep food, drink, fingers or objects away from their mouth until fully recovered
- Gather useful details for their doctor: what they were doing beforehand, whether the seizure began without warning, breathing patterns, body parts involved, colour changes, duration, injuries, and whether they slept afterward
- People with epilepsy may carry care plans, emergency medicines, bracelets or cards—follow their plan if you are trained, and maintaining a seizure diary can help track events

**When to See a Doctor**
- Call 999 for an ambulance if it is the person’s first seizure, lasts longer than usual or beyond 5 minutes, repeats without regaining consciousness, or recovery is incomplete; also call if they are seriously injured or struggle to breathe afterward
- Not every seizure requires hospital care (many people with epilepsy manage at home), but emergency help is vital in the situations above

title: Brain Tumours
body:
A brain tumour is an abnormal growth of brain cells that can be low grade (grade 1–2, often benign and slower growing) or high grade (grade 3–4, cancerous, more likely to grow back); tumours may start in the brain or spread there from other sites.

**Symptoms**
- Headaches that change in pattern or intensity
- Seizures (fits)
- Persistent nausea, vomiting or drowsiness
- Mental or behavioural changes such as memory problems or personality shifts
- Progressive weakness or paralysis on one side of the body
- Vision or speech difficulties, with symptoms that may be absent at first or develop gradually

**Causes**
- Exact causes are often unknown, but risk increases with age (most often in adults 85–89), though some types are more common in children
- Exposure to radiation (including previous radiotherapy or, very rarely, CT scans/X-rays of the head)
- Family history and certain genetic conditions such as tuberous sclerosis, neurofibromatosis type 1 or 2, and Turner syndrome

**Prevention**
- Management focuses on tailored treatment plans based on tumour type, location, size, spread, cell abnormality and overall health; options include steroids to reduce swelling, symptom-relief medicines (anti-epileptics, painkillers), surgery to remove as much tumour as safely possible, radiotherapy and chemotherapy
- Non-cancerous tumours are often treated successfully, but regular follow-up appointments may be needed because there is a small chance of recurrence

**When to See a Doctor**
- Consult a GP if you develop the symptoms listed—especially headaches that differ from your usual pattern or worsen
- If no other cause is found, you may be referred to a neurologist for further assessment, including brain scans; early evaluation helps determine appropriate treatment and outlook (about 12,000 UK residents are diagnosed with primary brain tumours annually, roughly half cancerous)

title: Antibiotics
body:
Antibiotics treat or prevent certain bacterial infections by killing bacteria or stopping them spreading, but they do not work for viral illnesses (colds, flu, most coughs), and unnecessary use drives antibiotic resistance, so always follow medical advice.

**Symptoms**
- Common side effects when antibiotics are taken correctly include feeling or being sick, bloating, indigestion and diarrhoea
- Allergic reactions (more likely with penicillins or cephalosporins) can cause itchy, red, swollen, blistered or peeling rashes, wheeze, tight chest or throat, trouble breathing or talking, or swelling of the mouth, face, lips, tongue or throat; these signs of anaphylaxis require emergency care
- Taking doses too close together raises the risk of stomach pain, diarrhoea and nausea

**Causes**
- Antibiotics are prescribed for bacterial infections unlikely to clear without help, those that could take too long, carry serious complication risks or might easily spread to others; infectiousness may continue for 48 hours to 14 days after treatment starts, so seek GP/pharmacist advice
- High-risk people may receive prophylactic antibiotics before exposure to anticipated infections
- Formulations include tablets, capsules and liquids for mild to moderate infections; creams, lotions, sprays and drops for skin, eye or ear infections; and injections or intravenous drips for more serious illnesses
- Major antibiotic groups include:
  - Penicillins (penicillin, amoxicillin, co-amoxiclav, flucloxacillin, phenoxymethylpenicillin) for skin, chest and urinary infections
  - Cephalosporins (cefalexin) for many infections, including sepsis or meningitis
  - Aminoglycosides (gentamicin, tobramycin) mainly in hospital for severe infections, sometimes as eye/ear drops
  - Tetracyclines (tetracycline, doxycycline, lymecycline) for varied infections, acne or rosacea
  - Macrolides (azithromycin, erythromycin, clarithromycin) for lung/chest infections or penicillin-resistant cases
  - Fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin) once widely used for respiratory or urinary infections but now limited due to serious side effects
  - Other options include chloramphenicol (eye/ear), fusidic acid (skin/eye), and nitrofurantoin or trimethoprim (urinary tract infections)

**Prevention**
- Take antibiotics exactly as directed on the label, leaflet or by your GP/pharmacist; never share medicines prescribed for someone else
- If you miss a dose, take it as soon as possible unless it is nearly time for the next one—never double up; if multiple doses are missed or extra doses taken, contact a GP or NHS 111, especially if severe side effects occur
- Always inform healthcare professionals if you are pregnant or breastfeeding so suitable options can be chosen, and review possible interactions with medicines (e.g., contraceptive pill) or alcohol by reading the information leaflet or consulting a pharmacist/GP

**When to See a Doctor**
- Seek urgent medical help (call 999 or go to A&E) for symptoms of anaphylaxis such as severe rash, wheeze, tight chest, breathing or speech difficulty, or swelling of the mouth, face, lips, tongue or throat
- Contact a GP or NHS 111 if you take more than one extra dose, experience troublesome side effects, or need advice about infectiousness, prophylaxis or suitability with other health conditions or treatments

title: Menstrual Cycle: What's Normal, What's Not
body:
Your menstrual cycle offers insights into overall health, so knowing your personal pattern makes it easier to spot changes such as missed periods or unusual bleeding that warrant discussion with a healthcare professional.

**Symptoms**
- Typical cycles run 21–35 days with 2–7 days of bleeding; long cycles are common soon after menstruation begins and may shorten with age
- Periods may be light or heavy, painful or pain-free; extended-cycle pills, intrauterine devices (IUDs) or approaching menopause can alter flow and timing, and any irregular bleeding around menopause should be evaluated
- Tracking start/end dates, flow (including clotting or pad/tampon use), bleeding between periods, pain severity, mood or behavior changes helps define what is normal for you

**Causes**
- Pregnancy or breast-feeding can delay or halt periods temporarily
- Eating disorders, extreme weight loss or excessive exercise disrupt hormones and lead to irregular cycles
- Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) involves irregular periods plus ovarian follicles on ultrasound
- Premature ovarian failure (primary ovarian insufficiency) causes irregular or occasional periods before age 40
- Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) results from reproductive-organ infection and may cause irregular bleeding
- Uterine fibroids (noncancerous growths) can trigger heavy, prolonged periods

**Prevention**
- Track cycles consistently to recognize deviations; note flow changes, pain, mood shifts and external factors (stress, new medications)
- Birth control pills can regulate cycles, while progestin-containing devices may lighten flow and ease cramps
- Treating underlying conditions (for example, eating disorders) may restore regularity, though some irregularities cannot be prevented; approaching menopause naturally causes renewed variability

**When to See a Doctor**
- Seek medical advice if periods stop for 90+ days without pregnancy, formerly regular cycles become irregular, bleeding exceeds seven days, flow soaks more than one pad/tampon every hour or two, cycles occur more often than every 21 days or less often than every 35 days, bleeding happens between periods, period pain becomes severe, or fever and illness follow tampon use
- Discuss any irregular bleeding around menopause to rule out uterine cancer risk as hormone levels change with age

title: Menopause
body:
Menopause marks the permanent end of menstrual periods—diagnosed after 12 consecutive months without bleeding—and typically occurs between the 40s and 50s (average age 51 in the U.S.), bringing natural hormonal shifts that may disrupt sleep, energy and mood but can be managed with lifestyle steps or medical therapy.

**Symptoms**
- Perimenopause (menopausal transition) lasts roughly 2–8 years with fluctuating hormones that cause irregular or skipped periods, vaginal dryness, hot flashes, night sweats, sleep issues, mood changes and brain fog
- Periods may pause for months before stopping entirely; pregnancy remains possible during perimenopause, so take a pregnancy test if uncertain
- Any vaginal bleeding after menopause should be evaluated

**Causes**
- Natural hormone decline: ovaries slowly produce less estrogen and progesterone from the late 30s onward, ending periods around age 51
- Surgical removal of ovaries (oophorectomy) triggers immediate menopause; hysterectomy without ovary removal stops periods but hormones continue temporarily
- Chemotherapy or pelvic/abdominal/lower spine radiation can bring on menopause symptoms during or after treatment (periods may occasionally return)
- Primary ovarian insufficiency affects about 1% before age 40 when ovaries underproduce hormones due to gene or autoimmune causes; hormone therapy often continues until typical menopause age to protect the brain, heart and bones
- Age, ovary-removal surgery and certain cancer therapies are key risk factors

**Prevention**
- Menopause itself cannot be prevented, but symptom management options include:
  - Hormone therapy (estrogen with progestin if uterus intact) to reduce hot flashes and bone loss, ideally at the lowest effective dose near menopause onset
  - Vaginal estrogen creams, tablets or rings plus prasterone (Intrarosa) to ease dryness and pain with intercourse
  - Nonhormonal medicines: low-dose SSRIs/SNRIs, gabapentin, clonidine, fezolinetant (Veozah), oxybutynin
  - Osteoporosis medicines and vitamin D for bone protection, and ospemifene for painful intercourse (avoid with breast cancer risk)
- Review treatment choices regularly with a healthcare professional because needs may change over time

**When to See a Doctor**
- Discuss symptoms, skipped periods or suspected pregnancy during perimenopause with a healthcare professional; mention bleeding after menopause promptly to rule out serious causes
- Seek evaluation for menopause-like symptoms caused by thyroid issues (TSH testing may be used), and maintain regular wellness visits to monitor complications such as cardiovascular disease, osteoporosis, urinary incontinence, sexual difficulties or weight gain linked to slower metabolism

title: Alzheimer's Disease
body:
Alzheimer's disease—the leading cause of dementia—results from amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles damaging brain cells, shrinking the brain and ultimately causing severe memory loss, daily-function decline and complications such as dehydration, poor nutrition or infections; about 6.9 million Americans aged 65+ (over 70% aged 75+) and an estimated 60–70% of the world’s 55 million people with dementia live with this condition, and while no cure exists, medicines plus caregiver support programs may ease symptoms or slow decline.

**Symptoms**
- Memory loss starts with forgetting recent events or conversations and progresses to repeating statements or questions, forgetting appointments, misplacing items, getting lost in familiar places, and struggling to recall names of loved ones or common objects
- Thinking and reasoning issues include trouble concentrating on abstract concepts (such as numbers), multitasking, managing finances or recognizing figures
- Judgment and decision-making deteriorate, affecting choices about clothing, social situations or driving, and everyday problem solving
- Planning and completing familiar multi-step tasks (cooking, games, dressing, bathing) become challenging as the disease advances
- Personality and behavior may shift toward depression, apathy, social withdrawal, mood swings, distrust, anger, aggression, sleep disturbance, wandering, loss of inhibitions or delusions
- Certain skills like reading, music appreciation, storytelling, singing, dancing or crafts may persist longer because they rely on brain regions affected later

**Causes**
- Abnormal protein buildup (amyloid plaques, neurofibrillary tangles) leads to neuron death and brain shrinkage over time, producing the cognitive symptoms described
- Advanced disease increases vulnerability to dehydration, malnutrition and infections, which can be fatal

**When to See a Doctor**
- Consult a healthcare professional if you notice memory or thinking changes in yourself or someone else, since other treatable conditions can mimic dementia and early evaluation allows symptom management and support planning

title: Migraine
body:
A migraine typically causes a severe, throbbing headache on one side of the head that can last from 2 hours to 3 days, with warning signs beginning up to two days beforehand; it is common, often improves with age, and has strategies to reduce impact.

**Symptoms**
- Headache with pulsating pain on one side, sometimes preceded by tiredness, yawning, food cravings, thirst, mood shifts, stiff neck or increased urination
- Aura (zigzag lines, flashing lights, numbness or tingling, dizziness, difficulty speaking) that should resolve within an hour; migraines may present without aura or, in silent migraines, aura occurs without headache
- Attacks may be frequent or rare, and menstrual migraines are common; some symptoms linger after the headache ends

**Causes**
- Exact cause is unknown, but family history increases risk
- Triggers can include menstruation, anxiety, depression, stress, tiredness, skipped meals, high caffeine intake, lack of exercise and other personal factors identified through a migraine diary

**Prevention**
- During an attack, rest in a dark room, avoid triggers, stay hydrated, limit caffeine/alcohol, maintain a healthy weight, eat regularly, exercise, sleep well and manage stress
- Treatments include painkillers (ibuprofen, paracetamol), triptans, anti-sickness medicines, relaxation techniques, acupuncture and gepant medicines; different combinations may be needed, and overusing high-dose painkillers can worsen migraines
- If standard treatments fail or symptoms worsen, a specialist referral may be offered

**When to See a Doctor**
- See a GP if migraines are severe, hard to control, last longer than usual, occur more than once a week or regularly around your period
- Get urgent GP/NHS 111 advice if a migraine lasts longer than 72 hours, aura exceeds an hour, or you are pregnant or recently had a baby
- Call 999 if you or your child develop a sudden extremely painful headache, speech or memory trouble, vision changes, drowsiness, confusion, seizure, very high temperature with meningitis signs, or weakness in the arms, legs or face on one side

title: Tuberculosis
body:
Tuberculosis (TB) is a serious infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis that most often attacks the lungs, spreads through airborne droplets from people with active disease, and remains treatable with antibiotics—although some strains are drug-resistant and risk rises in crowded living conditions or with weakened immunity such as HIV/AIDS.

**Symptoms**
- Primary infection: usually no symptoms, but low fever, tiredness or cough may appear
- Latent TB infection: no symptoms while the immune system walls off the germs
- Active pulmonary TB: gradual onset of cough, coughing up blood or mucus, chest pain, painful breathing or coughing, fever, chills, night sweats, weight loss, loss of appetite, tiredness and general malaise
- Extrapulmonary TB: infection spreads to kidneys, liver, meninges, heart muscle, genitals, lymph nodes, bones, joints, skin, blood vessel walls or larynx, causing fever, chills, night sweats, weight loss, appetite loss, tiredness, general discomfort and localized pain
- Active TB in children: teenagers mirror adult symptoms; ages 1–12 have persistent fever and weight loss; infants may show poor growth, lethargy, fussiness, vomiting, poor feeding, bulging soft spot (fontanelle) or weak reflexes

**Causes**
- Inhalation of airborne droplets released when someone with active TB coughs, sneezes or sings
- Higher exposure risk in crowded housing and among people with weakened immune systems (e.g., HIV/AIDS)

**When to See a Doctor**
- Consult a healthcare professional if presumed TB symptoms persist beyond a few days of rest
- Seek emergency care for chest pain, sudden severe headache, confusion, seizures or breathing difficulty
- Obtain urgent care if coughing up blood or noticing blood in urine or stool

title: Allergic Rhinitis
body:
Allergic rhinitis occurs when allergens such as pollen irritate the nose, provoking sneezing and other symptoms that most people can control with pharmacy treatments.

**Symptoms**
- Sneezing, itchy nose, runny or blocked nose
- Itchy, red, watery eyes
- Cough
- Itchy roof of the mouth
- Symptoms typically appear within minutes of allergen exposure

**Causes**
- Allergic reactions to pollen (hay fever), house dust mites, pet dander, mould or workplace triggers (wood dust, flour dust, latex)
- Family history of allergies, eczema or asthma raises risk
- Differs from non-allergic rhinitis, which may stem from infections, temperature changes or humidity

**Prevention**
- Avoid triggers when possible; pharmacists can recommend antihistamines, short-term decongestant sprays/drops (not for children under 6 and not beyond a week), and saline sprays or homemade saltwater rinses
- If you have a high temperature or feel unwell, stay home and limit contact until better
- Practical tips: wear wraparound sunglasses during pollen season; use hypoallergenic bedding and wash at 60°C+; dust with a damp cloth; vacuum with a HEPA filter; wash pets every two weeks and groom them outdoors; clean pet bedding and furniture; keep the home dry, well ventilated, and address damp or condensation; avoid letting pets into bedrooms and try not to go outside or dry clothes outdoors when pollen counts are high

**When to See a Doctor**
- See a GP if symptoms worsen, asthma also deteriorates, sleep or daily life is affected, triggers are unclear, or pharmacy remedies do not help
- A GP may prescribe steroid nasal sprays, alternative antihistamines or refer you to a specialist for further tests and treatment

title: COPD
body:
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a progressive lung condition marked by airway inflammation and damage (most often from long-term irritant exposure) that limits airflow, causes emphysema and chronic bronchitis together, and can be managed to improve quality of life while lowering heart-disease and lung-cancer risks.

**Symptoms**
- Shortness of breath (especially with activity), wheezing or whistling breath sounds
- Chronic cough producing clear, white, yellow or greenish mucus
- Chest tightness or heaviness, fatigue, frequent lung infections
- Unintended weight loss as COPD worsens and swelling in ankles, feet or legs
- Exacerbations (flare-ups) bring harder breathing, more chest tightness, increased coughing, thicker mucus and fever, often triggered by smells, cold air, pollution, colds or infections

**Causes**
- Tobacco smoking is the main cause in developed countries; fumes from burning fuel for cooking/heating in poorly ventilated homes are common causes in developing regions
- Long-term workplace exposure to chemical fumes, vapors and dust, plus secondhand smoke, cigar, pipe or marijuana smoke, air pollution and other irritants
- Genetic factors such as alpha-1-antitrypsin (AAT) deficiency (≈1% of cases) help explain why not all smokers develop COPD; asthma combined with smoking increases risk
- Airway obstruction arises from emphysema (damaged alveolar walls and elastic fibers trap old air) and chronic bronchitis (inflamed, narrowed bronchi with thickened walls and excess mucus)

**Prevention**
- Avoid or quit smoking to prevent or slow COPD progression
- Limit exposure to workplace irritants by improving ventilation and using protective equipment
- Reduce complications by staying current on flu, pneumococcal, COVID-19 and RSV vaccines and addressing mental health impacts of chronic illness

**When to See a Doctor**
