- Contact a healthcare professional if symptoms fail to improve, worsen, or signs of infection appear (fever or mucus changes)
- Seek emergency care for severe breathlessness, blue lips or nail beds, rapid heartbeat or confusion

title: Sleep Apnoea
body:
Sleep apnoea causes breathing to stop and start during sleep—most commonly obstructive sleep apnoea (OSA)—and requires treatment to avoid serious complications.

**Symptoms**
- During sleep: breathing pauses, gasping/snorting/choking noises, frequent waking and loud snoring (often best observed by another person)
- Daytime: severe tiredness, poor concentration, mood swings and morning headaches

**Causes**
- Airways that narrow during sleep, linked to obesity, large neck, older age (though it can affect children and young adults), family history, smoking, alcohol, large tonsils/adenoids, sleeping on the back and COPD

**Prevention**
- Ask a GP about sleep-clinic testing; overnight devices measure breathing and heart rate to calculate an apnoea–hypopnoea index (AHI): 5–14 mild, 15–30 moderate, over 30 severe
- Treatments include lifestyle changes (weight loss, quitting smoking, limiting alcohol), continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) every night to keep airways open, mandibular advancement devices and surgery (such as removing large tonsils)
- Self-help tips: lose weight if needed, exercise regularly, maintain good sleep habits (dark, quiet bedroom, consistent schedule), sleep on your side using a tennis ball or special pillow, avoid smoking, limit alcohol—especially before bed—and only take sleeping pills if prescribed
- You may need to notify the DVLA and must not drive until daytime symptoms such as tiredness are controlled

**When to See a Doctor**
- Consult a GP if breathing pauses during sleep, you make gasping/snorting/choking noises at night, or you feel very tired during the day; bring someone who has witnessed your sleep if possible
- Untreated sleep apnoea increases risks of high blood pressure, stroke, type 2 diabetes, heart disease, depression, accidents from tiredness and strained relationships, so prompt medical assessment and treatment are important

title: Family Planning and Contraception
body:
Family planning empowers people to decide how many children to have and when, through contraception and infertility care that uphold sexual and reproductive rights, advance health and gender equality, and support SDG 3.7’s goal of universal reproductive healthcare.

**Causes**
- Global need remains high: of 1.9 billion women aged 15–49 in 2021, 1.1 billion required family planning, 874 million used modern contraception and 164 million had unmet need
- Barriers include limited method availability (especially in low-resource or rural settings), restrictions linked to age, income or marital status, fear of side effects, misinformation, social or religious opposition, poor service quality, provider bias and gender inequality requiring partner consent or causing stigma

**Prevention**
- Modern contraceptive options span long-acting methods (implants, IUDs, sterilization), regular-use methods (pills, injections, patches, vaginal rings), barrier methods (condoms—the only method protecting against pregnancy and sexually transmitted infections including HIV) and less reliable methods (fertility awareness, withdrawal); choice should reflect personal health, preferences and needs with guidance from health workers
- Family planning reduces unintended pregnancies, lowers health risks for adolescents, supports education/employment, strengthens health systems and fuels economic growth, with modern contraceptive use projected to rise by 70 million women by 2030
- Infertility, affecting about 1 in 6 adults due to infections, medical conditions, environmental or lifestyle factors in any gender, must be addressed within family planning; modern contraceptives do not cause infertility, yet women often face disproportionate social blame, stigma and distress, making access to infertility care essential
- WHO supports universal access by issuing evidence-based safety/delivery guidelines, promoting human-rights-centred programmes, helping countries adapt tools, advancing new contraceptive technologies and researching better service access

**When to See a Doctor**
- Consult healthcare professionals to choose suitable contraception, receive accurate information on benefits and side effects, and obtain infertility evaluation or treatment; professional guidance ensures methods match individual health profiles and helps overcome misinformation or barriers

title: Food Poisoning (Foodborne Illness)
body:
Food poisoning is a foodborne illness caused by eating or drinking contaminated items; symptoms typically start within hours or days (sometimes weeks) and may involve the gut or, less commonly, the nervous system.

**Symptoms**
- Upset stomach, vomiting, loose or bloody stools, stomach pain or cramps, fever
- Less common neurologic signs: blurred or double vision, headaches, paralysis, tingling, numbness, weakness
- Potential complications include severe dehydration, bloodstream infections, kidney failure, chronic arthritis, irritable bowel syndrome, Guillain-Barré syndrome and breathing problems such as botulism

**Causes**
- Contaminants include bacteria, viruses, intestinal parasites, toxins, toxin-producing bacteria and toxin-producing molds
- Foodborne illness covers any contaminated food or drink; food poisoning is the subset caused by toxins in food
- Food can be tainted during growing, harvesting, processing, storing, shipping or preparation through poor handwashing, dirty utensils/surfaces or improper storage temperatures (e.g., food left at room temperature too long)

**Prevention**
- Cleaning: wash hands with soap and water for 20 seconds, rinse fruits/vegetables, clean utensils with hot soapy water after raw foods, and clean refrigerators regularly (baking-soda solution; bleach for mold)
- Preparing/eating/storing: keep raw foods separate, thaw/cook/store foods safely, cook meats to safe temperatures, refrigerate or freeze leftovers promptly, discard questionable or moldy foods (trim mold only from firm, low-moisture foods when appropriate)
- High-risk groups (pregnant people, young children, older adults, immunocompromised): avoid raw or undercooked meats, fish, shellfish, eggs or foods containing raw eggs, raw sprouts, unpasteurized juices/milk, soft or unpasteurized cheeses, refrigerated pâtés/meat spreads and uncooked deli meats unless reheated

**When to See a Doctor**
- Infants and children: seek medical care for vomiting and loose stools plus behavior changes, extreme thirst, little or no urine, dizziness, diarrhea lasting more than a day, frequent vomiting, blood or pus in stools, severe abdominal or rectal pain, any fever in children under 2, fever ≥102°F (38.9°C) in older children or when other medical problems exist
- Adults: seek care for nervous-system symptoms (blurry vision, muscle weakness, skin tingling), mental changes, temperature ≥103°F (39.4°C), frequent vomiting, diarrhea lasting more than three days, or dehydration signs such as intense thirst, dry mouth, little/no urination, weakness, dizziness and lightheadedness

title: Epilepsy
body:
Epilepsy is a chronic noncommunicable brain disease marked by recurrent, unprovoked seizures that affect people of all ages worldwide; around 50 million people live with it, nearly 80% in low- and middle-income countries, and up to 70% could be seizure-free with proper diagnosis and treatment, yet three quarters in low-income settings lack needed care while stigma, discrimination and premature mortality remain high.

**Symptoms**
- Seizures may involve part of the body (partial) or the whole body (generalized), with features ranging from brief lapses in attention or muscle jerks to prolonged convulsions and possible loss of consciousness or bladder/bowel control
- Temporary symptoms depend on the brain region affected and can include disturbances in movement, sensation, awareness, mood or cognition, as well as higher rates of physical injuries (e.g., fractures) and psychological conditions such as anxiety or depression
- People with epilepsy have heightened risks of preventable deaths from falls, drowning, burns and prolonged seizures, especially in low- and middle-income countries

**Causes**
- Epilepsy is not contagious and arises from structural, genetic, infectious, metabolic, immune or unknown factors
- Examples include prenatal or perinatal brain damage (oxygen deprivation, trauma, low birth weight), congenital abnormalities or genetic conditions, severe head injuries, strokes, meningitis, encephalitis, neurocysticercosis, certain genetic syndromes and brain tumours; about half of cases have no identifiable cause
- Global incidence is higher (up to 139 per 100 000) in low- and middle-income countries due to increased risks such as malaria, neurocysticercosis, traffic injuries and birth injuries, coupled with limited medical infrastructure

**Prevention**
- Around 25% of cases are preventable through measures such as preventing head injuries (reducing falls and traffic accidents), ensuring good perinatal care, treating fevers in children to avoid febrile seizures, reducing stroke risk (controlling blood pressure, diabetes, obesity; avoiding tobacco and excessive alcohol) and preventing central nervous system infections (e.g., eliminating parasites causing neurocysticercosis)
- Training primary health care providers, improving access to antiseizure medicines and shifting services from institutions to community-based care reduce treatment gaps and human rights abuses

**When to See a Doctor**
- People experiencing seizures—or caring for someone who does—should seek medical evaluation so that antiseizure medicines, psychosocial support, community mental health services or surgery (when medicines fail) can be provided, reducing injury risks, stigma and premature death

title: Schizophrenia
body:
Schizophrenia is a chronic mental health condition that causes psychosis, substantial disability and wide-ranging impacts on personal, family, social, educational and occupational life; about 23 million people worldwide live with it, more than two thirds of those with psychosis receive no specialist care, and stigma, discrimination, human rights violations and shortened life expectancy remain pervasive despite effective treatments that enable at least one in three people to recover fully.

**Symptoms**
- Marked changes in perception, thinking, behaviour and affect, including persistent delusions (fixed false beliefs), hallucinations (perceiving stimuli that are not present) and experiences of influence or control over thoughts or actions
- Disorganized thinking (jumbled or irrelevant speech) and disorganized behaviour that can appear bizarre or purposeless
- Negative symptoms such as very limited speech, restricted emotional expression, inability to feel interest or pleasure, social withdrawal, extreme agitation, slowed movements or rigid postures
- Cognitive difficulties with memory, attention and problem-solving are common; symptom courses vary from complete remission to alternating exacerbations and remissions or gradual worsening
- The condition causes significant distress, functional impairment, and higher rates of physical illness, premature mortality (on average nine years earlier) and vulnerability during emergencies that disrupt social supports and health services

**Causes**
- No single cause is known; schizophrenia likely results from interactions between genetic susceptibility and environmental influences, while psychosocial factors shape onset and course
- Contributing factors under study include heavy cannabis use, prenatal and perinatal complications, infections, stress and social determinants; these add to existing stigma, restricted opportunities and human rights abuses that limit access to health care, education, housing and employment

**Prevention**
- Improving access to community-based mental health services, integrating care into primary and general health systems, providing supported housing/employment, and involving people with lived experience help reduce neglect, abuse and exclusion
- WHO initiatives such as the Comprehensive Mental Health Action Plan 2013–2030, the Special Initiative for Mental Health, the Mental Health Gap Action Programme (mhGAP) and the QualityRights Project promote rights-based, recovery-oriented services that shift resources from institutional settings to person-centred community care

**When to See a Doctor**
- Individuals experiencing psychosis symptoms—or their families—should seek professional assessment so evidence-based treatments (antipsychotic medicines, psychoeducation, family interventions, cognitive-behavioural therapy, psychosocial rehabilitation, assisted living, supported employment) can be coordinated through collaborative, rights-respecting services

title: Oral Health
body:
Oral diseases are largely preventable yet remain one of the most common chronic health burdens worldwide. Nearly 3.7 billion people are affected, and untreated dental caries in permanent teeth is the most prevalent condition tracked by the Global Burden of Disease study. Most oral health issues can be managed if detected early. Common problems include dental caries, periodontal disease, tooth loss, and oral cancers, while other conditions of public-health concern include orofacial clefts, noma, and oro-dental trauma. Prevention and treatment are costly, seldom covered by universal health coverage packages, and services are especially limited in low- and middle-income countries.

**Symptoms**
- Bleeding or swollen gums
- Pain in teeth or gums
- Halitosis (bad breath)
- Gum detachment and tooth loosening
- Visible pits or holes in teeth
- Brown, black, or white staining on teeth
- Toothache or sensitivity
- Difficulty chewing
- Complete tooth loss

**Causes**
- Plaque formation from sugars and starches that metabolize into acids that erode teeth over time
- High sugar intake
- Insufficient fluoride exposure
- Inadequate plaque removal
- Poor oral hygiene
- Tobacco use
- Excessive alcohol intake
- Diets high in free sugars
- Limited fluoride exposure
- High availability of sugary foods and drinks
- Constrained access to community oral care services
- Tobacco, alcohol, and areca nut use (for oral cancer)
- HPV infections (for oral cancer in younger populations)
- Genetics (for orofacial clefts)
- Maternal undernutrition during pregnancy (for orofacial clefts)
- Malnutrition (for noma)

**Prevention**
- Promote diets low in free sugars and high in fruits and vegetables
- Encourage water as the primary beverage
- Eliminate all forms of tobacco (including areca nut chewing)
- Limit alcohol intake
- Promote protective gear during sports and cycling to reduce facial injuries
- Ensure adequate fluoride exposure
- Brush twice daily with fluoride toothpaste (1000–1500 ppm)

title: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
body:
Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is a hormonal disorder that affects people during their reproductive years. It typically causes infrequent, prolonged, or irregular menstrual periods and excess androgen levels. PCOS disrupts normal ovulation. Follicles containing immature eggs accumulate without regularly releasing eggs, leading to ovulatory dysfunction and hormonal imbalances. Multiple small follicles develop along the outer edge of the ovaries and often fail to release mature eggs. Although the exact cause is unknown, early diagnosis, treatment, and lifestyle changes such as weight management can reduce risks of long-term complications including type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular disease. The condition often presents soon after menarche but may arise later.

**Symptoms**
- Irregular or infrequent menstrual periods, often fewer than nine per year or cycles longer than 35 days
- Clinical or biochemical signs of excess androgen (hirsutism, severe acne, male-pattern baldness)
- Enlarged ovaries with multiple follicles that do not function normally
- Symptoms tend to be more severe in individuals with obesity

**Causes**
- Insulin resistance: Elevated insulin levels stimulate ovarian androgen production and disrupt ovulation. Signs include acanthosis nigricans, increased appetite, and weight gain
- Low-grade inflammation: Chronic inflammatory responses can drive ovarian androgen production and raise cardiovascular risk
- Heredity: Genetic predisposition and family history increase susceptibility
- Excess androgen: Ovaries may produce elevated androgen levels that interfere with follicular maturation and ovulation, promoting hirsutism and acne

**Prevention**
- Early diagnosis and treatment
- Lifestyle changes such as weight management

**When to see a doctor**
- Medical evaluation is recommended for menstrual concerns, infertility, or new androgen-related changes

title: Cavities and Tooth Decay
body:
Cavities are damaged areas of tooth enamel that progress into tiny openings or holes. Without treatment, decay penetrates deeper layers, causing pain, infection, and eventual tooth loss. Tooth decay is among the world's most common health problems and affects people of all ages, including children and infants. Cavities develop through a gradual process where plaque formation from sugars and starches feeds bacteria, creating sticky plaque. Bacterial acids then erode minerals in enamel, forming micro-openings. Once enamel thins, acids reach dentin, which is softer and more sensitive. Bacteria and acid can invade the pulp, causing inflammation, nerve compression, pain, and potentially spreading infection. Consistent dental care and oral hygiene are essential for prevention.

**Symptoms**
- Early cavities may not cause symptoms
- Toothache
- Sensitivity
- Sharp pain when eating or drinking hot, cold, or sweet items
- Visible pits or holes
- Brown, black, or white staining
- Pain while biting

**Causes**
- Plaque formation: Sugars and starches left on teeth feed bacteria, creating sticky plaque that hardens into tartar if not removed
- Plaque attacks: Bacterial acids erode minerals in enamel, forming micro-openings
- Progression: Bacteria and acid invade the pulp, causing inflammation, nerve compression, pain, and potentially spreading infection to bone and adjacent teeth
- Posterior tooth anatomy (grooves and roots)
- Clingy foods (sweets, dried fruit, chips)
- Frequent snacking or sipping sugary/acidic drinks
- Bedtime baby bottles or constant sippy cups
- Inadequate brushing
- Insufficient fluoride exposure
- Very young or older age
- Dry mouth
- Worn fillings or ill-fitting dental devices
- Gastroesophageal reflux
- Eating disorders (vomiting or reduced saliva)

**Prevention**
- Brush twice daily with fluoride toothpaste
- Clean between teeth (floss or interdental cleaners)
- Use fluoride mouth rinses for high-risk individuals
- Schedule routine professional cleanings and exams
- Apply dental sealants on molars
- Drink fluoridated tap water
- Limit snacking and sugary beverages
- Choose tooth-healthy foods (fruits, vegetables, unsweetened coffee/tea, sugar-free gum)
- Receive professional fluoride treatments or custom trays when needed
- Use antiseptic rinses (e.g., chlorhexidine) for medical conditions that heighten decay risk

**When to see a doctor**
- Regular dental visits are recommended even when no discomfort is present
- Prompt evaluation is needed for tooth or mouth pain

title: Common Cold
body:
The common cold is a viral upper respiratory infection that usually clears within 1–2 weeks without medical care. Symptoms develop gradually over 2–3 days. Colds appear gradually, mainly affect the nose and throat, and usually allow people to continue daily activities. Most colds can be managed at home with self-care measures.

**Symptoms**
- Blocked or runny nose
- Sneezing
- Sore or hoarse throat
- Cough
- Fatigue
- Feeling generally unwell
- Fever
- Muscle aches
- Loss of taste or smell
- Pressure in the ears and face
- Children may have longer-lasting symptoms, irritability, feeding and sleeping difficulties, mouth breathing, and vomiting after coughing

**Prevention**
- Avoid sharing towels, cups, or toys with infected individuals
- Refrain from touching eyes or nose after contact with surfaces
- Practice good hand hygiene
- Maintain general fitness
- Wash hands frequently with warm water and soap
- Use tissues to catch coughs/sneezes and discard tissues promptly
- Colds spread via droplets from coughs and sneezes and can survive on hands and surfaces for 24 hours
- People can spread the virus from a few days before symptoms begin until recovery

**When to see a doctor**
- Contact a GP if fever lasts more than 3 days
- If symptoms worsen or persist more than 10 days
- If temperature is very high or accompanied by chills
- If breathing becomes difficult
- If chest pain occurs
- If cough lasts more than 3 weeks
- If there is concern about a child's symptoms
- If the person has long-term conditions (e.g., heart, lung, kidney disease, diabetes) or weakened immunity (e.g., chemotherapy)

title: Gastritis
body:
Gastritis occurs when the stomach lining becomes inflamed or irritated. Treatments depend on the cause and may include antacids, alginates, acid-suppressing medicines, or antibiotics. Untreated gastritis can progress to ulcers.

**Symptoms**
- Tummy pain
- Indigestion
- Bloating
- Nausea
- Vomiting
- Reduced appetite
- Increased burping or flatulence

**Causes**
- Helicobacter pylori infection
- Regular use of anti-inflammatory painkillers (ibuprofen, aspirin)
- Excessive alcohol intake
- Severe stress or illness (e.g., after surgery)
- Autoimmune conditions targeting the stomach lining

**Prevention**
- Reduce caffeine intake
- Elevate the head/shoulders with an extra pillow at night
- Lose weight if overweight
- Consult a doctor about long-term NSAID/aspirin use
- Do not eat within 3–4 hours of bedtime
- Avoid consuming acidic, fizzy, spicy, or fatty foods or drinks
- Avoid drinking alcohol
- Do not smoke

**When to see a doctor**
- Call 999 or go to A&E if you vomit bright red blood or material that looks like coffee grounds, produce black tarry stools, or develop sudden severe abdominal or chest pain
- Ask for an urgent GP appointment or NHS 111 help if you lose appetite, feel full after small meals, lose weight unintentionally, sense a lump in the abdomen, have painful/difficult swallowing, or keep vomiting
- See a GP if tummy pain or indigestion lasts longer than a week, worsens, or recurs

title: Adolescent Pregnancy
body:
Adolescent pregnancy, defined as pregnancy in girls aged 10–19 years, remains a global public health concern with profound health, social and economic consequences. In low- and middle-income countries (LMICs), there were an estimated 21 million pregnancies annually among adolescents aged 15–19 in 2019, half of which were unintended, resulting in about 12 million births. Approximately 55% of unintended pregnancies in adolescents end in abortions, often unsafe in LMICs. Adolescents face higher risks of eclampsia, puerperal endometritis and systemic infections than women aged 20–24, and their babies have greater risks of low birth weight, preterm birth and severe neonatal complications. While global ABR has fallen, declines are uneven across regions and within countries, with higher rates among adolescents with limited education or low socioeconomic status.

**Causes**
- Socioeconomic inequities: Adolescents with less education or low income experience higher pregnancy rates
- Child marriage: Early marriage limits autonomy over timing of childbearing and contraceptive use
- Limited opportunities: In settings with restricted education/employment prospects, motherhood may be one of few valued roles
- Contraceptive barriers: Adolescents face limited availability, cost, stigma, restrictive laws (age/marital status), provider bias, side effects, and inconsistent use
- Sexual violence: About 120 million girls under 20 have experienced sexual violence by non-partners; 1 in 8 children experience sexual abuse before 18, and 1 in 20 girls aged 15–19 report forced sex, increasing unintended pregnancies
- Intimate partner violence: 24% of adolescent girls aged 15–19 have experienced physical and/or sexual violence from an intimate partner; 16% within the last year, undermining reproductive autonomy
- Social pressures to bear children
- Restrictive laws, provider bias, stigma, cost, and inadequate information

**Prevention**
- Strategies increasingly couple pregnancy prevention with improved access to respectful, high-quality maternal care and support for pregnant adolescents
- Preventing adolescent pregnancy aligns with SDG indicators 3.7.2 (adolescent birth rate) and 5.3.1 (child marriage)
- National programmes targeting adolescent pregnancy prevention and child marriage reduction

title: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
body:
Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) occurs when the lower esophageal sphincter relaxes inappropriately or weakens, allowing stomach contents to flow back into the esophagus. This reflux—acidic or sometimes nonacidic—irritates the lining of the esophagus, producing chronic symptoms commonly known as heartburn. Many people experience occasional reflux, but frequent or persistent episodes define GERD. GERD results from recurrent acid reflux. Normally, the lower esophageal sphincter opens to allow food into the stomach and then closes. If it relaxes improperly or weakens, stomach acid flows backward, inflaming the esophageal lining and causing chronic symptoms. Most cases improve with lifestyle changes and medicines, though some individuals require surgery.

**Symptoms**
- Chest burning (heartburn) after meals, worse at night or when lying down
- Regurgitation of food or sour liquid
- Upper abdominal or chest pain
- Difficulty swallowing (dysphagia)
- Sensation of a lump in the throat
- Nighttime reflux may add chronic cough, laryngitis, or worsening asthma

**Causes**
- Lower esophageal sphincter that relaxes improperly or weakens
- Recurrent acid reflux
- Obesity
- Hiatal hernia
- Pregnancy
- Connective tissue disorders (e.g., scleroderma)
- Delayed stomach emptying

**Prevention**
- Avoid smoking
- Avoid large meals or late eating
- Avoid fatty or fried foods
- Limit alcohol intake
- Limit coffee consumption
- Be cautious with certain medicines such as aspirin
- Lifestyle changes can help improve symptoms

**When to see a doctor**
- Immediate medical attention is required for chest pain with shortness of breath or jaw/arm pain, as these could indicate a heart attack
- See a healthcare professional for severe or frequent GERD symptoms
- See a healthcare professional if you rely on over-the-counter heartburn medicines more than twice weekly

title: Lung Cancer
body:
**Key Facts:**
Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer-related deaths worldwide, accounting for the highest mortality rates among both men and women. Smoking is responsible for approximately 85% of all cases. Lung cancer is often diagnosed at advanced stages when treatment options are limited. Screening high-risk individuals allows early detection and significantly improves survival rates. Primary prevention, including tobacco control and reducing environmental exposures, can reduce lung cancer incidence.

**Overview:**
Lung cancer occurs when abnormal cells grow uncontrollably in the lungs. Common symptoms include a persistent cough, chest pain, and shortness of breath. Early medical care is crucial for better outcomes. The main types are non-small cell carcinoma (NSCLC), which grows slowly and is more common, and small cell carcinoma (SCLC), which grows quickly. According to GLOBOCAN 2020 (IARC), lung cancer caused an estimated 1.8 million deaths in 2020. Risk factors include smoking, secondhand smoke, occupational exposures (asbestos, radon, chemicals), air pollution, hereditary syndromes, and chronic lung diseases.

**Symptoms:**
Common symptoms of lung cancer include:
- Persistent cough
- Chest pain
- Shortness of breath
- Coughing up blood (haemoptysis)
- Fatigue
- Unexplained weight loss
- Recurrent lung infections
Early symptoms may be mild, causing delayed diagnosis.

**Prevention:**
Avoiding tobacco use is the most effective way to prevent lung cancer. Other preventable risk factors include secondhand smoke, air pollution, and workplace chemical exposure. Primary prevention focuses on smoking cessation, smoke-free environments, occupational safety, and air quality improvement. Secondary prevention includes screening, especially low-dose computed tomography (LDCT), for high-risk individuals to detect early disease.

**Diagnosis:**
Lung cancer diagnosis involves physical examination, imaging (X-rays, CT, MRI), bronchoscopy, tissue biopsy for histopathology, and molecular testing to determine tumour type (NSCLC or SCLC) and guide treatment options.

**Treatment and Care:**
Treatment depends on cancer type, stage, spread, and patient history. Options include surgery, radiotherapy, chemotherapy, targeted therapy, and immunotherapy. Surgery is preferred for early-stage disease. Chemotherapy and radiation help shrink tumours. Multidisciplinary teams manage treatment. Supportive care focuses on pain relief, managing symptoms, and improving quality of life.

**Stages of Care:**
**a) Early-stage disease:** Surgery is the primary treatment when cancer is confined to the lung. Neoadjuvant therapy (before surgery) helps shrink tumours, while adjuvant therapy (after surgery) reduces recurrence risk. Radiation therapy or SBRT may be used when surgery is not possible. Targeted therapy and immunotherapy may also be considered.

**b) Advanced disease:** For metastatic lung cancer, treatment focuses on prolonging survival and improving quality of life. Chemotherapy is often first-line. Targeted therapy is used for tumours with specific mutations. Immunotherapy helps the immune system attack cancer cells. Local treatments like radiation or surgery relieve symptoms.

**Clinical Trials:**
Clinical trials offer patients access to new or experimental treatments and help advance lung cancer research.

**WHO Response:**
WHO works to reduce lung cancer burden through tobacco control, early detection, and improved cancer care. Initiatives include tobacco taxation, advertising bans, graphic health warnings, promoting healthy lifestyles, improving environmental conditions, supporting screening programs, and ensuring equitable access to essential cancer treatments.

title: Coronavirus Disease (COVID-19)
body:
**Key Facts:**
COVID-19 is a disease caused by a virus. The most common symptoms are fever, chills, and sore throat, though many others can occur. Most people recover without needing hospital treatment, but people with severe symptoms should seek urgent medical care. Over 760 million cases and 6.9 million deaths have been recorded globally since December 2019, although actual numbers may be higher. Over 13 billion vaccine doses have been administered as of June 2023.

**Overview:**
COVID-19 is caused by the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus and usually spreads through close contact between people. Vaccines provide strong protection against severe illness and death, although vaccinated people may still get infected and have mild or no symptoms. Anyone can get sick, but most people recover without treatment. Older adults (60+) and people with medical conditions such as hypertension, diabetes, obesity, immunosuppression (including HIV), cancer, or pregnancy are at higher risk. Unvaccinated individuals also face greater risk.

**Symptoms:**
Symptoms generally begin 5–6 days after exposure and last 1–14 days.

**Most common symptoms:**
- Fever
- Chills
- Sore throat

**Less common symptoms:**
- Muscle aches or heavy limbs
- Severe fatigue
- Runny or blocked nose, sneezing
- Headache
- Sore eyes
- Dizziness
- New persistent cough
- Chest tightness or pain
- Shortness of breath
- Hoarse voice
- Numbness or tingling
- Appetite loss, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhoea
- Loss or change of taste or smell
- Sleep difficulties

**Seek immediate medical attention if experiencing:**
- Difficulty breathing at rest
- Inability to speak full sentences
- Confusion or drowsiness
- Chest pain or pressure
- Skin turning pale, cold, or bluish
- Loss of speech or movement

People with chronic health conditions such as heart, lung, liver, rheumatological diseases, HIV, diabetes, cancer, obesity or dementia are at higher risk and should seek help early if symptoms worsen.

Severe COVID-19 may lead to respiratory failure, sepsis, blood clots, heart, liver or kidney injury, or death. Rarely, children may develop a severe inflammatory syndrome weeks after infection.

Some people continue to experience symptoms after recovery—this is known as **long COVID** (post COVID-19 condition). Common long COVID symptoms include fatigue, breathlessness, and cognitive difficulties, which may affect daily functioning.

**Treatment:**
Most people recover without hospitalization. Treatment depends on symptom severity, age, and underlying health conditions. Those with severe disease or high-risk factors require early medical care.

**Prevention:**
Vaccination is the most effective tool to prevent severe illness, hospitalization, and death. Additional preventive measures include:
- Avoiding crowded places
- Maintaining physical distance
- Wearing masks if sick, at high risk, or in poorly ventilated areas
- Cleaning hands frequently
- Covering mouth and nose when coughing or sneezing
- Disposing of tissues immediately and washing hands
- Self-isolating after testing positive or developing symptoms

Vaccination priority groups include people aged 60+, those with underlying medical conditions, immunosuppression (including HIV), obesity, cancer, pregnant individuals, and unvaccinated people. WHO's recommendations for primary series and booster doses may change as the virus evolves.

**WHO Response:**
WHO leads global coordination of the COVID-19 response, including research, guidance development, vaccine distribution, and monitoring global case trends. The Access to COVID-19 Tools (ACT) Accelerator, launched in April 2020, enabled rapid development of diagnostic, treatment, and vaccine tools. COVAX, part of ACT-Accelerator, works to ensure equitable global access to vaccines.

WHO also coordinates vaccine safety monitoring, provides technical support, and develops target product profiles for COVID-19 vaccines. It supports countries in oxygen production and supply enhancement. Although the emergency phase ended in May 2023, WHO continues to coordinate ongoing global response efforts.

title: Influenza
body:
**Key Points:**
Flu is a contagious respiratory illness caused by influenza viruses. It can range from mild to severe illness. Most experts believe flu spreads mainly through tiny droplets produced when infected people cough, sneeze, or talk. The first and most important step to prevent flu is getting a flu vaccine every year.

**Understanding Influenza:**
Flu is caused by influenza viruses that infect the nose, throat, and sometimes the lungs. It can cause mild to severe illness and can lead to death. The best prevention is annual vaccination.

**Symptoms:**
Flu symptoms usually appear suddenly and can be mild to severe. Common symptoms include:
- Fever or chills
- Cough
- Sore throat
- Runny or stuffy nose
- Muscle or body aches
- Headaches
- Fatigue
- Vomiting and diarrhea (more common in children)
Not everyone with flu will have a fever. Some people do not show any symptoms at all; a study from 2017–2023 found that 8% of people with flu infections were asymptomatic.

**Period of Contagiousness:**
- People with flu are most contagious during the first three days of illness.
- Healthy adults may spread flu from 1 day before symptoms to 5–7 days after becoming sick.
- Children and immunocompromised individuals may be contagious for longer.

**Onset of Symptoms:**
Symptoms typically appear about 2 days after infection but can range from 1–4 days.

**People at Risk:**
Anyone can get flu, but certain groups are at higher risk for complications:
- Adults 65+ years
- People with chronic medical conditions (asthma, diabetes, heart disease)
- People with BMI ≥ 40
- Pregnant individuals
- Children under 5 years

**How It Spreads:**
Flu viruses spread mainly through droplets when infected people cough, sneeze, or talk. Less commonly, a person may catch the flu by touching a contaminated surface and then touching their mouth, nose, or eyes.

**Prevention:**
The most important preventive measure is yearly flu vaccination. The vaccine reduces flu-related illness and the risk of severe complications such as hospitalization or death. Other prevention steps include:
- Staying away from sick people
- Covering coughs and sneezes
- Washing hands frequently
- Improving ventilation and air cleanliness

**Quick Facts:**
**U.S. Annual Flu Infection Rates:** A 2018 CDC study found that about 8% of the U.S. population gets sick with flu each season, ranging from 3% to 11% depending on the season.

**Groups Most Likely to Get Sick:**
- Children (0–17 years): 9.3% attack rate
- Adults (18–64 years): 8.8% attack rate
- Adults 65+: 3.9% attack rate
Children are more than twice as likely to develop symptomatic flu compared to older adults.

**Estimating Seasonal Flu Incidence:**
Flu infections are estimated based on hospitalization rates and adjusted to reflect total infections, since many people do not seek medical care or testing.

**Impact of Flu Season Severity:**
The percentage of people who get flu varies by season—from 3% in low-severity seasons to 11% in moderate or high-severity seasons.

**Table – Estimates of Symptomatic Influenza (2010–2022):**
A detailed table (2010–2022) shows incidence rates by age and predominant virus strains, with variations based on season severity.

**Complications of Flu:**
Flu can lead to:
- Bacterial pneumonia
- Ear and sinus infections
- Worsening chronic medical conditions (heart failure, asthma, diabetes)

**Testing and Diagnosis:**
Flu cannot be diagnosed by symptoms alone; diagnostic tests are available.

**Treatment:**
Antiviral medications can treat flu illness. Early treatment reduces complications.

**Types of Flu Viruses:**
Flu A and B viruses cause seasonal flu epidemics. Flu A viruses have subtypes based on surface proteins.

**How Flu Viruses Change:**
Flu viruses evolve through antigenic drift and antigenic shift.

**Transmission from Animals to Humans:**
Flu A viruses infect many animals (birds, pigs, dogs, horses, whales). Some strains can infect humans.

**Avian, Canine, Swine Flu:**
Information is available on flu viruses in birds, dogs, and pigs, along with human infections from animal-origin flu viruses.

**Pandemic Flu:**
A flu pandemic occurs when a new flu A virus spreads globally.

**Human Serology and Flu:**
CDC conducts serology studies to improve vaccines and pandemic preparedness.

**Antigenic Characterization:**
CDC analyzes circulating flu viruses each year to guide vaccine composition.

**Flu Virus Genome Sequencing:**
CDC researches genetic changes in flu viruses to support public health goals.

**Expanding Genomic Sequencing:**
CDC helps U.S. state labs expand flu sequencing capacity through funding and training.

**Advanced Molecular Detection (AMD):**
CDC uses advanced technology to study flu viruses in greater detail than previously possible.

title: Tuberculosis
body:
**Key Facts:**
A total of 1.23 million people died from tuberculosis (TB) in 2024 (including 150 000 among people with HIV). TB remains the world’s leading cause of death from a single infectious agent and one of the top 10 causes of death. It was the leading killer of people with HIV in 2024 and a major contributor to antimicrobial resistance–related deaths. In 2024, an estimated 10.7 million people fell ill with TB worldwide (5.8 million men, 3.7 million women, 1.2 million children). TB occurs in all countries and age groups. Multidrug-resistant TB (MDR-TB) remains a major global health threat, with only 2 in 5 drug-resistant TB patients receiving treatment in 2024. Global TB efforts have saved an estimated 83 million lives since 2000. TB is preventable and curable.

**Overview:**
Tuberculosis (TB) is an infectious bacterial disease that primarily affects the lungs. It spreads through the air when infected individuals cough, sneeze or spit. About a quarter of the global population is infected with TB bacteria, though most do not feel sick or spread the disease. Only 5–10% of infected individuals develop TB disease. Babies and children are at higher risk. TB is treatable with antibiotics, but fatal without treatment. In many countries, the BCG vaccine is administered to babies to prevent severe TB forms. Risk factors for TB disease include diabetes, weakened immunity (e.g., HIV), undernutrition, tobacco use, and harmful alcohol use.

**Symptoms:**
Most people with TB infection do not feel sick or spread TB. TB disease develops when bacteria multiply and affect organs, usually the lungs, but also the kidneys, brain and spine. TB symptoms may be mild for months, increasing the risk of unknowingly spreading infection. Some people with TB disease have no symptoms but can still spread TB.

**Common TB symptoms include:**
- Prolonged cough (sometimes with blood)
- Chest pain
- Weakness
- Fatigue
- Weight loss
- Fever
- Night sweats

Symptoms vary depending on the affected organ.

**Prevention:**
Prevention strategies include:
- Seeking medical attention early for prolonged cough, fever, or unexplained weight loss
- Screening for TB if at higher risk (e.g., HIV, household exposure)
- Completing TB preventive treatment (TPT) if prescribed
- Practicing good cough hygiene when infected (masking, covering mouth/nose, proper disposal of tissues)
- Ensuring good ventilation and respirator use in healthcare and institutional settings

**Diagnosis:**
WHO recommends rapid diagnostic tests as the initial method for all people with TB symptoms. These include biomarker-based tests and molecular assays that provide results within 48 hours. Diagnosing drug-resistant TB, HIV-associated TB, and pediatric TB can be complex; WHO provides specific recommendations for accurate detection.

Tests used to detect TB infection include the tuberculin skin test (TST), interferon gamma release assays (IGRA), and newer antigen-based skin tests (TBST). These identify individuals who may benefit from TB preventive treatment.

**Treatment:**
TB disease is treated with special antibiotics. Treatment is recommended for both TB infection and disease. Common antibiotics include:
- Rifampicin
- Isoniazid
- Pyrazinamide
- Ethambutol

Treatment lasts 4–6 months and must be taken consistently. Stopping early can cause drug resistance. Drug-resistant TB requires alternative medications.

**Multidrug-Resistant TB (MDR-TB):**
MDR-TB occurs when TB bacteria do not respond to rifampicin and isoniazid. MDR-TB can be treated with other, often more expensive medicines that may have more side effects. People exposed to MDR-TB may receive levofloxacin as preventive treatment.

XDR-TB (extensively drug-resistant TB) can develop when MDR-TB bacteria become resistant to additional drugs, leaving limited treatment options. MDR-TB remains a global crisis, with only 40% of patients receiving treatment in 2024.

WHO prioritizes a 6-month all-oral short regimen (BPaLM/BPaL) for eligible patients. Global scale-up increased from 1,744 people on short regimens in 2022 to 34,000 in 2024.

**TB and HIV:**
People living with HIV are 12 times more likely to develop TB disease. TB is the leading cause of death among people with HIV. In 2024, 150,000 people died from HIV-associated TB. About 82% of individuals with TB had documented HIV test results in 2024. The African Region bears the highest HIV-associated TB burden.

Only 61% of people with HIV-associated TB received antiretroviral therapy (ART) in 2024. Joint TB/HIV activities recommended by WHO since 2004 have helped avert 9.8 million deaths through screening, prevention and treatment.

**Impact:**
TB affects people of all ages but mainly adults in their productive years. Over 80% of TB cases and deaths occur in low- and middle-income countries. In 2024, new TB cases were highest in the WHO South-East Asia Region (34%), Western Pacific Region (27%), and African Region (25%). Eight countries accounted for two-thirds of global TB cases, with India alone representing 25%.

About 50% of TB patients and families face catastrophic costs (>20% of total household income). TB risk increases with HIV, undernutrition, diabetes, tobacco use and alcohol use. In 2024, new TB cases attributable to key risk factors included 0.97 million (undernutrition), 0.93 million (diabetes), 0.74 million (alcohol use), 0.70 million (smoking), and 0.57 million (HIV).

**Investments to End TB:**
US$ 22 billion is needed annually by 2027 to reach global TB targets. In 2024, 82% of TB funding came from domestic sources, totaling US$ 4.8 billion in LMICs. Brazil, China, India, the Russian Federation, and South Africa contributed 64% of domestic spending. Donor funding remained at US$ 1.1 billion. TB research funding in 2023 was US$ 1.2 billion—far below the target of US$ 5 billion per year.

**WHO Response:**
WHO works with countries, partners, and civil society to scale up the TB response. Its six core functions support global TB targets, the 2023 UN High-Level Meeting declaration, the End TB Strategy, SDGs, and WHO strategic priorities.

title: HIV and AIDS
body:
**Key Facts:**
HIV remains a major global public health issue, responsible for an estimated 44.1 million deaths to date. Transmission continues in all countries. By the end of 2024, approximately 40.8 million people were living with HIV, 65% of whom were in the WHO African Region. In 2024, there were an estimated 630,000 HIV-related deaths and 1.3 million new HIV infections. While there is no cure, effective HIV prevention, diagnosis, treatment, and care—including for opportunistic infections—allow people with HIV to live long and healthy lives. WHO, UNAIDS and the Global Fund have aligned strategies toward ending the HIV epidemic by 2030. The 95-95-95 targets aim for 95% of all people with HIV diagnosed, 95% of them on treatment, and 95% of those on treatment achieving viral suppression. In 2024, progress stood at 87%, 89% and 94% respectively. Among all people living with HIV globally, 87% knew their status, 77% were on ART, and 73% had suppressed viral loads.

**Overview:**
Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) attacks the immune system by targeting white blood cells. Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) is the most advanced stage of HIV infection. HIV spreads through body fluids including blood, breast milk, semen and vaginal fluids, and can also be transmitted from mother to child. It is not spread by casual contact such as kisses, hugs or sharing food. ART can prevent HIV from progressing to AIDS. WHO defines Advanced HIV Disease (AHD) as a CD4 cell count below 200 cells/mm³ or WHO stage 3 or 4 in adults and adolescents; all children aged under 5 with HIV are considered to have AHD.

**Signs and Symptoms:**
HIV symptoms vary by stage of infection. Many people have no symptoms during early infection, though some develop flu-like symptoms such as:
- Fever
- Headache
- Rash
- Sore throat

As HIV progresses, the immune system weakens, causing symptoms such as:
- Swollen lymph nodes
- Weight loss
- Fever
- Diarrhoea
- Cough

Without treatment, people can develop severe illnesses including:
- Tuberculosis (TB)
- Cryptococcal meningitis
- Severe bacterial infections
- Cancers such as lymphomas and Kaposi’s sarcoma

HIV can also worsen infections like hepatitis B, hepatitis C and mpox.

**Transmission:**
HIV is transmitted through the exchange of body fluids such as blood, breast milk, semen and vaginal secretions. It can be transmitted during pregnancy, childbirth or breastfeeding. HIV is *not* spread through casual contact such as kissing, hugging, shaking hands or sharing food, water or objects.

People living with HIV who take ART and maintain an undetectable viral load **will not transmit HIV** to sexual partners (U=U). Early diagnosis and consistent treatment are therefore key to preventing transmission.

**Risk Factors:**
Behaviours and conditions increasing HIV risk include:
- Anal or vaginal sex without a condom
- Having another STI (syphilis, herpes, chlamydia, gonorrhoea, bacterial vaginosis)
- Alcohol or drug use during sex
- Sharing needles, syringes or injecting equipment
- Unsafe injections, blood transfusions or tissue transplantation
- Unsterile medical procedures or accidental needle stick injuries

**Diagnosis:**
HIV is diagnosed using rapid diagnostic tests that provide same-day results, facilitating early diagnosis and treatment. HIV self-tests are also available. However, a diagnosis must always be confirmed by a trained health worker using a validated testing strategy. Most tests detect antibodies produced within 28 days of infection, during which false negatives may occur (the “window period”). People with recent high-risk exposure who test negative should be retested after 28 days.

Following a positive test, retesting is required before starting treatment to rule out error. Diagnosis in infants under 18 months requires virological testing, not antibody testing. New point-of-care technologies allow same-day results for early infant diagnosis.

**Prevention:**
HIV is preventable. Prevention strategies include:
- Using male or female condoms during sex
- Testing for HIV and STIs
- Male circumcision
- Harm reduction services for people who inject drugs

**WHO-recommended PrEP options include:**
- Oral tenofovir (TDF)-based PrEP
- Dapivirine vaginal ring
- Long-acting injectable cabotegravir
- Long-acting injectable lenacapavir

ART also prevents mother-to-child transmission when taken during pregnancy, childbirth and breastfeeding.

**PrEP and PEP:**
- **Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP):** Taken before exposure to prevent infection
- **Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP):** Taken after potential exposure
People should seek clinical advice when considering PrEP or PEP.

**Treatment:**
There is no cure for HIV. Treatment involves antiretroviral therapy (ART), which suppresses viral replication, strengthens the immune system and prevents disease progression. ART must be taken daily for life. A person on ART with an undetectable viral load will not transmit HIV sexually.

Pregnant women should start ART immediately to protect themselves and prevent transmission to their babies. Advanced HIV disease remains a major challenge; WHO is supporting the rollout of comprehensive care packages and new treatments such as shorter regimens for opportunistic infections like cryptococcal meningitis. Long-acting injectable medicines, including lenacapavir, may further improve prevention and treatment options.

**WHO Response:**
The WHO Global Health Sector Strategies (GHSSs) for 2022–2030 guide global actions to end AIDS, viral hepatitis and STIs by 2030. WHO’s HIV, Hepatitis and STIs Programmes support countries with evidence-based guidance, innovation, and technical assistance, focusing on reaching the populations most affected and reducing inequities. Under the principles of universal health coverage and primary health care, WHO works to achieve the goals of the 2030 Sustainable Development Agenda.

title: Hepatitis B
body:
**Key Facts:**
Hepatitis B is a viral infection that attacks the liver and can cause both acute and chronic disease. The virus is most commonly transmitted from mother to child during birth or early childhood, and through contact with infected blood or body fluids (such as during sex, unsafe injections, or exposure to sharp instruments). In 2022, an estimated 254 million people were living with chronic hepatitis B, with 1.2 million new infections each year. Hepatitis B caused approximately 1.1 million deaths in 2022, mainly from cirrhosis and liver cancer. Vaccines are safe, widely available, and highly effective in preventing hepatitis B.

**Overview:**
Hepatitis B is caused by the hepatitis B virus (HBV) and can lead to acute (short-term) or chronic (long-term) infection. Chronic infection significantly increases the risk of cirrhosis and liver cancer. HBV spreads through infected blood, saliva, semen, vaginal fluids, and from mother to child. A safe and effective vaccine provides nearly 100% protection when administered shortly after birth, followed by booster doses. The global burden is highest in the Western Pacific Region (97 million chronically infected) and African Region (65 million). High burdens also exist in South-East Asia (61 million), Eastern Mediterranean (15 million), European Region (11 million), and the Americas (5 million).

**Transmission:**
In highly endemic regions, HBV is most frequently transmitted from mother to child at birth or between young children during the first five years of life. Chronic infection develops in about 95% of infants infected early in life, compared to less than 5% of adults infected later. HBV can also spread through needlestick injuries, tattooing, piercing, or contact with infected blood and body fluids. Sharing contaminated needles or syringes, and unsterile medical or cosmetic procedures, increase the risk. Sexual transmission is more common among unvaccinated individuals with multiple partners.

**Symptoms:**
Most newly infected individuals show no symptoms. Some may develop acute illness lasting several weeks, including:
- Jaundice (yellowing of skin and eyes)
- Dark urine
- Extreme fatigue
- Nausea
- Vomiting
- Abdominal pain

Severe acute hepatitis can lead to liver failure and death. While many recover fully, some with chronic infection develop liver cirrhosis or hepatocellular carcinoma (liver cancer), which can be fatal.

**HBV–HIV Coinfection:**
About 1% (2.7 million) of people living with HBV are also infected with HIV. Conversely, 7.4% of people with HIV have HBV infection. WHO recommends HIV treatment for all diagnosed individuals. The drug **tenofovir**, used in first-line HIV therapy, is also effective against HBV.

**Diagnosis:**
Hepatitis B cannot be diagnosed clinically and requires laboratory testing. Blood tests detect viral markers and distinguish between acute and chronic infection. Additional tests such as ultrasound and elastography evaluate liver fibrosis and disease progression. WHO recommends screening all blood donations for HBV.

In 2022, only 13% of people living with HBV were aware of their infection, and only 3% (7 million) were receiving treatment. The prevalence of chronic HBV in children under 5 dropped below 1% in 2019 due to widespread vaccination.

WHO recommends adult HBsAg testing in areas with >2% HBV prevalence, with linkage to prevention, care, and treatment services. Targeted testing is advised for high-risk groups, including migrants, partners of infected individuals, health workers, people who inject drugs, people in prisons, men who have sex with men, sex workers, transgender individuals, and people living with HIV.

**Treatment:**
There is no specific treatment for acute HBV; care focuses on relieving symptoms and preventing dehydration.

Chronic hepatitis B can be treated with antiviral medicines such as **tenofovir** and **entecavir**, which:
- Slow progression to cirrhosis
- Reduce liver cancer risk
- Improve long-term survival

Most people receiving treatment require lifelong therapy.

The 2024 WHO guidelines estimate that over 50% of people with chronic HBV may require treatment, depending on eligibility criteria.

In low-income countries, liver cancer is often diagnosed late, resulting in high mortality. In high-income countries, earlier diagnosis allows access to surgery, chemotherapy, and liver transplantation.

**Prevention:**
Hepatitis B is preventable through vaccination. All infants should receive the first dose within 24 hours of birth, followed by 2–3 additional doses. Booster doses are generally not required once the series is completed.

The vaccine protects for at least 20 years, and likely for life.

Mother-to-child transmission can be prevented through antiviral treatment during pregnancy and timely vaccination of newborns.

To reduce HBV transmission:
- Practice safe sex using condoms
- Avoid sharing needles or piercing/tattoo equipment
- Wash hands thoroughly after contact with blood or body fluids
- Get vaccinated if working in healthcare or other high-risk settings

**WHO Response:**
Global health sector strategies (GHSS) for HIV, viral hepatitis, and STIs (2022–2030) guide health systems toward ending chronic HBV, HCV, HIV, and STIs by 2030. WHO supports countries by updating guidelines, strengthening prevention, testing and treatment programs, and promoting equitable access to care. WHO also raises awareness through annual World Hepatitis Day campaigns and helps nations integrate HBV strategies into broader universal health coverage and primary healthcare frameworks.

title: Hepatitis C
body:
**Key Facts:**
Hepatitis C is an inflammation of the liver caused by the hepatitis C virus (HCV). It can cause both acute and chronic hepatitis, ranging from mild illness to lifelong disease including cirrhosis and liver cancer. HCV is a bloodborne virus, commonly transmitted through unsafe injections, unscreened blood transfusions, shared needles among people who inject drugs, and sexual practices that involve blood exposure. Globally, around 50 million people have chronic HCV infection, with 1 million new infections each year. In 2022, approximately 242,000 people died from hepatitis C, mostly from cirrhosis and liver cancer. Direct-acting antiviral medicines (DAAs) can cure more than 95% of patients, but access to diagnosis and treatment remains low. There is currently no effective vaccine for hepatitis C.

**Overview:**
Hepatitis C is a viral liver infection that can be acute (short-term) or chronic (long-term). It spreads through contact with infected blood, including through unsafe medical procedures, unscreened transfusions, shared needles and syringes, and certain sexual practices. Symptoms may include fever, fatigue, appetite loss, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, dark urine, and jaundice. There is no vaccine, but antiviral treatments can cure the infection. Early detection and treatment prevent serious complications.

Acute infections are often asymptomatic and do not usually become life-threatening. About 30% of people clear the virus spontaneously within six months. However, 70% develop chronic infection, and 15–30% of these individuals progress to cirrhosis within 20 years.

**Geographical Distribution:**
HCV occurs in all WHO regions. The highest burden is in the Eastern Mediterranean Region (12 million). Other regions with high chronic infection include:
- South-East Asia: 9 million
- Europe: 9 million
- Western Pacific: 7 million
- Africa: 8 million
- Americas: 5 million

About 2.3 million of the estimated 39 million people living with HIV also show past or current HCV infection. Chronic liver disease is a major cause of illness and death among people living with HIV.

**Transmission:**
Hepatitis C is most commonly transmitted through:
- Reuse or poor sterilization of medical equipment (needles, syringes)
- Unscreened blood transfusions and blood products
- Sharing injection equipment among people who inject drugs

Less common transmission routes include mother-to-child transmission and sexual practices with blood exposure (e.g., among people with multiple partners or men who have sex with men). HCV is **not** spread through breast milk, food, water, hugging, kissing, or sharing food/drinks.

**Symptoms:**
Acute HCV infection is often asymptomatic. When symptoms occur, they may take 2 weeks to 6 months to appear. Possible symptoms include:
- Fever
- Fatigue
- Loss of appetite
- Nausea and vomiting
- Abdominal pain
- Dark urine
- Pale stools
- Joint pain
- Jaundice

Chronic infection may remain silent for decades until serious liver damage develops.

**Testing and Diagnosis:**
Most new HCV infections go undiagnosed because they are asymptomatic. Chronic infections are often diagnosed late, after liver damage is already present.

Diagnosis involves two steps:
1. **Anti-HCV antibody test** to identify past or present infection.
2. **Nucleic acid test (NAT) for HCV RNA** to confirm chronic infection.

People who clear the virus naturally remain antibody-positive but RNA-negative. After diagnosis, liver damage should be assessed via biopsy or non-invasive tests.

WHO recommends testing for people at higher risk, including:
- Blood donors
- People with liver disease
- Migrants from high-prevalence countries
- Healthcare workers
- People who inject drugs
- People in prisons
- Men who have sex with men (MSM)
- Sex workers
- People living with HIV or TB

In regions with >2% antibody prevalence, WHO recommends population-wide testing for adults and adolescents.

**Treatment:**
In 2013–2014, interferon-free treatment became available, revolutionizing HCV care. Direct-acting antivirals (DAAs) cure >95% of patients within 8–12 weeks.

WHO recommends pan-genotypic DAAs for all adults, adolescents, and children aged 3 years and older. These medicines have few side effects and are short-course treatments.

The most widely used, low-cost DAA regimen is **sofosbuvir + daclatasvir**, available in many low- and middle-income countries for under USD 50.

Despite effective treatment, global access remains limited. As of 2022:
- 36% of people with HCV knew their diagnosis
- 20% (12.5 million) of diagnosed individuals had been treated

Lifestyle changes such as avoiding alcohol and maintaining a healthy weight support liver health.

**Service Delivery:**
Historically, HCV care depended on specialists in hospital settings. Today, simplified DAA treatment allows testing, diagnosis, and treatment in primary care, harm reduction services, and prisons. WHO recommends decentralization, integration, and task-shifting to increase access.

**Prevention:**
There is no effective vaccine for hepatitis C. Prevention focuses on avoiding exposure to infected blood.

Prevention strategies include:
- Safe and sterile healthcare injections and procedures
- Proper handling of medical waste
- Harm-reduction programs for people who inject drugs (needle exchange, counseling, OAT)
- Screening donated blood
- Practicing safe sex using condoms

People at higher risk include individuals who inject drugs, men who have sex with men, people living with HIV, and individuals undergoing repeated medical procedures.

**WHO Response:**
The WHO Global Health Sector Strategies (2022–2030) guide countries in ending chronic hepatitis B and C, HIV, and sexually transmitted infections by 2030. They emphasize scaling up prevention, testing, and treatment; addressing inequities; and integrating services within universal health coverage. WHO updates guidelines and works with countries to implement best practices.

WHO also collaborates with UNITAID in expanding access to HCV prevention, testing, and treatment in 10 focus countries, especially among people who inject drugs and people in prisons. WHO leads World Hepatitis Day campaigns to raise awareness and promote prevention.

title: Dengue
body:
**Key Facts:**
Dengue is a viral infection caused by the dengue virus (DENV), transmitted to humans through the bites of infected mosquitoes. About half of the world’s population is now at risk, with 100–400 million infections each year. Dengue is common in tropical and sub-tropical climates, especially urban and semi-urban areas. Most infections are mild or asymptomatic, but severe dengue can cause death. Prevention relies on mosquito (vector) control, and there is no specific treatment for dengue or severe dengue. Early detection and access to proper care greatly reduce fatality rates.

**Overview:**
Dengue (also known as break-bone fever) is a mosquito-borne viral infection. It is more common in tropical and subtropical regions. Many infected individuals show no symptoms. When symptoms occur, they often include high fever, headache, body pains, nausea, and rash. Most people recover within 1–2 weeks, but some develop severe dengue requiring hospitalization. Severe cases can be fatal. Risk can be reduced by preventing mosquito bites, especially during daytime when dengue vectors are most active. Treatment focuses on pain management; no specific antiviral treatment exists.

**Symptoms:**
Most people experience mild or no symptoms and recover in 1–2 weeks. When symptoms occur, they usually start 4–10 days after infection and last 2–7 days.

**Common symptoms include:**
- High fever (40°C/104°F)
- Severe headache
- Pain behind the eyes
- Muscle and joint pain
- Nausea
- Vomiting
- Swollen glands
- Rash

People infected a second time are at higher risk of severe dengue. **Severe dengue symptoms** may include:
- Severe abdominal pain
- Persistent vomiting
- Rapid breathing
- Bleeding gums or nose
- Fatigue
- Restlessness
- Blood in vomit or stool
- Extreme thirst
- Pale, cold skin
- Weakness

People with severe symptoms need immediate medical care. After recovery, fatigue may persist for weeks.

**Diagnostics and Treatment:**
Dengue diagnosis relies on laboratory-based or point-of-care tests. Diagnostic methods include:
- NAATs (nucleic acid amplification tests)
- ELISAs
- Rapid diagnostic tests (RDTs)
- Antigen detection
- Molecular detection or virus isolation

Test quality varies widely across countries. There is **no specific treatment** for dengue. Pain can be managed with **paracetamol (acetaminophen)**. **Ibuprofen and aspirin should be avoided** because they increase the risk of bleeding. Severe dengue often requires hospitalization.

**Global Burden:**
Dengue incidence has grown dramatically worldwide. WHO-reported cases increased from 505,430 in 2000 to **14.6 million in 2024**, with over 12,000 dengue-related deaths. Most infections are asymptomatic or mild, leading to significant underreporting. Dengue is endemic in more than 100 countries.

In 2024, dengue spread globally, affecting all continents. Over 13 million cases were reported in the Region of the Americas. Factors driving increased spread include:
- Expansion of vectors (Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus) into new areas
- Climate change (temperature, rainfall, humidity)
- Weak health systems
- Poor surveillance and reporting
- Political instability and population movement

Models estimate **390 million infections each year**, with 96 million cases clinically apparent. In early 2025, over 4 million cases and 3,000 deaths were reported from 97 countries. Dengue continues to spread into Europe and the Eastern Mediterranean.

**Transmission:**
**Mosquito-to-human transmission:**
Dengue is transmitted primarily through the bite of infected **female Aedes aegypti** mosquitoes. Aedes albopictus can also transmit the virus. After feeding on an infected person, the virus replicates inside the mosquito and becomes transmissible after the **extrinsic incubation period (8–12 days)**.

**Human-to-mosquito transmission:**
Mosquitoes can become infected by biting individuals who are:
- Symptomatic
- Pre-symptomatic
- Asymptomatic

Transmission can occur from **2 days before symptoms** to **2 days after fever resolves**. Higher fever and viral load increase infectiousness.

**Maternal transmission:**
Rare but possible. Infection during pregnancy increases risks of pre-term birth, low birthweight, and fetal distress.

**Other rare modes:**
- Blood transfusion
- Organ transplantation
- Transovarial transmission in mosquitoes

**Risk Factors:**
Risk increases with:
- Previous dengue infection (higher risk of severe dengue)
- Rapid, unplanned urbanization (crowding, water storage)
- Human mobility
- Poor community practices in mosquito control
- Climate change
- Expansion of mosquito habitats into new regions

**Prevention and Control:**
Aedes mosquitoes are active during the day. Prevention includes:

**Avoid mosquito bites:**
- Wear long clothing
- Use mosquito nets (preferably insecticide-treated)
- Install window screens
- Use repellents (DEET, Picaridin, IR3535)
- Use coils and vaporizers

**Prevent mosquito breeding:**
- Remove standing water
- Dispose of waste properly
- Clean and cover water storage containers weekly
- Apply insecticides to outdoor water containers

**If infected:**
- Rest
- Drink plenty of fluids
- Use paracetamol
- Avoid NSAIDs
- Monitor for severe symptoms and seek medical care

**Vaccines:**
One vaccine, **QDenga**, is licensed in some countries for ages 6–16 in high-transmission settings. Multiple vaccines are under evaluation.

**WHO Response:**
WHO responds to dengue by:
- Supporting outbreak confirmation using global lab networks
- Providing guidance for outbreak management
- Strengthening surveillance and reporting systems
- Training countries on clinical care, diagnostics, and vector control
- Developing evidence-based policies and strategies
- Assisting countries in adopting the **Global Vector Control Response (2017–2030)** and **Global Arbovirus Initiative (2022–2025)**
- Recommending new tools (insecticides, technologies)
- Collecting official global dengue data
- Publishing guidance for surveillance, diagnosis, case management, and vector control

title: Measles
body:
**Key Facts:**
Measles is a highly contagious, serious airborne disease caused by a virus that can lead to severe complications and death. Measles vaccination averted more than 60 million deaths between 2000 and 2023. Even though a safe and cost-effective vaccine is available, in 2023, there were an estimated 107,500 measles deaths globally, mostly among unvaccinated or under vaccinated children under the age of 5 years. The proportion of children receiving a first dose of measles vaccine was 83% in 2023, well below the 2019 level of 86%.

**Overview:**
Measles is a highly contagious disease caused by a virus. It spreads easily when an infected person breathes, coughs or sneezes. It can cause severe disease, complications, and even death. Measles can affect anyone but is most common in children. Measles infects the respiratory tract and then spreads throughout the body. Symptoms include a high fever, cough, runny nose and a rash all over the body. Being vaccinated is the best way to prevent getting sick with measles or spreading it to other people. The vaccine is safe and helps your body fight off the virus.

Before the introduction of measles vaccine in 1963 and widespread vaccination, major epidemics occurred approximately every two to three years and caused an estimated 2.6 million deaths each year. An estimated 107,500 people died from measles in 2023 – mostly children under the age of five years, despite the availability of a safe and cost-effective vaccine. Accelerated immunization activities by countries, WHO, the Measles & Rubella Partnership (formerly the Measles & Rubella Initiative), and other international partners successfully prevented an estimated 60 million deaths between 2000–2023. Vaccination decreased an estimated measles deaths from 800,062 in 2000 to 107,500 in 2022.

**Effects of the COVID-19 Pandemic:**
The COVID-19 pandemic led to setbacks in surveillance and immunization efforts. The suspension of immunization services and declines in immunization rates and surveillance across the globe left millions of children vulnerable to preventable diseases like measles. No country is exempt from measles, and areas with low immunization encourage the virus to circulate, increasing the likelihood of outbreaks and putting all unvaccinated children at risk. We must regain progress and achieve regional measles elimination targets, despite the COVID-19 pandemic. Immunization programs should be strengthened within primary healthcare, so efforts to reach all children with two measles vaccine doses should be accelerated. Countries should also implement robust surveillance systems to identify and close immunity gaps.

**Signs and Symptoms:**
Symptoms of measles usually begin 10–14 days after exposure to the virus. A prominent rash is the most visible symptom. Early symptoms usually last 4–7 days. They include:
- Running nose
- Cough
- Red and watery eyes
- Small white spots inside the cheeks

The rash begins about 7–18 days after exposure, usually on the face and upper neck. It spreads over about 3 days, eventually to the hands and feet. It usually lasts 5–6 days before fading.

Most deaths from measles are from complications related to the disease. Complications can include:
- Blindness
- Encephalitis (an infection causing brain swelling and potentially brain damage)
- Severe diarrhoea and related dehydration
- Ear infections
- Severe breathing problems including pneumonia

If a woman catches measles during pregnancy, this can be dangerous for the mother and can result in her baby being born prematurely with a low birth weight. Complications are most common in children under 5 years and adults over age 30. They are more likely in children who are malnourished, especially those without enough vitamin A or with a weak immune system from HIV or other diseases. Measles itself also weakens the immune system and can make the body "forget" how to protect itself against infections, leaving children extremely vulnerable.

**Who is at Risk?:**
Any non-immune person (not vaccinated or vaccinated but did not develop immunity) can become infected. Unvaccinated young children and pregnant persons are at highest risk of severe measles complications. Measles is still common, particularly in parts of Africa, the Middle East and Asia. The overwhelming majority of measles deaths occur in countries with low per capita incomes or weak health infrastructures that struggle to reach all children with immunization. Damaged health infrastructure and health services in countries experiencing or recovering from a natural disaster or conflict interrupt routine immunization and overcrowding in residential camps increases the risk of infection. Children with malnutrition or other causes of a weak immune system are at highest risk of death from measles.

**Transmission:**
Measles is one of the world's most contagious diseases, spread by contact with infected nasal or throat secretions (coughing or sneezing) or breathing the air that was breathed by someone with measles. The virus remains active and contagious in the air or on infected surfaces for up to two hours. For this reason, it is very infectious, and one person infected by measles can infect nine out of 10 of their unvaccinated close contacts. It can be transmitted by an infected person from four days prior to the onset of the rash to four days after the rash erupts. Measles outbreaks can result in severe complications and deaths, especially among young, malnourished children. In countries close to measles elimination, cases imported from other countries remain an important source of infection.

**Treatment:**
There is no specific treatment for measles. Caregiving should focus on relieving symptoms, making the person comfortable and preventing complications. Drinking enough water and treatments for dehydration can replace fluids lost to diarrhoea or vomiting. Eating a healthy diet is also important. Doctors may use antibiotics to treat pneumonia and ear and eye infections. All children or adults with measles should receive two doses of vitamin A supplements, given 24 hours apart. This restores low vitamin A levels that occur even in well-nourished children. It can help prevent eye damage and blindness. Vitamin A supplements may also reduce the number of measles deaths.

**Prevention:**
Community-wide vaccination is the most effective way to prevent measles. All children should be vaccinated against measles. The vaccine is safe, effective and inexpensive. Children should receive two doses of the vaccine to ensure they are immune. The first dose is usually given at 9 months of age in countries where measles is common and 12–15 months in other countries. A second dose should be given later in childhood, usually at 15–18 months. The measles vaccine is given alone or often combined with vaccines for mumps, rubella and/or varicella.

Routine measles vaccination, combined with mass immunization campaigns in countries with high case rates are crucial for reducing global measles deaths. The measles vaccine has been in use for about 60 years and costs less than US$ 1 per child. The measles vaccine is also used in emergencies to stop outbreaks from spreading. The risk of measles outbreaks is particularly high amongst refugees, who should be vaccinated as soon as possible. Combining vaccines slightly increases the cost but allows for shared delivery and administration costs and importantly, adds the benefit of protection against rubella, the most common vaccine preventable infection that can infect babies in the womb.

In 2023, 74% of children received both doses of the measles vaccine, and about 83% of the world's children received one dose of measles vaccine by their first birthday. Two doses of the vaccine are recommended to ensure immunity and prevent outbreaks, as not all children develop immunity from the first dose. Approximately 22 million infants missed at least one dose of measles vaccine through routine immunization in 2023.

**WHO Response:**
In 2020, WHO and global stakeholders endorsed the Immunization Agenda 2021–2030. The Agenda aims to achieve the regional targets as a core indicator of impact, positioning measles as a tracer of a health system's ability to deliver essential childhood vaccines. WHO published the Measles and rubella strategic framework in 2020, establishing seven necessary strategic priorities to achieve and sustain the regional measles and rubella elimination goals.

Without sustained attention, hard-fought gains can easily be lost. Where children are unvaccinated, outbreaks occur. Based on current trends of measles vaccination coverage and incidence, the WHO Strategic Advisory Group of Experts on Immunization (SAGE) concluded that measles elimination is under threat, as the disease resurged in numerous countries that achieved, or were close to achieving, elimination. WHO continues to strengthen the Global Measles and Rubella Laboratory Network (GMRLN) to ensure timely diagnosis of measles and track the virus' spread to assist countries in coordinating targeted vaccination activities and reduce deaths from this vaccine-preventable disease.

The Immunization Agenda 2030 Measles & Rubella Partnership (M&RP) is a partnership led by the American Red Cross, United Nations Foundation, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Gavi, the Vaccines Alliance, the Gates Foundation, UNICEF and WHO, to achieve the IA2030 measles and rubella specific targets. Launched in 2001, as the Measles and Rubella Initiative, the revitalized Partnership is committed to ensuring no child dies from measles or is born with congenital rubella syndrome. The Partnership helps countries plan, fund and measure efforts to permanently stop measles and rubella.

title: Pneumonia in children
body:
**Key Facts:**
Pneumonia accounts for 14% of all deaths of children under 5 years old, killing 740,180 children in 2019. Pneumonia can be caused by viruses, bacteria or fungi. Pneumonia can be prevented by immunization, adequate nutrition, and by addressing environmental factors. Pneumonia caused by bacteria can be treated with antibiotics, but only one third of children with pneumonia receive the antibiotics they need.

**Overview:**
