Diabetic retinopathy is a diabetes complication that damages retinal blood vessels. It can arise in anyone with type 1 or type 2 diabetes, and risk rises with disease duration and poor glucose control. Early stages may be symptom-free, but unmanaged disease can cause severe vision loss or blindness.

**Symptoms:**
- Floaters (spots or dark strings)
- Blurred vision
- Fluctuating or changing vision
- Dark or empty areas in the visual field
- Vision loss

Seek prompt eye care if vision becomes blurry, spotty, or hazy. People with diabetes—including those who develop gestational diabetes—should get yearly dilated eye exams, with more frequent checks during pregnancy if advised.

**Causes and types:**
Chronic high blood sugar harms tiny retinal vessels, reducing blood supply. In advanced disease, the eye grows abnormal new vessels that leak easily.
- **Nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR):** Vessel walls weaken, forming bulges that leak fluid or blood. Swelling in larger vessels and macular edema can occur, progressing from mild to severe as more vessels are damaged.
- **Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR):** Closed vessels spur growth of fragile new vessels that bleed into the vitreous. Scar tissue can pull the retina away (detachment) and blocked fluid drainage can raise eye pressure, causing glaucoma.

**Risk factors:**
- Long duration of diabetes
- Poor glycemic control
- High blood pressure
- High cholesterol
- Pregnancy
- Tobacco use
- Being Black, Latino, or Native American

**Complications:**
- **Vitreous hemorrhage:** Bleeding into the vitreous causes floaters or vision loss; vision often returns once blood clears if the retina is unharmed.
- **Retinal detachment:** Scar tissue can separate the retina, leading to flashes, floaters, missing vision areas, or severe loss.
- **Glaucoma:** New vessels on the iris block fluid drainage, raising pressure and damaging the optic nerve.
- **Blindness:** Diabetic retinopathy, macular edema, and glaucoma can collectively result in permanent vision loss.

**Prevention:**
Regular eye exams, tight blood sugar and blood pressure control, and rapid treatment of vision changes help prevent vision loss. Manage diabetes with healthy eating, activity (e.g., 150 minutes of moderate exercise weekly), and prescribed medicines or insulin. Monitor blood glucose, track A1C goals, control lipids, stop smoking, and report sudden vision changes immediately. Proper diabetes management can prevent or delay retinopathy.

title: Toxic shock syndrome
body:
**Overview:**
Toxic shock syndrome (TSS) is a rare, potentially fatal complication of certain bacterial infections. It is most often caused by toxins from *Staphylococcus aureus* (staph) but can also result from group A streptococcus (strep). Anyone can develop TSS. Risk increases with skin wounds, recent surgery, and use of tampons or other vaginal devices (menstrual cups, birth control sponges, diaphragms) left in place too long.

**Symptoms:**
TSS develops suddenly and may include:
- High fever
- Low blood pressure
- Vomiting or diarrhea
- Sunburn-like rash, especially on palms and soles
- Confusion
- Muscle aches
- Red eyes, mouth, and throat
- Seizures
- Headaches

**When to seek care:**
Contact a healthcare professional immediately if TSS symptoms appear, particularly if you use tampons or have a skin or wound infection.

**Causes:**
Toxins produced by staph bacteria most commonly cause TSS. Strep bacteria toxins can also trigger the syndrome.

**Risk factors:**
While TSS can affect anyone, about half of staph-related cases occur in people who menstruate. Strep TSS occurs across all ages. Factors tied to higher risk include:
- Cuts or burns
- Recent surgery
- Use of birth control sponges, diaphragms, high-absorbency tampons, or menstrual cups for prolonged periods
- Viral infections such as flu or chickenpox

**Complications:**
TSS can progress quickly and may lead to shock, kidney (renal) failure, damage to other organs including the heart and liver, or death.

**Prevention:**
The FDA reviews tampons for safety and bacterial growth risk. To lower TSS risk:
- Use the lowest absorbency tampon needed
- Change tampons every 4–8 hours
- Alternate between tampons and sanitary napkins, using mini pads or liners when flow is light
- Avoid tampons if you’ve had TSS or other serious staph or strep infections

Prompt recognition of symptoms and medical care are critical because TSS can recur.

title: Anaphylaxis
body:
**Overview:**
Anaphylaxis is a severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can occur within seconds or minutes after exposure to allergens such as foods, medications, insect stings, or latex. Sudden immune activation releases chemicals that trigger shock, marked by sharp blood pressure drops and airway narrowing. Immediate intramuscular epinephrine and emergency care are critical; without rapid treatment, anaphylaxis can be fatal.

**Symptoms:**
Symptoms typically start within minutes but occasionally appear later. Signs include:
- Hives, itching, flushed or pale skin
- Low blood pressure (hypotension)
- Airway constriction and swelling of tongue or throat causing wheezing or breathing difficulty
- Weak, rapid pulse
- Nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea
- Dizziness or fainting

**When to seek care:**
Seek emergency help immediately when severe allergy symptoms occur—don’t wait to see if they improve. Use an epinephrine autoinjector promptly if available, then go to the emergency department even if symptoms improve to monitor for biphasic reactions. Follow up with an allergist/immunologist for diagnosis and long-term management after any severe attack.

**Causes:**
Anaphylaxis occurs when the immune system overreacts to otherwise harmless substances, releasing mediators that affect the whole body. Common triggers include:
- Foods (peanuts, tree nuts, fish, shellfish, wheat, soy, sesame, milk)
- Medications (antibiotics, aspirin, other pain relievers, IV contrast)
- Insect venom (bees, wasps, hornets, yellow jackets, fire ants)
- Latex
Less commonly, exercise (sometimes combined with specific foods or extreme temperatures) triggers symptoms. Some cases remain idiopathic.

**Risk factors:**
- Previous anaphylaxis (future reactions may be more severe)
- Existing allergies or asthma
- Certain medical conditions such as heart disease or mastocytosis

**Complications:**
Anaphylaxis can stop breathing or heartbeat, making rapid intervention essential.

**Prevention:**
Avoid known triggers and:
- Wear a medical alert bracelet or necklace
- Keep an emergency kit with prescribed medications; monitor epinephrine autoinjector expiration dates
- Inform healthcare providers about drug reactions
- Take precautions around stinging insects (protective clothing, avoid bright colors or scents, don’t go barefoot, cover drinks)
- For food allergies, read labels carefully, recheck frequent items, and question restaurant staff about ingredients and preparation

Even with caution, accidental exposures may happen. Recognizing symptoms and having a plan for rapid treatment are vital to prevent serious outcomes.

title: Cardiogenic shock
body:
**Overview:**
Cardiogenic shock is a life-threatening condition in which the heart suddenly cannot pump enough blood to meet the body’s needs. It most often follows a large or severe heart attack but can also result from other cardiac injuries. Although rare, it is frequently fatal without immediate treatment.

**Symptoms:**
Cardiogenic shock signs include very fast breathing, severe shortness of breath, rapid heartbeat, weak pulse, low blood pressure, sweating, cold extremities, little to no urine output, and confusion or loss of consciousness. Because it commonly follows a heart attack, watch for heart attack symptoms such as chest pressure or pain, discomfort radiating to the shoulder, arm, back, neck, jaw, or upper belly, cold sweats, fatigue, heartburn-like discomfort, dizziness, nausea, or shortness of breath. Symptoms can be atypical, particularly in women.

**When to seek care:**
Call emergency services immediately if cardiogenic shock or heart attack symptoms occur. Rapid treatment improves survival and limits heart damage. Do not drive yourself to the hospital.

**Causes:**
Cardiogenic shock usually occurs when the lower left heart chamber (left ventricle) cannot get enough oxygen, typically due to a heart attack. Less commonly, right ventricular damage, myocarditis, infective endocarditis, generalized heart weakness, or drug overdose can trigger the condition.

**Risk factors:**
- Older age
- History of heart failure or prior heart attacks
- Existing heart or blood vessel disease
- Diabetes or high blood pressure
- Female sex

**Complications:**
Without prompt treatment, cardiogenic shock can quickly lead to death or cause severe damage to organs such as the liver and kidneys due to lack of oxygen.

**Prevention:**
Prevent cardiogenic shock by reducing heart attack risk:
- Don’t smoke and avoid secondhand smoke
- Maintain a healthy weight
- Eat a heart-healthy diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and whole grains while limiting sugar, salt, and saturated or trans fats
- Manage blood pressure, cholesterol, and diabetes with regular checkups
- Limit alcohol (up to one drink daily for women, two for men) or avoid it altogether
- Exercise regularly—aim for at least 30 minutes of activity daily
- Prioritize good sleep (7–9 hours per night for adults)
- Manage stress through exercise, mindfulness, and social support

If a heart attack occurs, seek emergency care immediately to help prevent cardiogenic shock.

title: Slowing Sarcopenia
body:
**Overview:**
Starting around age 30, people naturally lose 3–5% of muscle mass every decade. Excessive loss reduces strength and can lead to sarcopenia, making everyday activities—standing from a chair, walking, opening jars, carrying groceries—more difficult and raising fall risk. Chronic illnesses, inactivity, unhealthy diet, and hormonal changes (e.g., menopause) can accelerate muscle loss. NIH experts estimate 10–20% of older adults have sarcopenia.

**Understanding sarcopenia:**
Assessing sarcopenia is challenging because there’s no single standard test. NIH-funded researchers analyzed large datasets and found grip strength and walking speed (slower than 2.6 feet per second) better predict falls, mobility limits, hip fractures, and mortality than lean body mass. As sarcopenia worsens, hospitalization risk nearly doubles, fractures and loss of independence rise, and the body struggles more to fight diseases such as cancer.

**Prevention and management:**
- **Stay active:** Regular physical activity is essential. Resistance training—push-ups, squats, weight lifting, planks, yoga poses, knee raises—builds strength. Start slowly, work all major muscle groups (arms, legs, abs, back, chest), and aim for consistent routines. Even five minutes helps when beginning.
- **Prioritize protein:** Muscles need protein for maintenance. Eating about 1.2 grams of protein per 2 pounds of body weight supports treatment or management of sarcopenia. Include lean meats, poultry, fish, seafood, eggs, low-fat dairy, legumes, nuts, and seeds.
- **Consider supplements cautiously:** Combining diet and exercise with certain supplements—amino acids, fish oil, vitamin D, selenium, magnesium, omega-3 fatty acids—may help slow muscle loss, though more research is needed.
- **Consult healthcare providers:** If you suspect sarcopenia, talk with your doctor to design a personalized plan to preserve muscle, reduce falls, and maintain independence.

**Wise choices for muscle strength:**
- Start new exercise routines gradually and choose activities you can sustain.
- Engage every major muscle group.
- Focus on strength and resistance exercises (push-ups, squats, sit-ups, arm curls, planks, side twists, knee raises, arm/leg lifts).
- Do what you can—short sessions are better than none.
- Eat sufficient protein daily.
- Discuss new exercise plans with your healthcare provider to choose safe options.

Maintaining muscle through activity, protein-rich nutrition, and informed guidance helps slow sarcopenia and supports healthy aging.

title: Healthy Diet
body:
A healthy diet protects against malnutrition in all its forms and helps prevent noncommunicable diseases (NCDs) such as diabetes, heart disease, stroke and cancer. Unhealthy diets combined with physical inactivity are leading global risks to health. Healthy dietary practices begin early: exclusive breastfeeding for the first 6 months supports growth, cognitive development, and may lower the risk of overweight, obesity and NCDs later in life. Throughout life, energy intake should balance energy expenditure. Total fat intake should stay below 30% of total energy, with saturated fats under 10% and trans-fats under 1%, while prioritizing unsaturated fats and eliminating industrially produced trans-fats. Free sugars should be less than 10% of energy intake (with <5% for additional benefit). Salt intake should remain under 5 g per day (sodium <2 g), using iodized salt. WHO Member States aim to reduce population salt intake by 30% and halt rises in diabetes, obesity and childhood overweight by 2025.

**Overview:**
Changing lifestyles, urbanization and increased consumption of processed, energy-dense foods have shifted dietary patterns, often reducing intake of fruits, vegetables and dietary fibre. Although dietary needs vary with age, gender, activity level, culture and available foods, the core principles of balanced, diversified nutrition are consistent worldwide.

**Adult dietary recommendations:**
- Emphasize fruits, vegetables, legumes, nuts and whole grains (e.g., unprocessed maize, millet, oats, wheat, brown rice).
- Consume at least 400 g (five portions) of fruits and vegetables daily, excluding starchy roots.
- Limit free sugars to <10% of total energy (ideally <5%); free sugars include added sugars and those naturally present in honey, syrups, fruit juices and concentrates.
- Keep total fat <30% of energy, prioritizing unsaturated fats (fish, avocado, nuts, sunflower/soybean/canola/olive oils) over saturated fats (fatty meats, butter, palm or coconut oil, cream, cheese, ghee, lard) and avoiding industrial trans-fats in baked/fried/pre-packaged foods as well as limiting ruminant trans-fats.
- Limit salt to <5 g per day and ensure salt is iodized.

**Infants and young children:**
- Exclusive breastfeeding for the first 6 months.
- Continued breastfeeding to 2 years of age and beyond.
- From 6 months, introduce safe, nutrient-dense complementary foods without added salt or sugar while maintaining breastfeeding.

**Practical guidance:**
- **Fruit and vegetables:** Include vegetables in meals, use fresh produce as snacks, choose seasonal varieties, and eat a diverse assortment.
- **Fats:** Keep total fat <30% of energy; reduce saturated fat to <10% and trans-fat to <1%, replacing them with unsaturated fats. Opt for steaming/boiling instead of frying, swap butter/ghee for oils rich in polyunsaturated fats, choose lean or reduced-fat animal products, and minimize baked/fried snacks containing industrial trans-fats.
- **Salt/Sodium/Potassium:** Most individuals consume 9–12 g of salt daily—well above recommendations—and insufficient potassium (<3.5 g). Excess sodium and low potassium raise blood pressure. Reducing salt to <5 g per day could prevent 1.7 million deaths annually. Limit high-sodium condiments, remove table salt, restrict salty snacks, select lower-sodium products, and increase potassium intake via fresh fruits and vegetables.
- **Sugars:** Limit free sugars to <10% of energy (ideally <5%). Reducing sugary snacks and sugar-sweetened beverages lowers risks of dental caries, overweight, obesity, and cardiovascular risk factors. Replace sugary snacks with fresh fruits or raw vegetables.

**Promoting healthy diets:**
Dietary choices are influenced by income, food prices, culture, preferences, and environmental factors. Governments and stakeholders can create supportive food environments by aligning trade, agriculture and health policies; incentivizing production and affordability of healthy foods; discouraging processed foods high in saturated fat, trans-fat, free sugars and salt; reformulating products; implementing marketing restrictions to children; establishing nutrition standards in public institutions; adopting clear nutrition labelling (including front-of-pack labels); and offering nutrition counselling in primary care. Education and school programmes that build culinary skills and awareness further encourage healthy habits.

**Infant and young child feeding promotion:**
Key actions include enforcing the International Code of Marketing of Breast-milk Substitutes, protecting working mothers, and supporting breastfeeding through initiatives such as the Baby-friendly Hospital Initiative.

**WHO response:**
WHO’s Global Strategy on Diet, Physical Activity and Health (2004) mobilizes governments, partners and civil society to advance healthy diets. Additional milestones include recommendations on marketing to children (2010), the Comprehensive Implementation Plan on Maternal, Infant and Young Child Nutrition (2012), and global voluntary NCD targets (2013) calling for salt reduction and halting rises in diabetes and obesity. WHO’s Commission on Ending Childhood Obesity (2014–2016) issued context-specific strategies. Jointly with FAO, WHO convened the Second International Conference on Nutrition (2014), resulting in the Rome Declaration and Framework for Action promoting healthy diets across the life course. WHO’s Thirteenth General Programme of Work (2019–2023) prioritizes sodium reduction and elimination of industrial trans-fats, supported by the REPLACE action package. These efforts guide countries in implementing policies, nutrition targets and programmes that ensure diversified, safe and nutritious diets for all ages.

title: Autism
body:
Autism, also referred to as autism spectrum disorder (ASD), encompasses a diverse group of neurodevelopmental conditions. In 2021, about 1 in 127 people worldwide had autism, though prevalence varies by study and remains unknown in many low- and middle-income countries. Characteristics can be detected in early childhood but are often diagnosed later. Autistic individuals differ widely in abilities and support needs: some live independently, while others require lifelong care. Community-level inclusion, accessibility and support are essential.

**Overview:**
ASD is marked by challenges with social interaction and communication, alongside atypical behaviours such as difficulty transitioning between activities, intense focus on details, and unusual sensory responses. Autism influences education and employment opportunities, and can place substantial demands on families. Co-occurring conditions—such as epilepsy, depression, anxiety, and attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder—are common, and intellectual functioning ranges from profound impairment to superior abilities.

**Epidemiology:**
Global prevalence estimates average 1 in 127 people, but figures vary greatly between studies and regions. Many LMICs lack data.

**Causes and risk factors:**
Autism likely results from multiple interacting genetic and environmental factors. Associated exposures include advanced parental age, maternal diabetes, prenatal air pollution or heavy metal exposure, prematurity, severe birth complications, low birth weight, and in-utero exposure to certain medicines (e.g., valproate, carbamazepine). Extensive evidence shows no link between autism and vaccines, including measles-mumps-rubella (MMR), thiomersal, or aluminium-containing vaccines. The study suggesting otherwise was fraudulent and retracted.

**Assessment and care:**
Early identification and evidence-based psychosocial interventions improve communication, social skills, development and quality of life. Routine monitoring of child development in maternal and child health services supports earlier detection. Once diagnosed, autistic people and caregivers should receive tailored information, services, referrals and practical support. Care needs are complex, spanning health promotion, treatment, rehabilitation, and collaboration across health, education, employment and social sectors. Programmes must be co-designed with autistic people, and community-level efforts should promote accessibility and inclusion.

**Human rights:**
Autistic people have the same right to the highest attainable standard of health as others, yet often face stigma, discrimination, and denial of services, education and community participation. They share common health needs with the general population but may have additional requirements due to autism or co-occurring conditions. Behavioural risk factors (physical inactivity, poor diet) and vulnerability to violence, injury and abuse contribute to higher rates of chronic illness and premature mortality. Autistic people also face elevated unmet healthcare needs and heightened risks during humanitarian emergencies, often due to providers’ limited knowledge of autism.

**Global response:**
In 2014, the World Health Assembly adopted a resolution urging coordinated efforts to manage ASD and strengthen national capacity. WHO works with Member States to: increase governmental commitment; guide policy and action plans across health, mental health, neurological disorders and disability; strengthen the health workforce; and foster inclusive environments with caregiver support. The Comprehensive Mental Health Action Plan 2013–2030 and the Intersectoral Global Action Plan on Epilepsy and Other Neurological Disorders call for improved early detection, care, treatment and rehabilitation of neurodevelopmental conditions, as well as addressing social, economic, educational and inclusion needs and strengthening research and surveillance.

title: Rabies
body:
Rabies is a viral, zoonotic, neglected tropical disease present in more than 150 countries, mainly across Asia and Africa. It causes tens of thousands of deaths annually, 40% in children under 15. In up to 99% of human cases, transmission follows dog bites or scratches. Dog-mediated rabies is vaccine-preventable. The virus infects mammals (dogs, cats, livestock, wildlife) and spreads through saliva via bites, scratches, or contact with mucosa. Children aged 5–14 are frequent victims. Once the virus reaches the central nervous system and symptoms begin, rabies is uniformly fatal. However, prompt post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP)—immediate wound cleansing, a course of human rabies vaccine, and rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) when indicated—prevents the virus from entering the nervous system.

**Symptoms**
- Incubation typically spans 2–3 months (range: 1 week to 1 year), influenced by exposure site and viral load
- Prodromal symptoms include fever, pain, and paresthesia at the wound
- As the virus invades the central nervous system, encephalomyelitis develops
- Furious rabies involves hyperactivity, agitation, hallucinations, hydrophobia, aerophobia and causes death within days due to cardio-respiratory arrest
- Paralytic rabies (approximately 20% of cases) causes ascending paralysis, coma and eventual death but is often misdiagnosed
- Once symptoms appear, survival is extremely rare and associated with severe neurological deficits

**Causes**
- Dog bites or scratches (up to 99% of human cases)
- Virus spreads through saliva via bites, scratches, or contact with mucosa
- In the Americas, where dog-mediated rabies is largely controlled, hematophagous bats are now the primary source
- Bat-mediated rabies also threatens Australia and parts of Western Europe
- Human rabies from foxes, raccoons, skunks, or other wild mammals is rare
- Inhalation of aerosolized virus, consumption of raw products from infected animals, organ transplantation, or human-to-human transmission is exceedingly rare

**Prevention**
- Mass vaccination of dogs, including puppies, is the most cost-effective prevention method
- Public education on dog behaviour, bite prevention, immediate wound care, and responsible pet ownership
- Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) is recommended for high-risk occupations (laboratory staff, animal control, wildlife rangers), travellers or residents in remote, highly endemic areas
- Post-exposure prophylaxis consists of thorough wound washing with soap and water for at least 15 minutes, a vaccine course, and RIG or monoclonal antibodies when indicated
- Category I (touching/feeding animals, licks on intact skin): wash exposed skin, no PEP
- Category II (nibbling of uncovered skin, minor scratches without bleeding): wound washing and immediate vaccination
- Category III (transdermal bites/scratches, mucosal exposure, contact with bats): wound washing, immediate vaccination, RIG/monoclonal antibodies

**When to see a doctor**
- Anyone bitten or scratched by a potentially rabid animal should seek PEP immediately
- Prompt post-exposure prophylaxis is critical and prevents the virus from entering the nervous system

title: Infertility
body:
Infertility is a disease of the male or female reproductive system defined by the inability to achieve a pregnancy after 12 months or more of regular unprotected sexual intercourse. Globally, an estimated 1 in 6 people of reproductive age experience infertility in their lifetime. Causes may stem from male, female, combined or unexplained factors. Infertility may be primary (no previous pregnancy) or secondary (after at least one prior pregnancy). Some causes are preventable. Fertility care includes prevention, diagnosis and treatment but remains inaccessible or unaffordable for many, particularly in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs), and is rarely included in universal health coverage benefit packages. Treatment often involves assisted reproductive technologies (ART) such as in vitro fertilization (IVF) and other medically assisted reproduction.

**Causes**
- Female factors: tubal disorders (e.g., blocked fallopian tubes from untreated STIs, complications of unsafe abortion, postpartum sepsis, pelvic surgery)
- Uterine conditions (inflammatory such as endometriosis, congenital such as septate uterus, benign such as fibroids)
- Ovarian disorders (e.g., polycystic ovarian syndrome, other follicular disorders)
- Endocrine disorders affecting the hypothalamus or pituitary (including pituitary cancers, hypopituitarism)
- Male factors: obstruction of reproductive tract affecting semen ejection (e.g., ejaculatory duct or seminal vesicle blockages from injuries or infections)
- Hormonal disorders involving the pituitary, hypothalamus or testicles (e.g., pituitary/testicular cancers)
- Testicular failure to produce sperm (varicoceles, gonadotoxic treatments such as chemotherapy)
- Abnormal sperm morphology or motility (e.g., anabolic steroid use)
- Lifestyle factors (smoking, excessive alcohol, obesity)
- Exposure to environmental pollutants or toxins can impair gametes

**Prevention**
- Integrate fertility awareness into comprehensive sexuality education
- Promote healthy lifestyles
- Prevent and treat STIs
- Avert complications of unsafe abortion, postpartum sepsis and pelvic surgery
- Address environmental toxins
- Avoid smoking
- Limit excessive alcohol intake
- Maintain healthy weight to prevent obesity

title: Sexual Health
body: Sexual health is fundamental to individual, familial, community and societal well-being and development. An affirmative view of sexual health requires positive, respectful approaches to sexuality and relationships, and the possibility of pleasurable, safe sexual experiences free of coercion, discrimination and violence. Achieving sexual health and well-being depends on access to comprehensive, high-quality information about sex and sexuality; awareness of risks and personal vulnerability; access to sexual health care; and supportive environments that promote sexual health. Sexual health is a state of physical, emotional, mental and social well-being in relation to sexuality; not merely the absence of disease, dysfunction or infirmity. It requires a positive and respectful approach to sexuality and sexual relationships, and the possibility of having pleasurable and safe sexual experiences, free of coercion, discrimination and violence. Sexual health concerns span sexual orientation, gender identity, expression, relationships and pleasure, as well as adverse outcomes such as HIV, sexually transmitted infections (STIs), reproductive tract infections (RTIs), unintended pregnancy, sexual dysfunction, sexual violence, and harmful practices like female genital mutilation (FGM). Sexual health concerns well-being, not just absence of disease; requires respect, safety, and freedom from discrimination and violence; depends on fulfilment of human rights; applies throughout the lifespan, for youth and older adults as well as people of reproductive age; is expressed through diverse sexualities and forms of expression; is shaped by gender norms, roles, expectations, and power dynamics; and must be understood within specific social, economic and political contexts.

title: Child Growth
body:
Child malnutrition remains a major public health issue. Globally, about 144 million children under five are stunted, 47 million are wasted and 38.3 million have overweight or obesity. Roughly 45% of deaths among children under five are linked to undernutrition. Monitoring growth is crucial for child health surveillance: inadequate infant growth due to poor nutrition can lead to undernutrition in low- and middle-income countries and later transition to overweight or obesity when calorie intake rises. The WHO Child Growth Standards help track height and weight for boys and girls from birth to five years, identifying children or populations not growing properly, underweight, or at risk of overweight to guide clinical and public health responses. These standards are used in health facilities, research institutions, advocacy organizations and ministries of health worldwide.

**Impact:**
- **Stunting:** Children too short for their age due to chronic or recurrent malnutrition. Stunting contributes to child mortality and signals development inequities.
- **Overweight:** Children too heavy for their height, often from low energy expenditure relative to intake or endocrine imbalances, raising later-life NCD risk.
- **Wasting:** Children too thin for their height from recent rapid weight loss or failure to gain weight. Moderate or severe wasting markedly increases mortality risk but is treatable.
Wasting and overweight can coexist in populations: in 2020, 6.7% (45.4 million) and 5.7% (38.9 million) of children under five were wasted and overweight, respectively.

**Prevention:**
In 2020, 22% (149.2 million) of children under five were stunted, down from 24.4% in 2015, but achieving a 50% reduction by 2030 requires doubling the annual decline from 2.1% to 3.9%. Key prevention pathways are consistent across malnutrition forms: adequate maternal nutrition before and during pregnancy and breastfeeding; optimal breastfeeding in the first two years; nutritious, diverse, and safe complementary foods in early childhood; and healthy environments with access to basic health care, water, hygiene, sanitation and safe physical activity. Threats—including COVID-19 disruptions—jeopardize progress; urgent action is needed to safeguard maternal and child nutrition, especially in hard-hit regions, ensuring every child’s right to nutrition.

title: Fragility Fractures
body:
**Overview:**
Fractures are partial or complete breaks in bone that can occur spontaneously (e.g., due to osteoporosis) or from trauma (falls, road crashes, sports). They pose significant morbidity, mortality and cost burdens worldwide. Data from the Global Burden of Disease Study show rising incidence, prevalence and YLDs since 1990, with highest rates in older age groups where fragility fractures predominate. Costs are escalating (e.g., a projected 27% increase in fragility fracture costs by 2030 in the largest five EU countries plus Sweden). Early risk assessment and osteoporosis treatment are essential.

**Types:**
Fragility fractures arise from low-energy trauma that would not normally cause fracture, typically due to osteoporosis. Common sites include spine, hip, distal forearm (wrist) and proximal humerus; others include pelvis, ribs and proximal tibia. Hip and vertebral fractures carry the highest seriousness.

**Risk factors:**
- **Modifiable:** smoking, alcohol use, physical inactivity, low body weight, nutrient-poor diets, vitamin D/calcium deficiency, eating disorders, malabsorption, certain medications (glucocorticoids, antidepressants, anticonvulsants, androgen deprivation therapy), and falls.
- **Non-modifiable:** older age, female sex, Caucasian ethnicity, prior fractures, parental fracture history, menopause.
Osteoporosis—low bone density and microarchitectural deterioration—is itself a major risk factor, increasing bone fragility and susceptibility to fracture.

**Risk prediction:**
Multiple fracture risk assessment tools combine clinical risk factors (age, sex, prior fractures) with or without bone mineral density (BMD) to estimate five- or ten-year fracture probability and inform treatment decisions. WHO is assessing available tools to recommend models for global use.

**Primary prevention:**
Strategies focus on maintaining bone density and strength: adequate diet and nutrition, regular exercise/physical activity, smoking cessation, limiting alcohol, treating osteoporosis, and preventing falls. While basic principles are agreed upon, debates continue on specific interventions and treatment duration; WHO is reassessing evidence on prevention measures.

**Treatment and management:**
Early detection and treatment (secondary prevention) are crucial—many vertebral fractures remain undiagnosed. Management may be surgical or non-surgical, with orthopaedic care central. Secondary (refracture) prevention and tertiary strategies include rehabilitation and quality-of-life improvement. Timely rehabilitation, assistive products (walking aids, orthoses) and training help individuals recover function.

**Comorbidities:**
Conditions such as diabetes, hypertension, cardiovascular disease, kidney and liver disease, depression, dementia, and HIV can coexist with fragility fractures, raising risks of post-fracture complications (e.g., infections, stroke) and impairing recovery. Identifying and co-managing comorbidities improves outcomes.

**WHO response:**
- **Rehabilitation 2030 Initiative:** emphasizes rehabilitation—including fracture care—as a core universal health coverage service; the WHO Package of interventions for rehabilitation outlines essential measures and resources for fractures.
- **UN Decade of Healthy Ageing (2021–2030):** fosters global collaboration to improve older adults’ lives; the WHO Integrated Care for Older People (ICOPE) recommends actions to prevent or slow declines, including fall prevention.
- **WHO Bone Health and Ageing Initiative (2023):** develops a strategic roadmap to optimize bone health for healthy ageing and advocates public health strategies to prevent fractures among older adults.

title: Helping Your Child with Anger Issues
body:
Anger is a normal, useful emotion that signals when something feels unfair or wrong. It becomes a concern when a child’s angry behaviour turns aggressive or unmanageable. Common triggers include witnessing family conflict, friendship problems, bullying, academic stress, anxiety or fear, and hormonal changes in puberty. Sometimes the cause is unclear, so it’s important to help children explore what might be driving their anger.

**Tackle anger together:**
Work with your child so they understand anger is the problem—not them. With younger children, naming and drawing anger (e.g., a volcano ready to erupt) can make it manageable. Your reactions influence theirs, so approach anger as a team challenge.

**Spot the signs:**
Help your child recognize early physical cues—fast heartbeat, tense muscles, clenched teeth or fists, stomach churning. Noticing these signs enables proactive coping.

**Strategies for your child:**
Identify triggers and agree on techniques such as counting to 10, walking away, slow deep breathing, clenching/unclenching fists, talking to a trusted person, or taking time alone to calm down. Point out signs when you notice them, giving your child a chance to use their strategies.

**Encourage active play:**
Regular physical activity (walks, jogging, running, cycling) can reduce anger and ease stress, anxiety or low mood. Refer to guidance on physical activity for children and young people.

**Be positive:**
Offer frequent praise for your child’s efforts—and your own—however small. Positive feedback builds confidence in managing anger and reinforces that you’re learning together.

**When to seek help:**
If anger harms your child or others, talk to a GP, health visitor or school nurse. A GP may refer to Children and Young People’s Mental Health Services (CYPMHS) for specialist support. In some areas, self-referral is possible. Additional support is available via the YoungMinds parents’ helpline (0808 802 5544, weekdays), YoungMinds resources for parents and young people, and MindEd for Families.

**Key actions:**
- Explore causes and feelings underlying anger.
- Collaborate on coping strategies and practice them early.
- Promote regular activity and positive reinforcement.
- Seek professional help if anger becomes harmful.

By responding calmly, modelling constructive coping, and accessing support when needed, parents can help children manage anger and develop healthier emotional skills.

title: Abusive Head Trauma
body:
Abusive head trauma (AHT), including shaken baby syndrome, is a severe form of child abuse that causes brain injury and is a leading cause of child abuse deaths in U.S. children under five. It typically occurs when a frustrated caregiver violently shakes or impacts an infant, often in response to persistent crying. This trauma can lead to bleeding around the brain or behind the eyes and results in serious long-term consequences such as vision problems, developmental delays, physical disabilities and hearing loss. About one-third of child maltreatment deaths involve AHT, and up to one in four affected babies dies. Infants under one year are at greatest risk.

**Key facts:**
- Crying (even inconsolable crying) is normal in infants; shaking, throwing or hitting a baby is never an appropriate response.
- AHT accounts for a substantial portion of child maltreatment fatalities.

**Prevention:**
Anyone can help prevent AHT by understanding normal infant crying patterns and supporting parents and caregivers.

**For parents/caregivers:**
- Try soothing strategies: swaddle, hold skin-to-skin, offer a pacifier, rock, sing or speak softly, take a stroller walk or car ride.
- If you feel overwhelmed, calm yourself: place the baby safely down and walk away briefly, checking every 5–10 minutes. Reach out to friends, relatives, neighbors, helplines or healthcare providers for help.
- If crying persists, check for illness and contact the child’s doctor. Never leave the baby with someone who is easily angered, has a temper, or a history of violence.
- The National Maternal Mental Health Hotline (1-833-852-6262) offers 24/7 confidential support for pregnant and postpartum individuals and their loved ones.

**For friends, family and community members:**
- Look out for new parents who may need assistance or breaks.
- Offer to watch the baby so caregivers can rest.
- Encourage breaks if parents show frustration, ensuring the infant is safely placed in a crib.
- Provide empathetic support when caregivers are coping with crying.
- Advocate for workplace policies that allow parents more time with infants during high-crying periods (4–20 weeks of age).

Understanding infant crying and providing social support can prevent abusive head trauma and protect infants from life-threatening injuries.

title: Panic Disorder
body:
Panic disorder is an anxiety disorder characterised by frequent, unexpected panic attacks and ongoing worry about having more attacks. While occasional anxiety is a natural response to stress, people with panic disorder experience recurring episodes of intense fear or panic without clear triggers and often begin avoiding situations that might provoke attacks, creating a “fear of fear” cycle.

**Symptoms:**
- **Anxiety:** feelings of unease ranging from mild worry to severe fear.
- **Panic attacks:** sudden rushes of intense mental and physical symptoms such as racing heartbeat, faintness, sweating, nausea, chest pain, shortness of breath, trembling, hot flushes or chills, shaky limbs, choking sensation, dizziness, numbness or pins and needles, dry mouth, dread or fear of dying, churning stomach, tingling fingers, and feelings of detachment. Most attacks last 5–20 minutes (occasionally up to an hour) and, though frightening, are not dangerous. Symptoms may overlap with other conditions, so medical assessment is important.

**When to seek help:**
See a GP if you have panic symptoms. Diagnosis typically requires recurrent, unexpected panic attacks plus at least a month of persistent worry about further attacks. Doctors will review symptoms, frequency, duration, and may perform physical exams to exclude other causes.

**Treatment options:**
Aim to reduce attack frequency and severity. Main approaches include:
- **Talking therapies:** Cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) helps you understand panic responses and learn coping strategies. In England, you can self-refer to talking therapy services or seek GP referral.
- **Medications:** Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are first-line antidepressants; if unsuitable, tricyclic antidepressants (imipramine or clomipramine) may be offered. Anti-epileptic medicines such as pregabalin, or clonazepam for severe anxiety, can also be used. Antidepressants may take 2–4 weeks to begin working and up to 8 weeks for full effect. Continue medication unless advised otherwise by your GP.
- **Specialist referral:** If symptoms persist despite CBT, medication and support groups, your GP may refer you to a psychiatrist or clinical psychologist for further assessment and personalised treatment.

**Self-help strategies:**
- During a panic attack: stay in place if possible, breathe slowly and deeply, remind yourself the episode will pass, focus on calming imagery, and remember it isn’t life-threatening.
- Preventing future attacks: read CBT-based self-help books, practise relaxation (yoga, pilates), learn breathing techniques, engage in regular physical activity, and avoid triggers such as sugary foods, caffeine, alcohol and smoking.

**Support:**
Connecting with others who have panic disorder can help. Useful organisations include Anxiety UK, Mind, No Panic, and Triumph Over Phobia (TOP UK). Ask your GP about local support groups or mental health services.

**Complications:**
Untreated panic disorder can escalate, leading to agoraphobia, other phobias, or substance misuse. Inform the DVLA if panic disorder affects your driving ability.

**Causes:**
Exact causes are unclear but may involve traumatic or stressful experiences (e.g., bereavement), family history of panic disorder, or brain chemical imbalances.

**Children:**
If a child shows panic disorder symptoms, consult a GP. After medical evaluation, referral to a specialist and CBT may be recommended.

Panic disorder is treatable. Early medical help and a combination of therapy, medication, lifestyle changes, and support can significantly improve quality of life.

title: 8 Tips for Healthy Eating
body:
Balancing calorie intake with activity levels and eating a varied diet underpin healthy eating. Adults should aim for roughly 2,500 kcal/day for men and 2,000 kcal/day for women, though many consume more than needed. Following these eight tips supports a balanced diet:

1. **Base meals on higher-fibre starchy carbohydrates:** Starchy foods (potatoes, bread, rice, pasta, cereals) should make up just over one-third of your intake. Opt for wholegrain/higher-fibre versions (wholewheat pasta, brown rice, skin-on potatoes) to stay full longer. Include at least one starchy food per meal and watch added fats (e.g., butter, creamy sauces) to keep calories in check.

2. **Eat lots of fruit and vegetables:** Aim for at least five portions daily (fresh, frozen, canned, dried or juiced). A portion is 80 g for fresh/canned/frozen, 30 g for dried fruit (best at mealtimes). Limit fruit juice/vegetable juice/smoothies to 150 ml per day due to sugar content.

3. **Eat more fish, including oily fish:** Have at least two portions of fish weekly, with one being oily (salmon, trout, herring, sardines, pilchards, mackerel) for omega-3 fats that may protect heart health. Non-oily options include haddock, plaice, coley, cod, tuna, skate and hake. Fresh, frozen or canned fish all count, but canned/smoked fish can be high in salt, and some species have intake limits.

4. **Cut down on saturated fat and sugar:**
   - **Saturated fat:** Limit to ≤30 g/day for men and ≤20 g/day for women (less for children; low-fat diets unsuitable under age five). Sources include fatty meats, sausages, butter, hard cheese, cream, cakes, biscuits, lard and pies. Choose unsaturated fats such as vegetable oils, spreads, oily fish and avocados. Use small amounts of vegetable or olive oil instead of butter/ghee, select lean meats, and trim visible fat.
   - **Sugar:** Reduce free sugars (added sugars and those in honey, syrups, unsweetened juices) found in fizzy drinks, sugary cereals, cakes, biscuits, pastries, sweets, chocolate and alcohol. Excess sugar contributes to weight gain and tooth decay. Check labels: >22.5 g total sugars/100 g is high; ≤5 g is low.

5. **Eat less salt (≤6 g/day for adults):** Excess salt raises blood pressure, increasing heart disease and stroke risk. Around 75% of salt is already in processed foods (cereals, soups, bread, sauces). Use labels—>1.5 g salt/100 g is high. Children should have even less.

6. **Get active and maintain a healthy weight:** Combine healthy eating with regular physical activity to reduce disease risk and support overall wellbeing. Use BMI calculators to assess weight status. For weight loss, eat fewer calories and increase activity; the NHS 12-week weight loss plan offers guidance. See a GP or dietitian if underweight or concerned about weight.

7. **Do not get thirsty:** Drink 6–8 glasses of fluid daily (in addition to fluids from food). Water, lower-fat milk and low-sugar drinks (including tea/coffee) are healthier choices. Limit sugary soft drinks; keep fruit juice/smoothies to ≤150 ml/day. Drink more in hot weather or when exercising.

8. **Do not skip breakfast:** A healthy breakfast that is high in fibre and low in fat, sugar and salt contributes to a balanced diet. Examples include wholegrain, lower-sugar cereals with semi-skimmed milk and fruit. Breakfast helps provide essential nutrients and may prevent overeating later.

Eating a variety of foods across these tips ensures the body receives necessary nutrients while supporting weight management and overall health.

title: Risks of Drinking Too Much Alcohol
body:
Regularly consuming more than 14 units of alcohol per week can damage your health. Units depend on drink size and alcohol strength. Emerging evidence shows stronger links between routine drinking and illnesses, including various cancers, and the idea that moderate alcohol benefits heart health has been downgraded.

**Low-risk drinking guidance:**
- Men and women should limit intake to 14 units per week if they drink most weeks.
- Spread drinking over 3 or more days if you consume up to 14 units weekly.
- Include several alcohol-free days each week to cut down.
- If pregnant or planning pregnancy, the safest approach is complete abstinence to minimise risk to the baby.

**No safe level:**
Drinking under 14 units weekly is considered low risk, not “safe,” because no level is risk-free. Regularly exceeding 14 units for 10–20 years increases the likelihood of:
- Mouth, throat and breast cancers
- Stroke
- Heart and liver disease
- Brain and nervous system damage
High-risk drinking can worsen mental health and is associated with self-harm and suicide. Overall risk rises with higher consumption; the less you drink, the lower the risk. Understanding alcohol units can help you track intake.

**Single-session risks:**
Drinking too much too quickly on one occasion increases risks of:
- Accidental injuries or death
- Poor judgement in dangerous situations
- Loss of self-control, leading to unprotected sex or violence
To stay safer:
- Limit how much you drink in one session
- Drink slowly
- Consume alcohol with food
- Alternate alcoholic drinks with water or non-alcoholic options

Keeping alcohol intake within recommended limits, moderating single-session drinking, and taking alcohol-free days can significantly reduce health risks.

title: 5 Steps to Mental Wellbeing
body:
Evidence shows five actions can support mental wellbeing:

1. **Connect with other people:** Strong relationships build belonging, self-worth, opportunities to share positive experiences, and mutual support. Ideas include prioritising family time (e.g., regular dinners), arranging outings with friends, switching off screens to talk or play games, having lunch with a colleague, visiting someone who needs company, volunteering locally, and using video calls to stay in touch. Avoid relying solely on texts or social media to build relationships.

2. **Be physically active:** Activity benefits physical health and boosts mental wellbeing by raising self-esteem, providing goals, and triggering mood-enhancing brain chemistry. Explore exercise guidance (running, aerobic workouts), strength and flexibility routines, or wheelchair-friendly fitness advice. Choose enjoyable activities; you do not need long gym sessions.

3. **Learn new skills:** Learning boosts confidence, self-esteem, purpose and social connection. Options include cooking new recipes, taking on new responsibilities at work (mentoring, presentations), tackling DIY projects, enrolling in college courses (languages, practical skills), or trying new hobbies (blogging, sports, painting). Focus on enjoyable activities rather than formal qualifications unless they interest you.

4. **Give to others:** Acts of giving and kindness foster positive feelings, purpose, self-worth and connection. Examples include thanking someone for their help, genuinely asking about others’ wellbeing, spending time with those who need support, offering practical help on projects, or volunteering in schools, hospitals, or care homes.

5. **Pay attention to the present moment (mindfulness):** Awareness of your thoughts, feelings, body and surroundings helps you enjoy life more and better handle challenges. Mindfulness can positively shift your outlook and self-understanding. Practice everyday mindfulness techniques to stay present.

Incorporating these steps regularly can make you feel more positive and help you get the most out of life.

title: How to Improve Strength and Flexibility
body:
Strength exercises make muscles work harder than usual, increasing strength, size, power and endurance. They typically use body weight or resistance. Aim for at least two muscle-strengthening sessions weekly. Examples include lifting weights, resistance bands, heavy gardening (digging, shovelling), climbing stairs, hill walking, cycling, dancing, push-ups, sit-ups, squats and yoga. Leg-strengthening activities such as tai chi, yoga, dance, stair walking, hiking and weightlifting help maintain strength, balance and coordination, reducing fall risk as you age. A session counts if muscles work to the point you need a brief rest before continuing (e.g., putting down a weight after several reps).

Flexibility exercises improve joint mobility necessary for daily tasks. Activities include stretching, yoga, tai chi and pilates. Maintaining flexibility supports posture, reduces aches, lowers injury risk and helps preserve ability to perform everyday activities.

Benefits of strength and flexibility training include maintaining independence, slowing age-related bone and muscle loss, reducing fall risk, improving posture and lowering injury risk.

Guidelines:
- Work all major muscle groups (legs, hips, back, abdomen, chest, shoulders, arms) on two or more days per week. Sessions can be under 20 minutes.
- Perform exercises until completing another repetition without assistance would be difficult.
- Do 8–12 repetitions per exercise (one set) and aim for at least two sets (three sets for added benefit). Start gradually and build up over weeks.
- No specific duration is prescribed for flexibility work; integrate stretching or mobility activities regularly.

Aerobic exercise: for general health, complete 150 minutes of moderate-intensity activity weekly plus two strength sessions, or 75 minutes of vigorous-intensity activity covering both aerobic and strength needs. Time spent on strength exercises does not count towards the 150-minute aerobic goal, though some vigorous aerobic activities (circuit training, dancing, martial arts, football, hockey, rugby) also build strength.

Incorporating varied strength, flexibility and aerobic activities supports full-body fitness, bone health, balance, and resilience across the lifespan.

title: 5 Lifestyle Tips for a Healthy Tummy
body:
Simple lifestyle changes can prevent, ease or eliminate digestive problems:

1. **Beat stress:** Anxiety disrupts digestion—slowing it (bloating, pain, constipation) or speeding it up (diarrhoea). It can also worsen ulcers and irritable bowel syndrome. Managing and reducing stress helps maintain digestive balance.

2. **Stop smoking:** Smoking weakens the muscle at the lower end of the oesophagus, allowing stomach acid to flow back (reflux). This causes heartburn and can aggravate ulcers and inflammatory bowel conditions, and increases stomach cancer risk.

3. **Eat properly:** Adopt healthy eating habits: eat slowly and chew well; avoid overeating by reducing portion sizes or having 4–5 smaller meals; eat regularly without skipping meals; avoid large meals within 2–3 hours of bedtime; stay hydrated with plenty of water.

4. **Lose excess weight:** Abdominal fat places pressure on the stomach, triggering heartburn and acid-related symptoms. Weight loss can relieve these complaints. Use BMI calculators to check weight status and follow NHS weight-loss advice if needed.

5. **Avoid binge drinking:** Moderate alcohol intake may not harm digestion, but binge drinking (drinking too much in a single session) increases stomach acid production and can cause heartburn or aggravate other digestive disorders. Cutting down on alcohol helps protect digestive health.

Incorporating these habits supports a healthier digestive system and reduces the likelihood of stomach upsets.

title: Benefits of Quitting Smoking
body:
Quitting smoking improves health at any age. Once you stop, your body begins clearing toxins immediately, and benefits appear within days or weeks:

**Better physical health:**
- Enhanced senses of taste and smell.
- Easier breathing and more energy.
- Improved blood circulation, easing physical activity.
- Better lung function, reducing cough, wheezing and breathing problems.
- Brighter skin due to increased oxygen, and tar-free teeth.

**Reduced disease risk:**
- After 1 year, heart attack risk halves compared to a smoker’s.
- After 10 years, lung cancer death risk falls to half that of a smoker.
- After 15 years, heart attack risk equals that of someone who never smoked.
- Lower likelihood of type 2 diabetes, osteoporosis, eye disease and dementia.

**Better mental health:**
Despite the perception that smoking relieves stress, evidence shows quitting boosts mental wellbeing. After withdrawal, people experience lower anxiety, depression and stress, and higher positive mood—often within six weeks.

**Better for family and friends:**
Staying healthy lets you support loved ones longer and act as a smoke-free role model (children of smokers are four times more likely to start smoking). Quitting protects others from harmful secondhand smoke, especially children. Financially, the average smoker saves about £49 per week (over £2,500 annually) by quitting.

**Ways to quit:**
- **Stop-smoking products:** Nicotine replacement and other aids improve success compared to going “cold turkey.”
- **Support options:** Seek help via online groups, phone services, or face-to-face advisers—support significantly increases the chance of quitting for good.

Whatever your smoking history, quitting delivers rapid and long-term benefits for you and those around you.

title: Avoiding Foot Fungal Infections
body:
Athlete’s foot (tinea pedis) is a contagious fungal infection, often starting between the toes, particularly when feet are sweaty inside tight shoes. It relates to other fungal infections like ringworm and jock itch. Over-the-counter antifungal creams can treat it, though recurrences are common; prescription options exist for more persistent cases.

**Symptoms:**
- Scaly red rash, typically between toes.
- Itching that worsens after removing shoes and socks.
- Blisters or ulcers in some cases.
- Moccasin-type infection causes chronic dryness and scaling on the soles, mimicking eczema or dry skin.
- Infection can affect one or both feet and spread to the hands via scratching.

**Causes:**
- Fungi that thrive in damp, warm environments such as sweaty socks/shoes.
- Locker rooms and public showers can spread the fungus, but the inside of shoes is a major source.
- Transmitted via contact with infected individuals or surfaces (towels, floors, shoes).

**Prevention and care tips:**
- **Treat feet promptly:** Apply over-the-counter antifungal creams or drying powders 2 to 3 times daily until the rash disappears.
- **Keep feet dry:** Especially between the toes. Go barefoot at home to air feet, and dry thoroughly after bathing.
- **Wear breathable socks:** Choose natural fibers (cotton, wool) or moisture-wicking synthetics; change sweaty socks twice daily.
- **Choose ventilated footwear:** Avoid vinyl or rubber shoes; go for light, breathable materials.
- **Alternate shoes:** Rotate pairs daily to allow full drying between uses.
- **Protect feet in public places:** Wear waterproof sandals in pools, showers, and locker rooms.
- **Use antifungal powder daily:** Helps keep feet dry and fungus-free.
- **Do not share shoes:** Prevents fungal spread.

**When to seek medical care:**
- If rash persists despite self-care, consult a healthcare provider.
- People with diabetes should seek prompt medical evaluation, especially if signs of bacterial infection appear (redness, swelling, drainage, fever).
- Mild cases may respond to over-the-counter antifungal products; persistent or severe infections may require prescription topical treatments or oral antifungal medications.

Consistent foot hygiene, moisture control, and protective habits significantly reduce the risk of athlete’s foot and promote quicker recovery if infection occurs.

title: Water: How Much Should You Drink?
body: Water is essential to health, making up about 50% to 70% of body weight and supporting every cell, tissue and organ by removing waste, regulating temperature, cushioning joints and protecting tissues. Dehydration occurs when fluid intake is insufficient and even mild dehydration can cause fatigue. Daily fluid needs vary with health, activity level and environment, but the U.S. National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine recommend about 15.5 cups (3.7 liters) of fluids per day for men and 11.5 cups (2.7 liters) for women, including water, other beverages and foods (which typically contribute about 20% of intake). The “eight glasses a day” guideline is reasonable for many people, but needs should be adjusted for exercise (extra fluids before, during and after activity), hot or humid weather, high altitude, illness (fever, vomiting, diarrhea), certain medical conditions (bladder infections, urinary tract stones) and pregnancy or breastfeeding. Hydration can come from water-rich foods (fruits, vegetables) and beverages such as milk, juice and herbal tea; even caffeinated drinks contribute, though sugary beverages should be limited due to excess calories. Adequate hydration is indicated by infrequent thirst and pale urine. To stay hydrated, drink water with each meal and between meals, before/during/after exercise, and whenever thirsty. Drinking too much water is uncommon but can occur, especially in athletes overcompensating; excess intake can dilute blood sodium and cause hyponatremia, which is potentially life-threatening.

title: Nutrition Basics
body:
Nutrition advice evolves, but core principles focus on eating wholesome foods that support health. For personalised guidance, consult healthcare professionals or dietitians who consider your health, lifestyle and preferences.

**Healthy diets:**
Choose eating plans that:
- Include a variety of foods from major groups: fruits, vegetables, whole grains, low-fat dairy, lean proteins (beans, legumes, nuts, seeds) and healthy fats.
- Provide portion guidance for each group.
- Feature foods available at local grocery stores.
- Fit your tastes, lifestyle and budget.
Discuss specific health risks with your healthcare team (e.g., low-sodium diets for high blood pressure).

**Healthy cooking:**
Move away from highly processed foods high in calories, sugar, fat and salt. Use techniques like baking, grilling, steaming and sautéing. Focus on food safety, recipe modifications and flavorful approaches that reduce health risks while keeping meals satisfying.

**Healthy menus and shopping strategies:**
Plan healthier meals by exploring recipes and cookbooks. When shopping, prioritise fresh, frozen and minimally processed foods—spend more time in produce aisles, choose whole grains and low-fat dairy. Limit time in snack and candy aisles, and visit farmers markets for seasonal produce.

**Nutritional supplements:**
Supplements complement but do not replace a balanced diet. Most healthy people who eat varied foods may not need them. They can help in situations such as pregnancy (prenatal vitamins with folic acid), limited diets, allergies, intolerances, or medical conditions that restrict certain foods. Consult your healthcare team or dietitian about whether supplements are appropriate, potential side effects and interactions with medications.

title: Tobacco
body:
**Key facts:** Tobacco kills up to half of its users who don’t quit. More than 7 million people die annually from tobacco, including 1.6 million non-smokers exposed to second-hand smoke. About 80% of 1.3 billion tobacco users live in low- and middle-income countries. WHO Member States adopted the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (WHO FCTC) in 2003; 183 countries are Parties. WHO MPOWER measures align with the FCTC and reduce deaths and costs.

**Overview:** The tobacco epidemic is a major public health threat causing over 7 million deaths yearly plus long-term illness. All forms of tobacco are harmful with no safe exposure level. Cigarettes are most common; other products include waterpipe tobacco, cigars, cigarillos, heated tobacco, roll-your-own, pipe tobacco, bidis, kreteks and smokeless products. 80% of users live in low- and middle-income countries where illness and death are greatest. Tobacco use drives poverty by diverting spending from basic needs and is difficult to curb due to addiction. Economic costs include healthcare spending and lost productivity.

**Key measures to reduce demand:**
- **Surveillance:** Monitoring tobacco use helps tailor policies; nearly half the global population is surveyed through national representative studies.
- **Second-hand smoke kills:** There's no safe level. It causes cardiovascular and respiratory diseases, including coronary heart disease and lung cancer, killing ~1.6 million people annually. Over one-third of the population in 79 countries is protected by smoke-free laws.
- **Tobacco users need help to quit:** Counselling and medications can more than double quitting success. Comprehensive cessation services with cost coverage exist in only 31 countries covering one-third of the global population.
- **Pictorial health warnings work:** Graphic warnings and mass media campaigns prevent uptake and encourage quitting. 62% of the world’s population lives in 110 countries with best-practice warnings (≥50% of packaging, national language, rotating). 2.9 billion people live in 36 countries that ran strong anti-tobacco campaigns in the last 2 years.
- **Bans on tobacco advertising lower consumption:** TAPS recruit new users and deter quitting. 68 countries, over a quarter of the world’s population, have complete TAPS bans.
- **Taxes are effective:** Raising tobacco taxes is cost-effective, reducing consumption especially in youth and low-income groups. A 10% price increase cuts consumption ~4% in high-income and ~5% in low- and middle-income countries. Only 41 countries (12% of the population) tax tobacco at ≥75% of retail price.
- **Illicit trade must be stopped:** One in ten tobacco products is illicit, undermining health, economic and security goals. Many countries show illicit trade can be curbed even with higher taxes. The WHO FCTC Protocol to Eliminate Illicit Trade (ITP) provides key supply-side controls.

**Newer nicotine and tobacco products:**
- **Heated tobacco products (HTPs):** Produce aerosols with nicotine and toxic chemicals via heating. Despite risk-reduction claims, evidence doesn’t show they’re safer than conventional tobacco. Some toxicants are lower; others (e.g., glycidol, pyridine, dimethyl trisulfide, acetoin, methylglyoxal) may be higher. Some toxicants unique to HTPs have uncertain health impacts; some are carcinogens.
- **Electronic cigarettes (ENDS/ENNDS):** Include e-cigars, e-pipes; emissions typically contain nicotine and other toxic substances harmful to users and bystanders. Products claiming nicotine-free may still contain nicotine. Long-term impacts remain unclear, but evidence shows harm, including increased risk of heart disease and lung disorders. Nicotine exposure in pregnancy harms the fetus and affects brain development.
- **Nicotine pouches:** Pre-portioned pouches similar to snus, used between gum and lip, often marketed as “tobacco-free” or “white pouches.”

**WHO response:** There is a fundamental conflict between the tobacco industry and public health. The industry promotes addictive, deadly products causing societal harms, including poverty. The WHO FCTC is an evidence-based treaty affirming the right to health and providing legal frameworks for international cooperation, with 182 Parties covering >90% of the world’s population. In 2007, WHO launched MPOWER to scale up demand-reduction provisions. MPOWER measures: Monitor tobacco use and policies; Protect people from tobacco use; Offer help to quit; Warn about dangers; Enforce advertising bans; Raise taxes. WHO monitors MPOWER via the global tobacco epidemic reports.

title: Rehabilitation
body:
**Key facts**
- Rehabilitation is an essential part of universal health coverage along with promotion of good health, prevention of disease, treatment and palliative care.
- Rehabilitation helps a child, adult or older person to be as independent as possible in everyday activities and enables participation in education, work, recreation and meaningful life roles such as taking care of family.
- Globally, an estimated 2.4 billion people are currently living with a health condition that may benefit from rehabilitation.
- The need for rehabilitation worldwide is predicted to increase due to changes in the health and characteristics of the population. For example, people are living longer, but with more chronic disease and disability.
- Currently, the need for rehabilitation is largely unmet. In some low- and middle-income countries, more than 50% of people do not receive the rehabilitation services they require. Emergencies including conflicts, disasters and outbreaks create enormous surges in rehabilitation needs while also disrupting rehabilitation services.
- Rehabilitation is an important part of universal health coverage and is a key strategy for achieving Sustainable Development Goal 3 – “Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages”.

**Overview**
Rehabilitation is defined as “a set of interventions designed to optimize functioning and reduce disability in individuals with health conditions in interaction with their environment”. Rehabilitation helps people to be as independent as possible in everyday activities and to participate in education, work, recreation and family life. It addresses underlying conditions and symptoms, adapts environments, involves assistive products, supports self-management and modifies tasks to improve safety and independence. Rehabilitation can help with difficulties related to thinking, seeing, hearing, communicating, eating or moving. Anyone may need rehabilitation at some point due to injury, surgery, disease, illness or age-related decline.

Examples include speech and language training after brain injury; physical exercise training for stroke or Parkinson disease; modifying home environments for older adults; educating people with heart disease about safe exercise; preparing a person with an amputation for prosthetic use; positioning and splinting after burns; prescribing medicine to reduce spasticity in cerebral palsy; psychological therapies after spinal cord injury; social skills training for schizophrenia or autism; training individuals with vision loss to use a white cane; and working with intensive care patients to improve breathing and recovery.

Rehabilitation is person-centred, tailored to individual goals and preferences, and can be provided in inpatient or outpatient hospitals, physiotherapy or occupational therapy practices, community settings, homes, schools or workplaces. The workforce includes physiotherapists, occupational therapists, speech and language therapists, audiologists, orthotists, prosthetists, clinical psychologists, physical medicine and rehabilitation doctors, rehabilitation nurses and other health workers such as general practitioners, surgeons and community health workers.

**Benefits of rehabilitation**
Rehabilitation reduces the impact of many health conditions, complements medical and surgical interventions, facilitates recovery and prevents complications. It minimizes or slows disability in chronic conditions (cardiovascular disease, cancer, diabetes) by providing self-management strategies, assistive products and pain control. It supports healthy ageing. Rehabilitation is cost-effective, helping to avoid hospitalization, shorten stays, prevent re-admissions and enable work or independence, thereby reducing financial and caregiver burdens. Rehabilitation is essential for universal health coverage and achieving SDG 3.

**Misconceptions**
Rehabilitation is not only for people with disabilities or long-term physical impairments; it is an essential health service for anyone with a condition or injury limiting function. It is not a luxury; timely, high-quality, affordable rehabilitation should be available to all and integrated early with other health interventions.

**Unmet global need**
About 2.4 billion people could benefit from rehabilitation, and demand is growing due to ageing populations, chronic diseases, injuries and developmental conditions. In many regions, especially low- and middle-income countries, more than half of those needing rehabilitation do not receive it. Barriers include lack of prioritization, funding, policies, services outside urban areas, long waiting times, high out-of-pocket costs, insufficient trained professionals (often fewer than 10 per million population), limited resources (assistive technology, equipment), insufficient research and data, and weak referral pathways.

**Rehabilitation in emergencies**
Disasters, conflicts, outbreaks and other hazards create surges in rehabilitation needs and disrupt services, particularly affecting vulnerable populations and weak health systems. Although rehabilitation’s role is recognized in guidelines, it is rarely included in preparedness and early response, leading to magnified service limitations, less efficient health delivery and increased impairment risks.

**WHO response**
Strengthening health systems is essential to ensure rehabilitation services are available at all levels, including primary care, and integrated into universal health coverage. WHO’s work is guided by the World Health Assembly resolution on strengthening rehabilitation in health systems and implemented through the Rehabilitation 2030 initiative. WHO supports Member States in areas such as leadership and governance, financing, health information systems, service delivery, workforce, research and evidence, and emergency preparedness. Tools and resources include policy briefs, rehabilitation packages, competency frameworks, workforce evaluation guides, the Rehabilitation Need Estimator, and standards for emergencies. WHO also promotes advocacy through the World Rehabilitation Alliance.

title: Heat and health
body:
**Key facts**
- Heat is a major environmental and occupational health hazard. Heat stress is the leading cause of weather-related deaths and can worsen cardiovascular disease, diabetes, mental health conditions, asthma, and the risk of accidents and some infectious diseases. Heatstroke is a medical emergency with a high case-fatality rate.
- The number of people exposed to extreme heat is rising exponentially in every world region due to climate change. Heat-related mortality among people over 65 years increased by about 85% between 2000–2004 and 2017–2021 (1).
- Between 2000–2019, studies estimate about 489 000 heat-related deaths each year, with 45% occurring in Asia and 36% in Europe (2). Europe recorded an estimated 61 672 heat-related excess deaths in the summer of 2022 (3). Past high-intensity events caused severe mortality, including 70 000 deaths in Europe during June–August 2003 and 56 000 excess deaths during a 44-day heatwave in the Russian Federation in 2010.
- Vulnerability to heat depends on physiological factors (age, health status) and exposure factors (occupation, socio-economic conditions).
- Heat impacts are predictable and largely preventable through targeted public health and multisectoral policies and interventions. WHO guidance supports institutions in identifying and managing extreme heat risks. Climate action combined with preparedness and risk management can save lives now and in the future.

**Overview**
A heatwave is a period when local excess heat builds over several unusually hot days and nights. Heatwaves and prolonged excess heat are becoming more frequent, longer, and more intense because of climate change. Even low or moderate events can harm vulnerable populations. Extended periods of high day and nighttime temperatures generate cumulative stress on the human body, raising illness and mortality risks. Heatwaves can affect large populations quickly, trigger public health emergencies, cause excess mortality, and create socioeconomic impacts such as lost work capacity and productivity. Power shortages during heat can disrupt health facilities, transport, and water infrastructure, reducing health service delivery.

Population ageing and the rising prevalence of noncommunicable diseases (respiratory, cardiovascular, diabetes, dementia, renal, musculoskeletal) heighten susceptibility to heat. Urban design deficiencies—loss of greenspace, heat-amplifying materials like metal roofs—further increase exposure. Awareness of heat risks remains insufficient among health workers and the public, underscoring the need to adjust guidance, planning, and interventions and to manage sharp increases in admissions during heatwaves. Practical, feasible, often low-cost measures across individual, community, organizational, governmental, and societal levels can save lives.

**Who is affected?**
Populations in tropical and subtropical climates are chronically exposed to high temperatures, while exposure in mid to high latitudes is seasonal. Adult vulnerabilities tied to physiological or clinical factors are well documented (4). Heat affects health via multiple direct and indirect mechanisms, although evidence on chronic exposure to persistent high temperatures and humidity is limited.

Outdoor and manual workers, athletes, and civil protection personnel are at risk of exertional heat stress due to their work. Urban and rural poor often face overheating because of low-quality housing and limited cooling access; informal settlements can be hotter than other urban areas. Gender roles may influence exposure, such as women cooking indoors during hot weather.

**How does heat impact health?**
Heat retained in the body depends on an inability to dissipate metabolically generated heat under environmental stress (high temperature, humidity, low wind, high thermal radiation), clothing that blocks heat loss, and external heat gain. When thermoregulation fails, the risks of heat exhaustion and heatstroke rise, and the body’s cooling effort stresses the heart and kidneys. Heat extremes exacerbate chronic conditions (cardiovascular, mental, respiratory, diabetes) and can cause acute kidney injury.

Heat-related deaths and hospitalizations occur rapidly, often the same day or shortly after a heat event, so interventions must be swift once a heat alert is issued. Heat can disrupt essential services through power or transport outages, decrease productivity, increase accident risk, hinder work or learning, and even close schools or institutions. Heatwaves may coincide with hazardous air pollution. The health impact scale depends on the timing, intensity, and duration of events and the acclimatization and adaptability of local populations, infrastructure, and institutions.

**What actions should the public take?**

*Stay out of the heat*
- Avoid outdoor and strenuous activity during the hottest part of the day.
- Stay in the shade; perceived temperatures in direct sun may be 10–15 °C higher.
- Spend 2–3 hours daily in a cool place.
- Never swim alone and be mindful of drowning risks.
- Monitor official heat warnings.

*Keep your home cool*
- Use night air to cool the home by opening windows when outdoor temperatures drop below indoor levels.
- During hotter daytime periods, keep windows closed and shaded with blinds or shutters, and switch off unnecessary electrical devices.
- Use electric fans only when temperatures are below 40 °C / 104 °F; above this threshold they heat the body.
- If using air conditioning, set the thermostat to 27 °C / 81 °F and run an electric fan to feel roughly 4 °C cooler while saving up to 70% on cooling costs.
- Remember shaded outdoor areas may be cooler than indoors.

*Keep your body cool and hydrated*
- Wear light, loose-fitting clothing and bedding.
- Take cool showers or baths.
- Cool skin with damp cloths, sprays, or wet light clothing.
- Drink water regularly (about one cup per hour and at least 2–3 litres daily).
- Check frequently on vulnerable people, especially those over 65, individuals with heart, lung, or kidney conditions, people with disabilities, and those living alone.

*Protect infants and children*
- Never leave children or animals in parked vehicles; temperatures rise dangerously fast.
- Avoid direct sun during peak hours by seeking shade or staying indoors; shade can reduce perceived heat by more than 10 °C.
