Care plans cover insulin selection and dosing schedules, blood glucose targets, regular HbA1c reviews (2–4 times/year), hypo/hyper awareness and management, lifestyle guidance (diet, alcohol, driving, exercise, sick-day rules), complication screening, and wellbeing support. Equipment (e.g., glucose meters, insulin delivery tools) is provided, and regular follow-up appointments are scheduled.

**Insulin:**
Multiple insulin types are taken at different times. Doses are calculated and delivered via injections (pens) several times daily or via insulin pumps. Excess insulin can cause hypoglycaemia; patients are trained to recognise and treat hypos. Insulin regimens are individualised. People with type 1 diabetes qualify for free prescriptions in the UK.

**Insulin pumps:**
Continuous subcutaneous insulin infusion devices reduce hypos and improve glucose control. Eligibility on the NHS includes inability to meet HbA1c targets without severe hypos or persistently high HbA1c despite optimal management; pumps are recommended for children under 12 who struggle with multiple daily injections.

**Hybrid closed loop systems:**
Some pumps integrate with continuous glucose monitors (CGM) to automate insulin dosing. These systems lessen hypos, improve glucose control, and reduce management burden. Availability on the NHS is expanding, with priority for individuals under 18, those pregnant/planning pregnancy, or those not achieving control with pump or CGM alone.

**Appointments and tests:**
At least annual diabetes check-ups (more frequent initially) include HbA1c (past 8–12 weeks), weight/BMI, cholesterol, blood pressure, kidney and thyroid function, and mental wellbeing assessments. Additional routine care includes HbA1c tests every 3–6 months, diabetic eye screening every 1–2 years, and annual foot checks. Children under 12 may require fewer tests.

**Diabetes courses:**
Education programmes (free within 1 year of diagnosis) build confidence and self-management skills. Options include DAFNE (Dose Adjustment for Normal Eating) and BERTIE Diabetes (online). Courses cover insulin adjustment, diet, and practical living strategies.

title: Type 2 diabetes symptoms and diagnosis
body:
**Common symptoms:**
- Persistent tiredness
- Frequent urination
- Constant thirst
- Unintentional weight loss

Other signs include blurred vision, slow-healing cuts/wounds, and genital itching or recurrent thrush. Symptoms can appear gradually and may be absent in some individuals. Presentation overlaps with type 1 diabetes, but type 1 typically develops faster and is more common in younger people.

**Risk factors:**
Higher risk if you’re white and over 40 years old, or over 25 from South Asian, Chinese, Black African, or Black Caribbean backgrounds. Family history (parent or sibling), overweight/low physical activity, and certain conditions (e.g., high blood pressure) increase risk. Though less common in children, ethnicity, weight, activity, and family history contribute to pediatric risk too.

**When to see a GP:**
Consult a GP if you or your child have symptoms or risk factors. Routine checks are important because many people have no symptoms. Diabetes UK’s Know Your Risk tool and free NHS Health Checks (ages 40–74 without existing conditions) help assess risk for diabetes and other health issues.

**Diagnosis:**
A blood test measures glucose levels; results typically arrive in a few days. Additional tests differentiate type 1 from type 2 diabetes. Discuss questions about testing and next steps with healthcare professionals.

**If diagnosed with type 2 diabetes:**
The diagnosis can feel overwhelming, but your diabetes care team (doctors, nurses, other professionals) can address treatment questions and ongoing management.

**Prediabetes:**
Prediabetes signifies elevated blood glucose not yet reaching diabetic levels, raising future risk. Many people lack classic symptoms. Focus on healthy eating, physical activity, and lifestyle changes to prevent progression; work with your care team for tailored guidance.

**Education courses:**
Programmes like DESMOND (Diabetes Education for Self-Management for Ongoing and Newly Diagnosed) and X-PERT Health support patients and families with knowledge and skills for type 2 diabetes management.

title: Fungal nail infection
body:
Fungal nail infections typically begin at the nail edge and gradually spread, causing thick, brittle, crumbly nails that can turn white or yellow. Although usually not serious, they are slow to treat and often affect toenails, occasionally fingernails.

**Symptoms:**
- Discolouration (yellow/white patches)
- Thickening and brittleness
- Crumbling edges or lifting from the nail bed
- Swelling or pain around the nail in severe cases

**Pharmacy care:**
Pharmacists can advise on topical antifungal nail treatments applied daily or weekly for 6–12 months. These aren’t suitable for everyone (e.g., under 18s, pregnant or breastfeeding people). Improvement is seen as healthy nail regrows from the base.

**When to see a GP:**
Seek medical advice if infection is severe, spreads to other nails, or if you have diabetes or a weakened immune system (e.g., post-transplant, chemotherapy). GP assessment is also advised when pharmacy treatments fail.

**Medical treatment:**
GPs may prescribe oral antifungal tablets after confirming the infection type via nail sampling (and possibly blood tests). Treatment can last up to six months and may cause side effects (headache, rash, stomach upset, nausea, diarrhoea). Tablets are unsuitable for some people (liver/kidney disease, pregnancy, breastfeeding). Severely affected nails might require surgical removal under local anaesthetic.

**Prevention tips:**
- Treat athlete’s foot promptly
- Keep nails short, feet clean and dry
- Wear clean socks, well-fitting shoes, and flip-flops in communal showers
- Discard old footwear
- Avoid shoes that trap heat, and don’t share towels, footwear, or nail tools

Persistent warmth and dampness (e.g., prolonged trainer use) raise infection risk. Prompt treatment and good foot hygiene help prevent recurrence.

title: Jet lag
body:
Jet lag occurs when long flights disrupt your normal sleep pattern. Symptoms usually improve within a few days as your body adjusts to the new time zone.

**Reducing jet lag:**
- Rest well before travel; gradually shift your sleep schedule toward the destination time zone.
- **During flights:** Stay hydrated, move around regularly, try sleeping if it’s nighttime at your destination, and use eye masks or earplugs if helpful. Avoid excessive caffeine or alcohol.
- **After arrival:** Align sleep with local time quickly, set alarms to prevent oversleeping, and get daylight exposure to reset your body clock. Avoid daytime naps—sleep only at night. For short trips (2–3 days), consider keeping your home schedule to avoid repeated adjustments.

**Treatment:**
Medications are usually unnecessary. Jet lag typically resolves as circadian rhythms realign. Short-term sleeping tablets may help severe insomnia but carry dependency risks. Melatonin tablets aren’t recommended on the NHS due to insufficient evidence.

**Symptoms:**
Difficulty sleeping at the correct times, daytime fatigue, poor sleep quality, decreased concentration/memory, and sometimes indigestion, nausea, constipation, appetite changes, or mild anxiety.

title: Kidney stones
body:
Kidney stones are hard deposits that form in one or both kidneys, most common between ages 30 and 60, and affect over 1 in 10 people. They can reside in the kidneys or ureter (the tube to the bladder). Left untreated, stones can cause severe pain, infections, or kidney impairment.

**Symptoms:**
Small stones may pass unnoticed. Larger stones can cause side abdominal pain, severe intermittent pain, and nausea or vomiting.

**Urgent medical help:**
Contact a GP or NHS 111 if you experience severe pain, fever/shivering, or blood in urine.

**Causes:**
Waste products in blood can crystallize in kidneys, forming stones over time. Risks increase with inadequate fluid intake, certain medications, or medical conditions that elevate specific urine substances.

**Treatment and prevention:**
Many stones pass naturally with urine; symptoms can often be managed at home with medication. Larger stones may require surgical removal or fragmentation. Up to half of individuals may have recurrence within five years. Preventive strategies include staying well hydrated and keeping urine pale to dilute waste products.

**Kidney function:**
Kidneys are bean-shaped organs (~10 cm) located toward the back of the abdomen on either side of the spine. They filter waste from blood, returning clean blood to circulation and eliminating waste through urine.

title: Fever treatment: Quick guide to treating a fever
body:
A fever is a common sign of illness and may help fight infections; these tips apply to people without serious health issues such as immune suppression, chemotherapy use or recent surgery.

**Symptoms:**
- Adults with a fever should watch for a bad headache, stiff neck, shortness of breath or other concerning symptoms that warrant medical advice.

**When to See a Doctor:**
- Infants 0-3 months: Rectal temperature 100.4 F (38 C) or higher — contact a healthcare professional, even if no other symptoms appear.
- Infants 3-6 months (up to 102 F rectal): Ensure rest and fluids; call a healthcare professional if the child is unusually cranky, low-energy or uncomfortable.
- Infants 3-6 months (above 102 F rectal): Call the healthcare professional, who may recommend an exam.
- Infants 6-24 months (above 102 F rectal): Give age-appropriate acetaminophen or ibuprofen, avoid aspirin, and call if the fever resists medicine or lasts beyond one day.
- Children 2-17 years (up to 102 F): Encourage rest and fluids; contact healthcare if the child is very cranky, lacks energy or feels significant discomfort.
- Children 2-17 years (above 102 F): Provide acetaminophen or ibuprofen (avoid duplicating acetaminophen in other medicines and do not use aspirin); call if the fever persists despite medicine or exceeds three days.
- Adults up to 102 F oral: Rest, hydrate and seek medical help if severe symptoms like headache, stiff neck or shortness of breath accompany the fever.
- Adults above 102 F oral: Use acetaminophen, ibuprofen or aspirin as directed and contact a healthcare professional if the fever does not respond, reaches 103 F (39.4 C) or lasts longer than three days.

title: How to treat the common cold at home
body:
Overview:
Colds are very common. A visit with your health care provider is often not needed, and most colds get better in about a week. Some symptoms, such as runny nose and cough can last 14 days or longer.

A type of germ called a virus causes most colds. There are many types of viruses that can cause a cold. Depending on what virus you have, your symptoms may vary.

Common symptoms of a cold include:
- Fever (100°F [37.7°C] or higher) and chills
- Headache, sore muscles, and fatigue
- Cough
- Nasal symptoms, such as stuffiness, runny nose, yellow or green mucus, and sneezing
- Sore throat

Mild symptoms of COVID-19 may be similar to those of the common cold. Always check with your provider if you are at risk for COVID-19.

Treating Your Cold:
Treating your symptoms will not make your cold go away, but it will help you feel better.

Acetaminophen (Tylenol) and ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin) help lower fever and relieve muscle aches. Aspirin can also treat a cold, but it may have potential serious side effects, such as stomach bleeding. So it's best to avoid using aspirin. Aspirin should never be used in children and teens due to the risk of Reye syndrome.

When taking over-the-counter (OTC) pain relievers:
- Check the label for the proper dose.
- Contact your provider if you need to take these medicines more than 4 times per day or for more than 2 or 3 days.

OTC cold and cough medicines may help ease symptoms in adults and older children:
- Do not give OTC cough and cold medicine to children under age 4, as they can have serious side effects.
- For children ages 4 to 6 years, contact your provider before giving your child OTC cold medicine.
- If you take prescription medicines for another health problem, ask your provider which OTC cold medicines are safe for you.

Many OTC multi-symptom cough and cold medicines use more than one medicine. Instead of buying OTC remedies with multiple medicines, treat each symptom individually. That way you know how much you are taking of each medicine. If you do opt for these medicines, be sure to read the labels carefully to make sure you do not take too much of any one medicine.

To treat individual symptoms:
- A nasal decongestant can help relieve stuffiness and a runny nose.
- Throat lozenges or sprays can help ease a sore throat.
- Coughing is your body's way of getting mucus out of your lungs. So only use cough medicines if needed.
- A cough suppressant can help if your cough keeps you from getting enough rest or sleeping at night.
- If you are coughing up thick mucus, a cough expectorant may help. It thins mucus so it's easier to cough it up.

Here are other things you can do to help relieve a cold:
- Drink plenty of water and other fluids without caffeine. You lose a lot of fluid from coughing and blowing your nose, and this will help you stay hydrated.
- Gargle with warm salt water to help relieve a sore throat.
- Prop yourself up with pillows at night to help relieve your cough so you can sleep.
- A humidifier may help ease symptoms. Follow all instructions for cleaning the machine.
- Breathe in steam by taking a hot shower, or putting your head under a towel and over a bowl of hot water.
- Take time to rest and get plenty of sleep.
- Stay away from secondhand smoke.

Wheezing can be a common symptom of a cold if you have asthma:
- Use your rescue inhaler as prescribed if you are wheezing.
- See your provider immediately if it becomes hard to breathe.

Do not ask your provider for antibiotics to treat a common cold. Keep in mind that antibiotics kill bacteria. They will not treat a common cold, which is caused by a virus.

Home Remedies:
Many home remedies are popular treatments for the common cold. These include vitamin C, zinc supplements, and echinacea.

Although not proven to be helpful, most home remedies are safe for most people:
- Some remedies may cause side effects or allergic reactions.
- Certain remedies may change the way other medicines work.
- Contact your provider before trying any herbs and supplements.

Preventing the Spread of Colds:
Wash your hands often. This is the best way to stop the spread of germs.

To wash your hands correctly:
- Rub soap onto wet hands for 20 seconds. Make sure to get under your fingernails. Dry your hands with a clean towel or air dryer and turn the faucet off with a towel.
- You can also use alcohol-based hand sanitizers with at least 60% alcohol. Use a dime sized amount and rub all over your hands until they are dry.

To further prevent colds:
- Stay home when you are sick.
- Cough or sneeze into a tissue or into the crook of your elbow and not into the air.

When to Call the Doctor:
Try treating your cold at home first. Contact your provider right away, or go to the emergency room, if you have:
- Difficulty breathing
- Sudden chest pain or abdominal pain
- Sudden dizziness
- Acting strangely
- Severe vomiting that does not go away

Also contact your provider if:
- You start acting strangely
- Your symptoms get worse or do not improve after 10 days

title: Natural cough remedies
body:
Allergies, infections and acid reflux are common triggers for cough, and some people explore natural options to ease symptoms even though scientific evidence is limited.

**Causes:**
- Cough may stem from allergies, respiratory infections or acid reflux, which irritate the airways.

**Treatment:**
- Safety first: Herbs and supplements are not FDA-monitored, may be low quality and can interact with medications, so research brands and talk with a doctor before use.
- Honey: Shown in a 2021 review to suppress cough and reduce antibiotic need compared with usual care; take a spoonful or add to hot drinks.
- Hot fluids: Clear broths, herbal teas, decaf black tea or hot water with honey and ginger can soothe the throat and ease coughing.
- Steam: Hot showers or baths that fill the room with steam may temporarily relieve wet, mucus-producing coughs, though evidence is mixed.
- Marshmallow root: Traditional remedy that may ease coughs by adding mucilage to drinks; evidence relies on older or small studies, so more research is needed.
- Saltwater gargle: Dissolve 1/2 teaspoon salt in warm water, let cool slightly, gargle and spit; repeat several times daily to loosen mucus and reduce throat discomfort.
- Bromelain: Pineapple-derived enzyme with anti-inflammatory and mucolytic properties; some drink pineapple juice to cut mucus, but the juice may not contain enough bromelain for strong effects.
